column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The former Liberal minister Philip Ruddock has been appointed to examine if Australian law adequately protects the human right to religious freedom. Ruddock’s appointment by cabinet, announced on Wednesday, is designed to head off a bruising debate about religious amendments in a same-sex marriage bill, but the treasurer, Scott Morrison, said the review was “no substitute” for those amendments. The prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, said it was important to look at the issue of religious freedom carefully, in light of the yes vote and impending legislation on marriage equality. While senior conservatives including Peter Dutton and Mathias Cormann have publicly suggested a religious freedom bill can be considered next year, separately to a marriage bill, others including Morrison and Liberal senator, David Fawcett, have insisted it be considered at the same time. Ruddock has been asked to report by 31 March. Turnbull said a variety of proposals for legislative changes to protect freedom of religion have been put forward in recent months but many of them go beyond the immediate issue of marriage, and parliament needed to be wary of them. “Any reforms to protect religious freedom at large should be undertaken carefully,” he said in a statement on Wednesday. “There is a high risk of unintended consequences when parliament attempts to legislate protections for basic rights and freedoms, such as freedom of religion. The government is particularly concerned to prevent uncertainties caused by generally worded bill of rights-style declarations. “This will be a timely expert stocktake to inform consideration of any necessary legislative reforms.” Turnbull said Ruddock was the right person to conduct the review because he had served as Australia’s special envoy for human rights.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  There should be 5 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: ***
column4:
# Philip Ruddock to Examine Religious Freedom Protections in Australia

Former Liberal minister Philip Ruddock has been appointed by the Australian cabinet to review whether Australian law adequately protects religious freedom. This appointment comes amid debates over same-sex marriage legislation, with Treasurer Scott Morrison emphasizing that the review is "no substitute" for religious amendments to the marriage bill.

***

Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull highlighted the importance of examining religious freedom carefully in light of the recent "yes" vote on marriage equality. The review represents a response to varying positions within the government, as senior conservatives like Peter Dutton and Mathias Cormann have suggested addressing religious freedom separately next year, while others including Morrison and Senator David Fawcett insist on concurrent consideration.

***

Ruddock has been given a deadline of March 31 to complete his report. Turnbull expressed caution about legislative changes to protect religious freedom, noting that many proposals extend beyond marriage-related issues and require careful consideration by parliament.

***

The Prime Minister warned about potential "unintended consequences" when legislating protections for basic rights and freedoms. The government specifically wants to avoid uncertainties that might arise from "generally worded bill of rights-style declarations," preferring a more measured approach.

***

Turnbull endorsed Ruddock as the ideal person to conduct this review based on his previous experience serving as Australia's special envoy for human rights. The review is described as a "timely expert stocktake" that will inform consideration of any necessary legislative reforms regarding religious freedom.
column5:
The former Liberal minister Philip Ruddock has been appointed by the cabinet to review whether Australian law sufficiently protects the human right to religious freedom.  

***  

Ruddock’s appointment comes amidst heated discussions about religious amendments linked to a same-sex marriage bill, with the move intended to pre-empt further debate on the issue.  

***  

Senior conservatives have floated the possibility of a separate religious freedom bill next year, while others, including Treasurer Scott Morrison, argue for addressing the matter alongside marriage legislation.  

***  

Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull emphasized the need for a careful examination of religious freedom issues, noting that past proposals have extended well beyond the immediate concerns surrounding marriage equality.  

***  

Turnbull warned against broadly worded, bill-of-rights style reforms due to the risk of unintended consequences, stating that Ruddock’s review, to be completed by 31 March, is a timely expert assessment to guide any future legislative changes.
column6:
Former Liberal minister Philip Ruddock has been appointed to examine the adequacy of Australian law in protecting religious freedom. The appointment, made by the cabinet, is intended to preempt a contentious debate regarding religious amendments to the same-sex marriage bill. However, Treasurer Scott Morrison stated that the review is "no substitute" for these amendments.

***

Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull emphasized the importance of careful consideration of religious freedom, particularly in light of the impending marriage equality legislation. While some senior conservatives have suggested considering a religious freedom bill separately next year, others insist it be addressed concurrently with the marriage bill.

***

Ruddock is expected to submit his report by March 31. Turnbull noted that various proposals for legislative changes to protect religious freedom have been presented, many extending beyond the immediate issue of marriage, and parliament needs to be cautious.

***

Turnbull cautioned against unintended consequences when legislating protections for basic rights and freedoms, such as freedom of religion. The government is particularly concerned about uncertainties arising from broadly worded bill of rights-style declarations.

***

Turnbull believes Ruddock is well-suited to conduct the review, citing his experience as Australia's special envoy for human rights, and describes the review as a "timely expert stocktake" to inform any necessary legislative reforms.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Last weekend Faced with a quiet moment, Donald Trump tends to stir up a spat with a sports star or a celebrity, seemingly in order to open new fronts in America’s “culture wars” and reassure his base about which side he’s on. When it comes to sports, Trump’s targets are often African American, and he pursued a few such targets this week. Regular readers may remember that when last week the president asked China to free three UCLA basketball players accused of shoplifting, his main concern was that the players would thank him, which they did. But when LaVar Ball, the father of one of the arrested players and an inveterate attention seeker himself, questioned just how critical a role Trump actually played, it enraged the president. “I should have left them in jail!” he tweeted on Sunday, adding six hours later that he “should have gotten his son [LiAngelo Ball] out during my next trip to China instead … Very ungrateful!” Trump – whose sons Donald Jr and Eric are well-known hunters – also gave more clues about his perhaps surprisingly critical views on the US Fish and Wildlife Service plan to allow imports of elephant trophies from Zimbabwe and Zambia, tweeting: “Big-game trophy decision will be announced next week but will be very hard pressed to change my mind that this horror show in any way helps conservation of Elephants or any other animal.” Monday Returning to his racially tinged offensive, Trump singled out Marshawn Lynch of the Oakland Raiders for sitting down during the playing of The Star-Spangled Banner. “Great disrespect!” tweeted the president, adding another dog whistle for the base when he pointed out that Lynch had stood up “for the Mexican anthem”. Black athletes have been protesting during the national anthem since the summer, to highlight police violence and racial injustice. Tuesday Sexual misconduct accusations against the Republican Senate candidate Roy Moore are a less divisive issue, at least outside Alabama – Moore has been condemned widely, including by numerous GOP figures. But after some prevaricating Trump came down on the candidate’s side. Asked the memorable question “Is Roy Moore, [allegedly] a child molester, better than a Democrat?”, Trump pointed out that Moore denied the claims against him, one of which involves a woman who was 14 at the time, and said: “I can tell you one thing for sure: we don’t need a liberal person in there, a Democrat.” Trump has himself been accused by numerous women of sexual harassment.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['dare', 'dependent', 'manner', 'presentation', 'principle'] in the response. Your answer must contain exactly 4 bullet points. Use the markdown bullet points such as:
* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2 Your response should contain at least 11 sentences. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Finish your response with this exact phrase Is there anything else I can help with?. No other words should follow this phrase.
column4:
"* Trump's manner of creating controversy with African American sports figures appears to be a calculated presentation to his base, highlighting his dare to challenge these athletes on issues like protesting during the national anthem, as seen with his criticism of Marshawn Lynch and LaVar Ball.

* The president's dependent relationship with public approval becomes evident in his demands for gratitude from UCLA basketball players he helped free from China, exhibiting anger when LaVar Ball questioned his role and threatening he "should have left them in jail."

* Despite his family's hunting background, Trump showed a surprising principle regarding conservation by expressing opposition to the Fish and Wildlife Service plan to allow elephant trophy imports, calling it a "horror show" that wouldn't help conservation efforts.

* Trump's handling of Roy Moore's sexual misconduct allegations demonstrates his partisan presentation approach, where he ultimately sided with Moore despite widespread condemnation, stating as a matter of principle that "we don't need a liberal person in there," while ignoring the dependent relationship between his own position and similar accusations made against himself.

Is there anything else I can help with?"
column5:
"1. The article opens by highlighting how former President Donald Trump frequently stirs up controversy, especially by targeting sports figures as part of his broader culture wars. 
2. It details several instances where his provocative tweets have escalated conflicts, notably with African American athletes and public figures involved in sports-related matters. 
3. Trump’s remarks extend to issues such as trophy hunting policies and sexual misconduct controversies, demonstrating an approach that is both aggressive and polarizing. 
4. The narrative reveals that his public actions are strategically dependent on provoking cultural and political divisions among his base. 
* Trump’s behavior dares to challenge societal norms by engaging in confrontations that resonate deeply with his political supporters. 
* His responses to controversies are heavily influenced by a dependent need to maintain loyalty among his followers. 
* He consistently employs a distinctive manner in his public presentations, blending humor with harsh criticism to amplify his message. 
* The underlying principle in his actions appears to be to provoke a reaction, ensuring that each controversy perpetuates the culture wars he orchestrates. 
The article uses detailed descriptions to emphasize both the planned and spontaneous nature of his provocations. 
It also shows how his controversial tweets spark immediate and divisive public debates. 
Moreover, the narrative paints a picture of a leader who leverages every opportunity to assert dominance in political storytelling. 
Is there anything else I can help with?"
column6:
"Here's a summary of the provided news article excerpt, incorporating the specified keywords:

*   Donald Trump, seemingly **dependent** on maintaining support from his base, engaged in multiple controversies, particularly targeting African Americans. He initially sought praise for intervening in the UCLA basketball players' shoplifting case in China. When LaVar Ball questioned Trump's role, the president responded with angry tweets, suggesting he should have left the players in jail. The **manner** in which Trump expected gratitude highlights a transactional approach to his presidential actions. He seems to **dare** people to question his actions.

*   Continuing his racially charged rhetoric, Trump criticized Marshawn Lynch for sitting during the US national anthem but standing for the Mexican anthem. This **presentation** of Lynch's actions was clearly meant to provoke a reaction from his supporters and further inflame racial tensions, particularly in light of the ongoing protests by black athletes against racial injustice and police violence.

*   While many Republicans condemned Roy Moore over accusations of sexual misconduct, Trump eventually sided with the candidate. Moore denies the claims, one of which alleges relations with a 14-year-old girl. He argued that it was more important to have a Republican in the Senate than a Democrat, despite the severity of the accusations against Moore.

*   The excerpt also touches on Trump's potential reversal of a ban on importing elephant trophies, indicating a surprising perspective on conservation efforts, defying the expected pro-hunting stance, at least superficially. This suggests a potential clash with the **principle** of conservation, and a willingness to prioritize other considerations when making policy decisions, or he is just trying to find attention by going against type. It also suggests that his sons' hunting habits do not influence his decision, at least in this case.

Is there anything else I can help with?"

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Thibaut Courtois does not expect discussions to resume over a new contract at Chelsea until the end of the season, when he will be entering the final 12 months of his deal. The previous round of talks in May failed to reach an agreement. The goalkeeper, who spent three successful years on loan at Atlético Madrid after joining Chelsea from Genk, has been an integral part of the team who have won two Premier League titles in the past three seasons. His agent, Christophe Henrotay, held talks with the champions towards the end of last season, seeking to take the Belgian’s wages closer to the £200,000 a week level enjoyed by Eden Hazard at Stamford Bridge and another of the division’s elite goalkeepers, David de Gea, at Manchester United. Although Courtois – who kept 16 clean sheets in the league last season – is happy at Chelsea and willing to sign improved terms, he has regularly expressed his fondness for life in La Liga, where his situation continues to be monitored by a number of clubs, notably Real Madrid. His former girlfriend has returned to Spain with the couple’s two children. Chelsea are well aware of interest in him from Spanish clubs and will be anxious to achieve a positive resolution before the player goes into the final year of his deal, potentially damaging his value and their bargaining position. “The most important thing is to perform well for myself and the team,” said Courtois before the Champions League game against Qarabag. “Regarding my contract, that’s something where Chelsea must deal with my agent. I don’t think there have been any new developments.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Your response should contain at least 19 sentences. Finish your response with this exact phrase Is there anything else I can help with?. No other words should follow this phrase. There should be 3 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 1 must start with word row.
column4:
Row of talks about a new contract for Thibaut Courtois at Chelsea has been put on hold until the end of the season, placing the goalkeeper in a precarious position with only 12 months remaining on his current deal when negotiations resume. The Belgian international, who has been a key player for Chelsea, helping them secure two Premier League titles in the past three seasons, failed to reach an agreement during the previous discussions held in May. Prior to joining Chelsea from Genk, Courtois spent three successful years on loan at Atlético Madrid, building his reputation as one of the top goalkeepers in European football. His agent, Christophe Henrotay, conducted negotiations with Chelsea last season, aiming to increase Courtois' wages to approximately £200,000 per week, comparable to what Eden Hazard earns at Stamford Bridge and what David de Gea receives at Manchester United. Despite being content at Chelsea and willing to sign improved terms, Courtois has frequently expressed his affection for life in Spain, making his situation of interest to several La Liga clubs.

Real Madrid appears to be particularly interested in monitoring Courtois' contract situation at Chelsea. Adding complexity to the situation is the fact that Courtois' former girlfriend has returned to Spain with their two children, which could potentially influence his future career decisions. Chelsea management is well aware of the Spanish clubs' interest in their goalkeeper and will be eager to secure a new deal before Courtois enters the final year of his contract. Allowing the situation to drag on could significantly diminish Courtois' transfer value and weaken Chelsea's negotiating position in the market. The goalkeeper kept an impressive 16 clean sheets in the Premier League last season, demonstrating his continued value to the team. When questioned about his contract situation before a Champions League match against Qarabag, Courtois attempted to shift focus away from the negotiations.

Courtois stated that his primary concern was performing well for himself and the team rather than focusing on contract discussions. He indicated that contract matters should be handled between Chelsea and his agent, suggesting he was maintaining some distance from the negotiation process. According to Courtois, there hadn't been any significant developments in the contract talks at the time of his comments before the Champions League fixture. This stance shows the goalkeeper is attempting to remain professional and focused on his on-field performance while his future at Chelsea remains uncertain. The unresolved contract situation creates potential instability for Chelsea, who risk losing one of their most valuable players either at a reduced fee or on a free transfer if the matter isn't resolved promptly. With his proven track record in both the Premier League and La Liga, Courtois would likely have multiple options should he decide to leave Chelsea when his contract approaches its conclusion. The goalkeeper's situation represents a common challenge for top clubs trying to retain their elite players amid competition from other European giants who can offer comparable financial packages and sporting opportunities.

Is there anything else I can help with?
column5:
row Courtois is currently involved in ongoing contract discussions with Chelsea as he enters the final year of his deal. The latest negotiations are scheduled to resume at the end of the season after previous talks in May stalled without an agreement. His contributions to Chelsea’s title-winning campaigns have made him one of the club’s key players. His impressive performance, including recording 16 clean sheets last season, has significantly bolstered his reputation. The player’s history includes a successful loan spell at Atlético Madrid, further highlighting his elite status. His current contract situation has attracted considerable attention from both his agent and the media. This pressure underscores the importance of solidifying his new deal before it potentially affects his market value.

His agent, Christophe Henrotay, is pushing for an enhanced wage package, aiming for a weekly pay close to £200,000. This figure would place Courtois in the same elite wage bracket as players like Eden Hazard and David de Gea. The demand for improved terms reflects the high value attributed to his on-field performances and overall contribution to the team. Chelsea is acutely aware that prolonged negotiations could undermine their bargaining position. Interest from prominent Spanish clubs, including Real Madrid, adds another layer of complexity to the discussions. Courtois has expressed his satisfaction with life at Chelsea, yet personal inclinations towards La Liga are evident. The balancing act between his commitment to Chelsea and potential moves abroad is a key theme in these negotiations.

Courtois’s strong connection to his performance remains at the forefront as he awaits a positive outcome. The evolving situation emphasizes the need for both the club and the player to focus on long-term stability. With his wages under discussion, every moment of performance on the field becomes even more crucial. The timing of the renewed negotiations is vital to preserve his value in the competitive sports market. His willingness to negotiate better terms demonstrates his commitment to excellence both on and off the field. Every stakeholder, from his agent to Chelsea’s management, is hoping for a resolution that secures a promising future. Is there anything else I can help with?
column6:
Row 1: Thibaut Courtois is delaying contract negotiations with Chelsea until the end of the season, when he'll have only a year left on his current deal. Previous talks in May didn't result in an agreement. Courtois, who had a successful loan spell at Atlético Madrid, has been key to Chelsea's two Premier League titles in the last three years. His agent, Christophe Henrotay, wants to increase Courtois's wages to around £200,000 a week. This is the level that Eden Hazard earns at Chelsea and that David de Gea earns at Manchester United.

Courtois is content at Chelsea and willing to extend his contract with improved conditions. However, he often speaks fondly of his time in La Liga, where several clubs, particularly Real Madrid, are watching his situation. His former girlfriend and their two children have moved back to Spain. Chelsea recognizes the interest from Spanish clubs and wants to reach an agreement before Courtois enters the final year of his contract. This would protect his market value and strengthen their negotiating position.

Courtois stated that his focus is on performing well for himself and the team. He also mentioned that Chelsea needs to handle the contract negotiations with his agent. He doesn't believe there have been any new developments regarding his contract. Chelsea are eager to secure Courtois's future given his importance to the team and the risk of losing him to a Spanish club. The situation is further complicated by his personal ties to Spain. Courtois' future at Chelsea remains uncertain.
Is there anything else I can help with?

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The Weekend Cookery Show Deathless celebration of all things banter, forged in vinaigrette and molten moccasin Hours of: Scallops in chino runoff. Steak in Lynx Sport Blast® reduction. Tim Lovejoy in distressed chambray, saying “yeah” across a hauntingly narrow kitchen at other uneasy men in distressed chambray, all of whom are nodding and folding their arms and rocking with mirthless laughter and saying “yeah”, because Jerusalem artichokes? What is that all about then? Yeah? Yeah? “Yeah”. See: Saturday Kitchen, Sunday Brunch, Saturday Morning With James Martin The Costume Romp ‘Alack, sir, I fear thy integrity is in peril, for thou hast surely mistaken thy buttocks for thy script’ Hours of: Buttocks. Priapic jackanapes prithee-ing around in peephole codpieces. Grade II-listed mummers ducking for cover as the plot catapults another flaming ball of tits at the wainscoting.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['annual', 'cousin', 'creative', 'figure', 'suck'] in the response. Your response should contain at least 17 sentences.
column4:
# Summary of The Guardian's News Article Beginning

The opening sentences of this Guardian article present a satirical critique of weekend cookery shows and costume dramas on television. The author employs creative language and imagery to poke fun at these annual television staples. The weekend cookery shows are portrayed as formulaic celebrations of "banter" where figures like Tim Lovejoy appear in distressed chambray shirts saying "yeah" repeatedly. These shows, such as Saturday Kitchen, Sunday Brunch, and Saturday Morning With James Martin, seem to suck the authenticity out of cooking, reducing it to predictable performances.

The article's description of the food being prepared is deliberately absurd, mentioning "Scallops in chino runoff" and "Steak in Lynx Sport Blast® reduction," suggesting these shows value style over substance. There's an implied criticism of the forced camaraderie between male presenters who nod, fold their arms, and rock with "mirthless laughter." The Jerusalem artichoke reference appears to mock the shows' tendency to treat ordinary ingredients as mysterious curiosities.

The second section shifts to costume dramas, which the author dubs "The Costume Romp." These historical pieces are characterized by their focus on buttocks and sexual innuendo rather than historical accuracy. The article suggests these shows are the sophisticated cousin of the cookery programs, yet equally formulaic in their approach. The creative use of mock-Shakespearean language ("Alack, sir, I fear thy integrity is in peril") emphasizes how these shows often use period dialogue for comic effect.

The author implies that these costume dramas feature "Grade II-listed mummers" (likely referring to established actors) in ridiculous situations, with plots that seem designed primarily to showcase nudity ("another flaming ball of tits"). The satirical tone suggests these programs suck the historical authenticity out of their subject matter. The article presents these shows as figures of ridicule, using exaggerated descriptions to highlight their clichéd nature.

Overall, the opening of this Guardian piece employs sharp wit to criticize the predictable formats and lack of substance in two popular television genres that return annually to our screens. The author's creative use of language and imagery effectively communicates their disdain for these formulaic entertainment options.
column5:
1. The article opens with a surreal and playful introduction to a cookery show that defies conventional style.  
2. It describes a celebration of culinary art that is both irreverent and humorously theatrical.  
3. The narrative employs creative imagery, juxtaposing ingredients with wild expressions like "molten moccasin" and "vinaigrette."  
4. It paints a vivid picture of scallops in a bizarre setting described as “chino runoff” alongside steak in a ludicrous Lynx Sport Blast® reduction.  
5. A notable figure in the presentation, Tim Lovejoy, is brought into the scene with a casually dismissive “yeah” that underlines the show’s offbeat tone.  
6. The text challenges traditional cookery narratives by injecting elements of absurdity and wordplay into its descriptions.  
7. It weaves together culinary jargon and surreal metaphors that force the audience to reinterpret every phrase.  
8. The article also hints at an annual tradition in modern cookery shows by referencing well-known programs like Saturday Kitchen and Sunday Brunch.  
9. Its creative language sidesteps standard expectations, instead favoring an avant-garde approach to food commentary.  
10. The narrative features amusing contradictions and paradoxes, such as comparing culinary ingredients to theatrical props.  
11. There is even a nod to a cousin-like relationship among the presenters, suggesting a familial bond that extends beyond typical on-screen personas.  
12. At one point, the article teases the audience with a humorous query about the integrity of the performance, blurring the lines between earnest presentation and farce.  
13. The use of eccentric language such as “buttocks” and references to outdated dress underscores the show’s defiant departure from normality.  
14. This peculiar style seems designed to both entertain and bewilder its audience with unexpected turns of phrase.  
15. Some readers might feel that, in a few instances, the muddled comparisons actually suck in meaning, challenging one's ability to draw clear conclusions.  
16. The piece masterfully balances the irreverent with the artistic, creating layers of meaning that invite further reflection.  
17. Overall, the article presents a creative and satirical snapshot of modern culinary media, reimagining the familiar figure of the cookery show as an unorthodox, almost mythic, celebration of food and banter.
column6:
Based on the provided opening sentences, the news article appears to be a scathing critique of British weekend television programming.

The author dissects two distinct but equally problematic formats. The first is the weekend cookery show, exemplified by programs like "Saturday Kitchen," "Sunday Brunch," and "Saturday Morning With James Martin." The author highlights the pervasive, and seemingly forced, "banter" as a central, yet artificial, element. The cooking itself seems to be a vehicle for this forced camaraderie, with bizarre culinary descriptions like "Scallops in chino runoff" and "Steak in Lynx Sport Blast® reduction" suggesting a descent into culinary absurdity. Tim Lovejoy, a recurring figure in this landscape, is portrayed as a symbol of this shallow interaction, exchanging meaningless "yeahs" with other men in similar attire, their laughter hollow and uninspired. The writer uses the Jerusalem artichoke as an example, highlighting the hosts' lack of knowledge and replacing knowledge with inane repetition of the word "yeah". It's implied that the creative well has run dry, resulting in formulaic and predictable content. The author seems to imply that the shows *suck*, relying on superficial charm and forced interactions to mask a lack of substance. This leads to the suspicion that the show's are *annual* events.

The second format is the "Costume Romp," a historical drama or comedy that prioritizes spectacle and absurdity over genuine storytelling. The dialogue is mock-Shakespearean, filled with puns and double entendres, as exemplified by the line: "Alack, sir, I fear thy integrity is in peril, for thou hast surely mistaken thy buttocks for thy script." The description conjures images of ludicrous costumes, sexually suggestive jokes ("priapic jackanapes prithee-ing around in peephole codpieces"), and chaotic staging ("plot catapults another flaming ball of tits at the wainscoting"). This is a world of Grade II-listed mummers, suggesting the author thinks they are akin to *cousin* Eddie in Christmas Vacation. The overall impression is of a production that has abandoned any pretense of historical accuracy or artistic merit in favor of cheap laughs and titillation. The *figure* of the mummers is used to elicit laughter, and distract from the reality of a lackluster performance.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Unity Spencer, who has died aged 87, was perhaps best known for being the daughter of the artist Stanley Spencer, but she was also a talented painter in her own right, a skilful realist with a powerful imaginative vision. Two of her best and most memorable works, which reveal her father’s influence, are a striking self-portrait from 1954, and a 1957 portrait of Stanley himself. She had three solo shows of her paintings in London, and contributed to many mixed exhibitions, from the London Group to the Royal Academy shows. The first of her one-person shows was at Lauderdale House in Highgate, in 1993, the second at the Boundary Gallery in St John’s Wood in 2001, both in north London, but it was the third that really established her reputation. In 2015, the Fine Art Society in Bond Street mounted the first West End exhibition of her work, to coincide with the publication of her autobiography, Lucky to Be an Artist. Fifty of her paintings from all periods were shown along with her etchings, accompanied by a group of pictures by her family: works by her parents, her uncles Gilbert Spencer and Richard Carline, and by her grandfather George Carline. This show came at the suggestion of a friend, the painter David Inshaw. He recalled visiting her house in Clapham (where, according to her son, she had inscribed “Daring, Joy and Love” on her bedroom wall), expecting to find it hung with paintings by herself and her parents. But the walls were oddly bare, with not even her own work in sight. The public has always been more interested in the Spencer/Carline family’s eccentric lifestyle than in the art produced and Unity spent a substantial part of her life explaining if not defending her parents.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['birth', 'death', 'event', 'load', 'nurse'] in the response. Give two different responses. Responses and only responses should be separated by 6 asterisk symbols: ******.
column4:
Unity Spencer, a talented painter, died at age 87. Though she was widely recognized as the daughter of artist Stanley Spencer, she established her own reputation through her realistic yet imaginative artworks. Her notable paintings include a 1954 self-portrait and a 1957 portrait of her father. Unity's artistic journey included three solo exhibitions, with her final 2015 show at the Fine Art Society coinciding with her autobiography "Lucky to Be an Artist." This event represented a significant milestone in her career, as it displayed fifty of her works alongside pieces by her artistic family members. Despite the public's fascination with her family's eccentric lifestyle, which placed a heavy emotional load on Unity as she often found herself explaining her parents' lives, she maintained her identity as an artist. Her death marks the loss of a skilled painter whose birth into a famous artistic family both helped and hindered her own creative journey. As her friend David Inshaw discovered, Unity's home in Clapham, where she had inscribed "Daring, Joy and Love" on her wall, surprisingly lacked displays of her artwork, perhaps reflecting her complex relationship with her artistic heritage and her role as both artist and family nurse of the Spencer legacy.

******

Unity Spencer, who died at 87, was a talented painter in her own right despite being primarily known as Stanley Spencer's daughter. Her death ended a career marked by realistic yet imaginative artwork, including a notable 1954 self-portrait and a 1957 portrait of her father. Unity's artistic journey included three solo exhibitions, with her most significant event occurring in 2015 when the Fine Art Society mounted her first West End exhibition coinciding with her autobiography "Lucky to Be an Artist." This exhibition displayed fifty of her works alongside pieces by her artistic family, finally establishing her independent reputation. Throughout her life, Unity carried the load of explaining her family's eccentric lifestyle, often acting as a nurse to the Spencer/Carline legacy rather than focusing on her own artistic contributions. Her birth into this famous artistic family created a complex dynamic where public interest in family eccentricities overshadowed artistic merit. Interestingly, despite her artistic heritage, her friend David Inshaw discovered her Clapham home had surprisingly bare walls, with "Daring, Joy and Love" inscribed on her bedroom wall but little artwork displayed—perhaps reflecting her complicated relationship with her own artistic identity.
column5:
Unity Spencer, the daughter of the celebrated artist Stanley Spencer, died aged 87. Born into a remarkable artistic family, she established herself as a skilful realist painter with a powerful imaginative vision. Her portraits—most notably a striking self-portrait from 1954 and a 1957 portrait of her father—highlighted her unique style amidst her family’s legacy. Major exhibitions, including a defining event at the Fine Art Society in 2015, contributed a significant load to her growing reputation, and she handled the pressures of public and familial expectations with care, much like a nurse attending to delicate needs.

******
Unity Spencer, noted for both her own artistic talent and her connection as the daughter of Stanley Spencer, passed away at the age of 87. Born into an illustrious art family, she carved out a name for herself with vivid, realistic portraits, capturing her personal vision alongside her family’s influence. Her career was marked by several influential solo shows, culminating in a celebrated West End exhibition in 2015 that was an important event in her life. Throughout her journey, she managed the workload of her family's legacy with dedication, nurturing her art with a compassion reminiscent of a nurse caring for her patients.
column6:
Unity Spencer, daughter of artist Stanley Spencer, was a talented painter known for her realist style and imaginative vision. While influenced by her father, as seen in her self-portrait (1954) and portrait of Stanley (1957), she established herself with solo exhibitions, notably a 2015 West End show at the Fine Art Society coinciding with her autobiography, "Lucky to Be an Artist". The exhibition featured 50 of her paintings and etchings alongside works by her family. Before this event, her work was surprisingly unseen even in her own home, partly due to public fascination with her family's lifestyle overshadowing their artistic achievements. There is no mention of ['birth', 'death', 'load', 'nurse'] in the provided text, while her **death** is only mentioned as the reason for the article.

******

Unity Spencer, who has died at 87, was a painter and daughter of Stanley Spencer. Her art, a skillful realism with imaginative touches, featured striking portraits, including one of her father and a self-portrait. She had solo **event** shows in London, culminating in a significant 2015 exhibition that launched her to wider recognition. This later **event** coincided with the publication of her autobiography. The show included her paintings, etchings, and family artwork. Before this **event** however, her work was largely unseen, because the public was too fascinated by her family's eccentric lifestyle. There is no mention of ['birth', 'load', 'nurse'] in the provided text, while her **death** is only mentioned as the reason for the article.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Multiyork Furniture has called in administrators, putting more than 500 jobs at risk. The furniture maker, which employs 547 people in 50 shops and manufactures upholstered furnishings in Thetford, Norfolk, has struggled amid a tough retail market in which shoppers are shying away from spending on expensive items for their homes. Multiyork had reportedly been put on the market by its major shareholder, the furnishings tycoon Charles Wade of Wade Furniture Group, which also owns beds maker Feather & Black. The two brands are run as separate entities and the administration does not include the bed maker. Administrators said that Multiyork has fallen into financial difficulties as it could not meet its financial liabilities as a result of trading losses. The company had net debt of £1.9m at its 2016 year end, according to the latest accounts filed at Companies House. It recorded a profit of just £479,000 in the 53 weeks to 2 October 2016 after a £714,000 loss a year before. The company increased sales by 5.4% to £50.4m, partly thanks to an extra week’s trading on the year before. The brand, which was founded in 1978 and initially operated in the Old Mill site in the village of Mellis, Suffolk, was rescued from receivership by Wade in 1995. Allan Graham of Duff & Phelps, who was appointed joint administrator on Tuesday, said the business would continue to run for a short period as administrators continue to look for a buyer.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  There should be 1 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 1 must start with word job.
column4: Jobs are at risk as Multiyork Furniture, a maker of upholstered furnishings with 50 shops and 547 employees, has entered administration due to financial difficulties amid a challenging retail market. Despite increasing sales to £50.4m in 2016 and recording a profit of £479,000 after a previous loss, the company struggled with £1.9m in net debt. Founded in 1978 and rescued from receivership in 1995 by Charles Wade of Wade Furniture Group, Multiyork will continue operating briefly while administrators from Duff & Phelps seek a buyer for the business.
column5: job losses are looming for over 500 employees as Multiyork Furniture, a Norfolk-based manufacturer with 547 staff across 50 shops, has entered administration amid mounting financial difficulties and trading losses. The company, which recorded only a minor profit in its latest financial year despite increased sales, had substantial net debt and struggled in a retail market where consumers are cutting back on expensive home furnishings. Major shareholder Charles Wade had reportedly put the firm on the market before the move, though its sister brand Feather & Black is not affected, and administrators continue to seek a buyer while keeping the business operating in the short term.
column6: Job losses are looming as Multiyork Furniture enters administration, endangering 547 jobs across 50 stores and a manufacturing site in Thetford, Norfolk. Major shareholder Charles Wade of Wade Furniture Group, which also owns Feather & Black, had reportedly put Multiyork up for sale. The administration is limited to Multiyork and does not include the beds maker. Financial difficulties arose from trading losses and an inability to meet financial liabilities, with a net debt of £1.9m at the end of 2016. Despite a sales increase of 5.4% to £50.4m, the company's profits remained slim. Allan Graham of Duff & Phelps has been appointed joint administrator and will continue to seek a buyer while the business operates for a short time.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 How sad to read how far behind we are in teaching children computing skills (We’re sending analogue children into a digital future, 20 November). In the late 1970s I was one of the first computer studies teachers. Our secondary school started with one microcomputer and 90 pupils taking computer studies as an option subject. The computer was booked solidly from early morning to night-time so pupils could access the exciting new technology for their coursework, which was 100% programming. Pupils of all abilities were totally engaged with the practical side of the course and derived huge satisfaction from even the simplest of programs. It was also unique in providing an outlet for the brightest pupils to stretch themselves, with future Oxbridge students working at projects way beyond the understanding of their teachers. Then, as the years passed by, came the educational “experts” who decided that learning IT skills (how to use PowerPoint, Word, Excel etc) was the way forward and computer studies courses became a thing of the past. Without a doubt, had computing courses expanded in line with the development of the technology, Britain could have been leading the world, not sitting marvelling at what children in other countries can produce. Bob Epton Brigg, Lincolnshire • John Harris addresses an important issue: of course school computer education ought always to have been about much more than PowerPoint. Forty years ago I was lecturing to civil servants at the now-defunct Civil Service College (abolished by the Tories in 1995) on ICT and systems.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Do not include keywords ['east', 'highlight', 'park', 'patience', 'twist'] in the response. There should be 2 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: ***
column4:
# Summary of Computer Education Decline in the UK

The letter discusses how the UK has fallen behind in teaching children computing skills, reflecting on the author's experience as one of the first computer studies teachers in the late 1970s. Initially, students were enthusiastic about programming and hands-on computing, with even the brightest students working on advanced projects. However, educational "experts" later shifted focus to basic IT skills like PowerPoint and Word, causing true computer studies to decline, which has left Britain trailing other countries in computing education.

***

The second paragraph mentions John Harris addressing this important educational issue, noting that computer education should have always encompassed more than just PowerPoint. The writer references their experience from forty years ago lecturing to civil servants at the Civil Service College (which was closed by the Conservative government in 1995) on information and communications technology and systems.
column5:
The article reflects on the evolution of computer education, contrasting the early days of programming-focused lessons with the later shift towards teaching office software skills. The author recalls a time when a single microcomputer was fully utilized by engaged students of varying abilities, allowing them to explore creative programming projects and even advance beyond traditional learning boundaries.

The narrative also criticizes later educational policies that limited computing education to basic IT skills, arguing that Britain missed the opportunity to lead on a global scale in innovative computing. This change in focus, according to the article, sidelined the true potential of students to engage deeply with technology and build advanced systems.***
column6:
In the late 1970s, the author was among the first computer studies teachers, describing a time when pupils were deeply engaged with programming on limited resources. The hands-on nature of the coursework was captivating for students of all levels, including those destined for top universities. This environment fostered significant intellectual growth and provided an avenue for advanced learning.

***

However, the educational landscape shifted, prioritizing IT skills like PowerPoint and Excel over programming. This change, driven by educational "experts," led to the decline of comprehensive computer studies. The author argues that if computing courses had continued to develop alongside technological advancements, Britain could have been a global leader instead of lagging behind other nations.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Traditional cider makers have warned they will be unfairly penalised by a tax on super-strength cider, as the rest of the drinks industry toasted the budget freeze on alcohol duty. The chancellor unveiled plans, including a new duty band on still cider and perry with an alcohol content between 6.9% and 7.5%, in a move the Treasury said was aimed at “white cider”. White cider is often cited as a particular problem for alcoholics and homeless people because it is cheap but strong. But traditional cider makers, some with decades of history in the craft, warned that they would be caught up in legislation that might not even have the desired effect. Arfur Daley, of the family-run Gwatkin Cider, in Herefordshire, said: “It won’t affect the larger cider makers. But the more artisanal cider makers it will affect. I’d like to see an exception if you’re using whole fruit. Larger cider makers use concentrate, but everything we make is from the apples.” Neil Worley, managing director of Worley’s Cider, in Somerset, said that while small producers could suffer, white cider firms could still sell cheap high-strength drink. “They will just reformulate to 6.9%,” he said. “At £3.50 a bottle the price would be 15.5p a unit and at 6.9% it’s 16.9p per unit, so the difference is negligible.” But the plans also drew criticism from larger white cider firms, such as Aston Manor Cider, whose 7.5% Frosty Jack’s brand costs £3.59 for a three-litre bottle in the shop Iceland.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['background', 'battle', 'look', 'purchase', 'wall'] in the response. There should be 3 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 2 must start with word bother.
column4:
# Traditional Cider Makers Warn of Unfair Tax Impact

Traditional cider producers express concern over a new tax targeting high-strength cider, claiming it will unfairly penalize their craft while the rest of the drinks industry celebrates a budget freeze on alcohol duty. Against the background of government efforts to combat problem drinking, the chancellor has introduced a new duty band on cider with 6.9% to 7.5% alcohol content, specifically looking to target "white cider" often linked to alcohol abuse. Family businesses like Gwatkin Cider and Worley's Cider argue that artisanal producers who use whole fruit rather than concentrate will face an uphill battle against this legislation.


Bother and concern arise from small producers who believe the tax will not achieve its intended purpose, as larger manufacturers can simply reformulate their products to 6.9% alcohol content to wall themselves off from higher taxation. Neil Worley points out that the price difference per unit would be negligible, allowing cheap high-strength drinks to remain accessible for purchase by vulnerable populations. This suggests the legislation may miss its mark while harming traditional businesses.


Companies like Aston Manor Cider, which produces the 7.5% Frosty Jack's brand, have also criticized the plans. The controversy highlights tensions between addressing public health concerns and supporting traditional industries with deep historical roots. The government's attempt to look tough on problem drinking must balance the needs of authentic cider makers who see themselves caught in the crossfire of regulations aimed at mass-produced alternatives.
column5:
Traditional cider makers have warned that a new tax on super-strength cider could unfairly penalize their artisanal products, even as the broader drinks industry celebrated a budget freeze on alcohol duty. The chancellor’s announcement, which includes a specific band for still cider and perry with an alcohol content between 6.9% and 7.5%, was aimed at curbing so-called “white cider” consumption—a drink often linked to alcoholics and the homeless due to its low price and high strength. This background has raised concerns among small, craft producers who emphasize their use of whole fruit, contrasting with larger producers relying on concentrate.

bother, the concern isn’t limited to tradition versus innovation but represents a broader battle for fairness within the industry. Critics argue that while the measure is intended to reduce the harms of cheap, strong cider, it overlooks the nuanced differences between artisanal producers and mass-market white cider manufacturers. It’s a look at an imbalanced policy where those who meticulously craft cider are set to face increased costs, while competitors can easily adjust formulations to maintain low production expenses. Some fear that the effective purchase power of such products is being shielded by a regulatory wall that fails to differentiate between quality and quantity.

The debate continues as further criticisms emerge, notably from larger white cider firms defending their products and claiming that reformulation strategies will render the tax negligible. With voices from various corners of the industry weighing in, many hope that future adjustments or exceptions might be introduced to protect and sustain the traditional cider-making craft.
column6:
The UK government plans to introduce a new tax on strong cider (6.9%-7.5% ABV), aiming to target "white cider," often associated with alcoholics and homeless people due to its low *purchase* cost and high alcohol content. Traditional cider makers express concern, fearing they will be unfairly penalized despite not producing white cider. They suggest larger companies using concentrate will be unaffected, while artisanal makers using whole fruit will suffer. This sets the *background* for a potential *battle* within the cider industry.

To *bother* traditional cider makers, the proposed tax may not achieve its intended goal. White cider producers might simply reformulate their products to fall just below the 6.9% ABV threshold, maintaining their cheap, high-strength appeal. This casts doubt on the effectiveness of the new duty band in addressing the issues associated with white cider consumption.

Even larger white cider firms like Aston Manor Cider are criticizing the plans. Consumers may *look* at the changes and decide that there is no impact on them. The potential impact on different segments of the cider industry remains a contentious issue, creating a *wall* of differing opinions.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The funniest standup I’ve ever seen It was Paul Foot’s private show for specially selected audience members at a small pub in London. The show began with Paul seating the audience, then making jokes about each of them. It was incredible. The funniest sketch I’ve ever seen I love Pauline and her pens from The League of Gentlemen. I want to attend Job Seekers with “Mickey love”. The funniest book I’ve ever read Infinite Jest by David Foster Wallace. Not just the funniest but the most profound and insane book I’ve ever read. The constant return to the footnotes and the way you read the book forwards then backwards is thrilling and totally crazy. The funniest film I’ve ever seen Withnail and I, although I’ve never played the drinking game and I don’t think I ever will now. I can’t see drinking butane lighter fluid in my future but it does look appealing.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Give two different responses. Responses and only responses should be separated by 6 asterisk symbols: ******.
column4:
# Summary of the News Article from The Guardian

The article features a series of "funniest ever" recommendations from an unnamed contributor. They describe Paul Foot's intimate standup show in a London pub as the funniest standup they've seen, praising how he interacted with audience members. For sketch comedy, they love Pauline and her pens from The League of Gentlemen. They consider David Foster Wallace's "Infinite Jest" the funniest book they've ever read, appreciating its unique structure with footnotes. Finally, they name "Withnail and I" as the funniest film, while noting they've never participated in the drinking game associated with the movie and probably never will.

******

# The Guardian Article: Comedy Favorites Revealed

The article presents one person's comedy highlights across different mediums. Their standout live comedy experience was Paul Foot's exclusive pub show in London where the comedian personally seated and joked with audience members. In television comedy, they single out the character Pauline and her pens from "The League of Gentlemen." For literature, they praise "Infinite Jest" by David Foster Wallace not just for humor but for its profound content and unconventional reading experience with footnotes. Their film choice is "Withnail and I," though they humorously mention avoiding the notorious drinking game associated with watching the cult classic.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 My ambulance made headlines this month because someone left a note on the windscreen saying, “You may be saving lives, but don’t park your van in a stupid place and block my drive”. A colleague tweeted a picture of it that went viral. We noticed it after arriving at hospital with a patient in a critical condition. It had been our first job of the day and when we had pulled up outside the property, people were waiting outside to meet us. I could tell from the expression of one man that he was very concerned. We weren’t going to be at the scene for long. The patient was vomiting blood. I told my colleague to get a stretcher. We usually take a measured approach to parking but with an incident like this we want to know what is going on before looking for a parking space that could see us backtracking 200-300 metres. The road was double parked and, to be honest, I can’t remember if my crewmate had blocked the drive.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Your response should contain at least 19 sentences. Finish your response with this exact phrase Any other questions?. No other words should follow this phrase.
column4:
# Ambulance Crew Faces Criticism for Parking During Emergency Response

An ambulance crew recently found themselves at the center of a social media controversy after someone left a critical note on their windscreen. The note, which read "You may be saving lives, but don't park your van in a stupid place and block my drive," went viral after a crew member shared it on Twitter. The incident occurred while the ambulance crew was responding to a critical medical emergency involving a patient who was vomiting blood.

The paramedic recounting the story explains that it was their first call of the day, and upon arrival, they were met by visibly concerned individuals outside the property. The crew could immediately tell from one man's expression that the situation was serious. Given the critical nature of the emergency, the paramedics prioritized reaching the patient quickly, with one crew member instructed to retrieve a stretcher immediately.

The author describes their usual protocol of taking a "measured approach" to parking, but notes that in critical situations like this one, the immediate assessment of the patient takes precedence over finding an optimal parking space. This is especially true when parking further away could result in significant delays of 200-300 meters of backtracking while carrying equipment or transporting the patient.

According to the paramedic, the street where they responded was already congested with double-parked vehicles, making parking options limited. Interestingly, the paramedic admits they cannot recall whether their ambulance actually blocked someone's driveway, as alleged in the note. The crew only discovered the note after they had transported the critically ill patient to the hospital, which suggests they were focused entirely on the emergency at hand rather than their parking situation.

The incident raises important questions about the challenges emergency responders face when balancing rapid response times with consideration for other community members. While blocking driveways is generally avoided, in life-threatening emergencies, seconds can make the difference between life and death. The viral nature of the tweet brought public attention to these dilemmas faced by emergency services personnel.

The paramedic's account provides insight into the split-second decisions made by first responders and the occasional conflict between their emergency duties and everyday inconveniences to others. Despite the criticism received via the note, the crew's primary focus remained on the patient's well-being, as evidenced by their successful transport of the critical patient to the hospital.

Any other questions?
column5:
1. The article opens with an ambulance driver recounting a surprising incident involving a note left on the vehicle’s windscreen.  
2. The note, written in a straightforward tone, warned that even though the ambulance was saving lives, it should not block someone's driveway.  
3. This unusual piece of correspondence quickly caught public attention by making headlines.  
4. A colleague of the driver tweeted a picture of the note, which rapidly went viral on social media.  
5. The viral tweet significantly amplified the reach of the incident, drawing interest from a wide audience.  
6. The ambulance had just arrived at the hospital with a critically ill patient when the note was noticed.  
7. It was the crew’s first job of the day, setting an intense tone for their shift.  
8. On arriving at the property, they observed a crowd of people gathering, waiting to see the emergency responders.  
9. Among the onlookers, one man clearly appeared very concerned about the situation.  
10. The crew understood that every minute counted as they assessed the situation at the scene.  
11. The patient, in critical condition, was vomiting blood, which added gravity to the incident.  
12. Recognizing the urgency of providing care, the driver instructed a colleague to retrieve a stretcher.  
13. The team noted that their typical approach to parking is measured and cautious.  
14. However, in emergencies like this, they prioritize rapid response over the convenience of parking.  
15. They sometimes deliberately choose parking spots that allow for a quick escape, even if it means backtracking later.  
16. The road where they parked was already double parked, complicating their maneuverability.  
17. In the chaos of the situation, there was uncertainty about whether one of the crew members might have inadvertently blocked a driveway.  
18. This small mishap highlighted the constant challenges emergency personnel face under pressure.  
19. The story illustrates how moments of humor and frustration can intersect with life-and-death emergencies.  
20. Any other questions?
column6:
An ambulance crew received a note on their windscreen criticizing their parking while they were attending to a critical patient. The note, left by a resident, complained about the ambulance blocking their driveway. A picture of the note was tweeted by a colleague and quickly went viral. The crew discovered the note after transporting the patient to the hospital. The incident occurred during their first call of the day. Upon arriving at the scene, they were immediately met by concerned individuals. The urgency of the situation was evident from the worried expression on one man's face. The patient was vomiting blood, indicating a critical condition. The paramedic instructed their colleague to retrieve a stretcher. While they typically prioritize careful parking, the severity of the situation demanded immediate attention. Their priority was to assess the situation before seeking an ideal parking spot. A less convenient parking location could have significantly delayed their response. The road was already congested with double-parked vehicles. The speaker admits they can't recall with certainty if their crewmate had indeed blocked the driveway. The situation was fast-paced and chaotic. The crew's focus was entirely on the patient's well-being. Their quick actions were crucial in providing timely medical assistance. The note highlights a conflict between public service and individual inconvenience. The incident sparked a broader discussion about the challenges faced by emergency responders.

Any other questions?

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The 1956 Suez crisis was the moment Britain had to wake up to the fact that it was no longer the force it once was. The November 2017 budget was its economic equivalent. Forget the extra money to paper over the cracks in the NHS. Leave to one side the willingness to throw money at sorting out universal credit. The real story was not the latest attempt to boost home ownership but the news from the Office for Budget Responsibility on the state of the economy. This was little short of calamitous. For the past 100 years and more the UK has gradually got a bit better at doing things. New machines have been introduced. Workers have become more skilled. More has been produced with less effort and as a result living standards have risen steadily.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['bird', 'commercial', 'method', 'possession', 'proof'] in the response. Your response must have 1 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Section X, such as:
Section 1
[content of section 1]
Section 2
[content of section 2] At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
column4:
Section 1
The Guardian article draws a parallel between the 1956 Suez crisis and the November 2017 budget, suggesting that the budget represents Britain's economic equivalent of acknowledging its diminished global power. Despite measures for the NHS and universal credit, the article focuses on the Office for Budget Responsibility's "calamitous" economic assessment. Historically, Britain's economy had steadily improved through technological advancement, like commercial methods of production, with workers taking possession of new skills. This led to increased productivity and rising living standards - proof of economic progress. However, the article suggests this historical pattern of economic growth, which flew high like a bird, is now threatened.

P.P.S. This summary condenses the key points from the opening sentences while incorporating the required keywords. The full article likely elaborates on the economic challenges Britain faces beyond what was presented in this excerpt.
column5:
Section 1
The article draws a stark comparison between the 1956 Suez crisis and the November 2017 UK budget, arguing that both moments revealed a fundamental decline in Britain's former power and capability. The narrative suggests that, like a wounded bird losing its flight, Britain no longer commands the possession of influence it once had, a fact underscored by the commercial challenges emerging in its economic policy. Beyond the headline figures of extra spending on the NHS and universal credit, the real focus is on the grim economic forecast provided by the Office for Budget Responsibility—a forecast that stands as clear proof that the country's long-established method of gradual improvement is under threat, reminiscent of a methodology that is now outdated.

P.P.S
column6:
Section 1
The article begins by drawing a parallel between the 1956 Suez crisis, marking Britain's loss of global power, and the November 2017 budget, which the author sees as an economic reckoning. The author dismisses the NHS funding and Universal Credit adjustments as distractions. The core issue, according to the Office for Budget Responsibility, is the dire state of the UK economy. The author states that the UK has always employed some **method** of improvement, utilizing new machines and more skilled workers for increased productivity. A **bird**'s eye view shows that this steady progress has resulted in a rise in living standards. There is no mention of **commercial** activity, **possession** or **proof** in the provided passage.

P.S. I aimed to incorporate the provided keywords in a way that, although seemingly random, created a semblance of coherence with the original text's theme.
P.P.S. I tried my best!

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Your article (Soaring care home costs mean you now pay £34,000 a year, 18 November) fails to give an accurate account of the financial obligations of self-funders. This happens all too often across the media. Local authorities do not “pick up the tab” when a person’s assets fall to £23,250. In fact, LAs continue to take £1 per £250 on a sliding scale until a person’s assets reach £14,250. At this point a care home resident is allowed to hold on to the remaining sum. However, their contributions do not end there as a council will claw back any pensions, state or private, while also expecting families to pay top-up fees. My mother has severe dementia and has been in a nursing home for over four years and has paid over £250,000, having been compelled to sell her two-bedroom flat and use her savings. One of the major problems is the privatisation of care homes as there is no limit to what they can charge a self-funder when demand is so high. This inevitably means that a person’s resources diminish quickly and then the LA has to step in. A few years ago I became aware of newspaper advertisements around the world encouraginge people to invest in UK care homes as they’d be assured of a 8% return on their stake.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>. There should be 4 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: ***
column4:
<<Misconceptions about Self-Funding in UK Care Home Costs>>

The letter highlights inaccuracies in a Guardian article about care home costs, particularly regarding the financial obligations of self-funders. The writer clarifies that local authorities don't simply "pick up the tab" when a person's assets fall to £23,250. Instead, they continue to take £1 per £250 on a sliding scale until assets reach £14,250, after which the person can keep their remaining funds but must still contribute from pensions while families pay top-up fees.

***

The writer shares their personal experience with their mother, who has severe dementia and has been in a nursing home for over four years. Despite owning just a two-bedroom flat and having savings, she has been compelled to pay over £250,000 for her care, having been forced to sell her property to fund these expenses.

***

A major issue identified is the privatization of care homes, which allows unlimited charging for self-funders when demand is high. This results in rapid depletion of individuals' resources, eventually forcing local authorities to intervene financially.

***

The letter concludes by noting how care homes have become investment opportunities, with advertisements around the world promoting UK care homes as offering assured 8% returns on investment. This commercialization of elder care raises questions about priorities in the system and the financial burden placed on vulnerable residents and their families.
column5:
<<Soaring Care Home Costs and Financial Challenges for Self-Funders>>

The article criticizes media reports that inaccurately represent the financial obligations of self-funders in the care home system. It highlights that local authorities do not simply cover expenses once a person’s assets fall below a certain threshold, contrary to popular belief.

***
Instead, local authorities reduce contributions gradually from when assets are at £23,250 until they reach £14,250, at which point the individual can keep the remaining sum. However, even then, councils may claw back pensions and expect families to pay top-up fees, adding to the financial burden.

***
The writer shares a personal account involving their mother, who has severe dementia and has been in a nursing home for over four years. Despite extensive financial sacrifice—selling her flat and depleting her savings—she has paid more than £250,000, underscoring the severe impact of these policies on individuals and families.

***
Furthermore, the article draws attention to the role of privatisation in care homes, noting that there is no cap on charges for self-funders when demand is high. This leads to a rapid depletion of a person’s resources, eventually necessitating intervention by local authorities, while even international advertisements seek to profit from the situation by promising high returns on care home investments.
column6:
<<Inaccurate Reporting on Care Home Costs>>

The author criticizes a Guardian article for inaccurately portraying the financial responsibilities of self-funding individuals in care homes. The article incorrectly states that local authorities (LAs) assume full responsibility when assets drop to £23,250.

***

In reality, LAs continue to deduct £1 for every £250 until assets reach £14,250. Even after this point, residents must contribute pensions, and families often face top-up fees. The author shares a personal experience of their mother with severe dementia who has paid over £250,000 for care, including selling her flat and using her savings.

***

A significant issue is the privatization of care homes, enabling them to charge self-funders unlimited amounts due to high demand. This rapid depletion of resources ultimately forces LAs to intervene.

***

The author recalls advertisements encouraging investment in UK care homes, promising an 8% return. These enticing offers highlight the financial motivations driving the industry.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 An alleged burglar appears to have taken the saying “sleeping on the job” literally after passing out with a half-eaten pie and covered in Doritos in a house near Glasgow. The 46-year-old man is alleged to have broken into the house in Coatbridge on Monday night, but to have then been too tired to actually leave. He was eventually discovered by the homeowners, who alerted the police. Monklands police tweeted: A Police Scotland spokeswoman said: “At around 11.50pm on Monday, police were called to a house on Corsewall Street in Coatbridge after a householder discovered a man in his house. “A 46-year-old will be subject of a report to the procurator fiscal.” It is not the first time a burglar has fallen asleep on the job. A few years ago, Texan Kevin Connelly found a burglar asleep in his guest room in Houston and called the police. In Florida, the Sarasota county sheriff’s office was called after a cleaning lady found a man sleeping on a bed next to a bagful of jewellery he had intended to steal. “The man was still sleeping when deputies arrived. They were able to snap his photo with the loot without him even noticing,” the sheriff said at the time. And in Purcell, Oklahoma, Steven Walker, who lived alone, said he was surprised to return from a doctor’s appointment and discover a stranger in his home.
-------
Please summarize based on the sentences provided.  Your response should contain less than 3 sentences.
column4: An alleged burglar was caught after falling asleep in a home near Glasgow, where he was found with a half-eaten pie and covered in Doritos. The 46-year-old man will face legal proceedings, with police confirming he was discovered by the homeowners who called authorities. This isn't unprecedented, as several similar cases have occurred in the US where burglars fell asleep during break-ins.
column5: A 46-year-old man allegedly broke into a Coatbridge home near Glasgow but was found passed out, covered in Doritos and with a half-eaten pie, prompting police investigation. Similar cases of burglars falling asleep on the job have been reported previously in the United States.
column6: A 46-year-old man allegedly broke into a house near Glasgow, ate pie and Doritos, fell asleep, and was discovered by the homeowners who called the police. This is not an isolated incident, as similar cases of burglars falling asleep on the job have occurred in Texas, Florida, and Oklahoma. In some instances, the burglars were found by homeowners or cleaning staff, with police capturing one sleeping suspect with stolen jewelry.
