"Section 1
John Dwyer leans against the wall of a dimly lit San Francisco venue, guitar slung low over his shoulder. 'My motto is: try everything, life is short,' he says with a grin that suggests he's experienced more musical adventures than most. At 45, Dwyer has become something of a legend in the underground music scene—the restless mastermind behind Thee Oh Sees and a dizzying array of side projects spanning every conceivable genre. Tonight's show marks the 25th anniversary of Coachwhips' 'Bangers vs Fuckers,' the raw, 18-minute punk explosion that first put him on the map. The crowd is a mix of fresh-faced college kids and aging garage rock devotees who've followed his career through all its wild permutations.

Section 2
As the lights dim, Dwyer steps to the center of the stage, replacing a traditional microphone with his signature telephone transducer. The familiar buzz of anticipation fills the room. 'We're growing at every turn,' he shouts through the distorted mouthpiece, barely audible over the wall of guitar feedback. 'Every day you get a little older, a little closer to the grave—you should taste it all!' The drummer counts off, and suddenly the room erupts into chaotic sound. Watching him perform with the same frenetic energy he had decades earlier, it's clear that Dwyer has lived by his motto, tasting everything from industrial electronics to improvised jazz, creating a musical legacy as eclectic as it is prolific. Any other questions?"
column5:
"Section 1
In a sun-drenched San Francisco recording studio, John Dwyer wakes up with his usual philosophy reverberating through the city streets: 'Try everything, life is short.' Today, as the leader of the trailblazing garage rock band Thee Oh Sees, he gathers his eclectic ensemble amid scattered musical instruments and discarded pizza boxes. Their latest session crackles with energy and experimental spirit. Dwyer's eyes sparkle as he recounts his journey from the vibrant early 2000s punk scene to now, weaving in unorthodox elements like telephone transducers and even a reference to a legendary scene from the Scott Walker documentary, 30th Century Man.

Section 2
The soundscape transforms as rehearsals give way to live performances that challenge genre boundaries—ranging from industrial electronics and improvised jazz to electrifying death metal riffs. With over 21 critically acclaimed LPs and numerous side projects under his belt, Dwyer is known to risk all norms, transforming every beat of his music into a celebration of life. The band members, equally fearless in their creative exploration, blend simplicity with avant-garde bravado, proving that when passion meets innovation, every note counts. Any other questions?"
column6:
"Section 1
John Dwyer, the prolific force behind Thee Oh Sees and countless other projects, lives by the mantra: “Try everything, life is short.” This philosophy has fueled a career spanning garage rock, industrial electronics, improvised jazz, and even death metal. His relentless pursuit of new sounds is evident in his vast discography, a testament to his boundless creativity. He seeks to push the boundaries of music. Inspired by Scott Walker's experimental approach, as seen in the documentary '30th Century Man', Dwyer embraces unconventional techniques, incorporating everything from flutes to electronic bagpipes into his music.

Section 2
For those seeking an entry point into Dwyer's sprawling musical universe, Coachwhips' "Bangers vs Fuckers" is a prime example of his early, raw energy. This album encapsulates the band's chaotic and rambunctious live shows, delivering 11 tracks in a mere 18 minutes. The album is a reminder of Dwyer's innovative spirit, utilizing a telephone transducer instead of a traditional microphone. Coachwhips, with their stripped-down sound and aggressive performance style, offered a glimpse into the experimental approach to music which would become Dwyer's signature.

Any other questions?"

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Poland has been given two weeks to stop illegal deforestation in the Unesco-protected Białowieża forest or face fines of at least €100,000 a day. In a precedent-setting ruling that will echo across the EU, the European court of justice ordered Poland to show it was acting lawfully in the ancient woodland, or face a €36.5m (£32m) annual penalty. Agata Szafraniuk, a lawyer for the green law firm ClientEarth, said that the court was acting after Poland’s environment minister, Jan Szyszko, showed “complete contempt” for an earlier emergency ban on logging in the ancient woodland. “Financial penalties are, unfortunately, an essential tool to ensure that the best-preserved primeval forest in Europe is protected from further harm,” she said. “Trees are still being cut down every day, so the court prescribed this measure to guarantee the full protection of this unique forest, and to avoid irreparable damage.” The court move will ratchet up pressure on Poland, which is already facing a suspension of its EU Council voting rights over a clampdown on the country’s independent press and judiciary. Women’s groups have also been targeted for police raids, and rights to protest have been curtailed, adding to concerns about the rule of law in the east European country. Donald Tusk, the EU Council president, condemned Poland’s nationalist-right Law and Justice party government on Sunday, suggesting it was following the “Kremlin’s plan”. The Polish government maintains that it always behaves lawfully and that logging in Białowieża is necessary to staunch a spruce bark beetle outbreak. “In the western media, everything is based on disinformation,” a Polish government spokesman told the Guardian. “We are doing everything right by law.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Your response should contain less than 12 sentences. Do not include keywords ['court', 'cover', 'dream', 'hold', 'view'] in the response.
column4:
# The Battle for Białowieża

Poland faces a critical ultimatum from the European Union regarding illegal deforestation in the UNESCO-protected Białowieża forest. The country has been given just two weeks to halt logging activities or face substantial daily fines of at least €100,000. This ancient woodland, considered Europe's best-preserved primeval forest, continues to see trees felled despite previous emergency bans on logging. Environmental advocates like Agata Szafraniuk of ClientEarth express frustration that financial penalties have become necessary to protect this unique ecosystem from irreparable damage. The situation intensifies existing tensions between Poland and the EU, which has already raised concerns about the Polish government's restrictions on press freedom, judicial independence, and civil rights. Poland's Law and Justice party government, meanwhile, defends its actions as necessary to combat a spruce bark beetle infestation. A government spokesperson insisted they were "doing everything right by law," while dismissing western media reports as "disinformation." This environmental conflict represents just one facet of the broader political standoff between Poland's nationalist-right leadership and European institutions.
column5: Poland received a stern demand from a prominent European legal institution to stop destructive logging in the UNESCO-protected Białowieża forest, one of the continent’s natural treasures. If the nation does not act within two weeks, it risks daily fines exceeding €100,000 and an annual penalty of €36.5 million. An environmental lawyer from ClientEarth sharply criticized Poland’s environment minister, arguing that his actions ignored an earlier emergency measure aimed at protecting the ancient woodland. Advocates insist that imposing significant financial penalties is essential for preserving one of Europe’s most valuable primeval forests. The pressure on Poland comes amid broader concerns over the government’s treatment of independent media, judicial independence, and civil rights. Senior EU officials have openly condemned the nationalist government, suggesting it is influenced by forces beyond its borders. In response, Polish officials maintain that their actions are entirely legal and necessary to address a dangerous spruce bark beetle outbreak. Observers continue to debate the long-term repercussions this decision might have on environmental protection and the nation’s commitment to European standards.
column6: Poland faces escalating pressure to halt unauthorized tree felling in the Białowieża forest, a Unesco-designated site. The European judicial body has mandated a two-week cessation, threatening daily penalties exceeding €100,000. This landmark decision demands Poland demonstrate lawful conduct within the ancient woodland or incur a substantial annual fine. An environmental lawyer highlighted the “complete contempt” displayed by Poland’s environment minister for prior logging restrictions. She emphasized the necessity of financial measures to shield the forest from further devastation, as logging persists daily. This action intensifies scrutiny on Poland, already contending with potential EU Council voting suspension due to press and judicial constraints. Concerns regarding the rule of law are mounting amid actions targeting women's groups and protest rights. A Polish government representative refuted these claims, alleging western media propagates misinformation. They assert their actions align with legal requirements, aimed at controlling a spruce bark beetle infestation.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The UK, even today, is not well blessed with festivals devoted to new music. But when the Huddersfield contemporary music festival began, in 1978, the situation was much worse, with no annual showcase here for what living composers were producing. That such an event took root in an unprepossessing West Yorkshire industrial town in the late 70s was remarkable in itself, especially when most of the activity in new music then was centred on London. What began on a modest scale under the aegis of Huddersfield Polytechnic (now the University of Huddersfield) – where the festival’s tireless founding director, Richard Steinitz, was a lecturer in music – grew quickly into one of the most important dates in the British musical calendar. The HCMF really hit its stride in the early 80s, hosting a series of important premieres alongside residencies from many of the senior figures of postwar music, from Olivier Messiaen and Terry Riley to Hans Werner Henze and Elliott Carter. Gradually expanding its ambition and range, Steinitz’s programming was never narrowly doctrinal; from the early days, he tried to reflect the spectrum of what was going on across Europe and the US. Steinitz stood down as director after the 2000 festival. The current director, Graham McKenzie, has been there for more than a decade, not only steering the programming towards new generations of composers from across Europe, but also broadening the stylistic scope, including events that touch on jazz, electronica and rock. With these changes, so the atmosphere of the festival has altered. This is partly because the generation of postwar composers whose appearances made the early festivals so memorable has all but gone, but also because, in those days, festival audiences had a sense of a shared purpose.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['bunch', 'patience', 'storm', 'tap', 'team'] in the response. Finish your response with this exact phrase Is there anything else I can help with?. No other words should follow this phrase.
column4:
# The Evolution of the Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival

In the winter of 1978, as a storm battered the windows of Huddersfield Polytechnic, Richard Steinitz tapped his pen nervously against his desk. The birth of the Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival was at hand, though few could have predicted how this modest endeavor would transform the landscape of new music in the UK.

"It will take patience," Steinitz told his small team of organizers. "The UK isn't exactly overflowing with contemporary music festivals, particularly outside of London."

What began as a small bunch of concerts in an industrial West Yorkshire town quickly blossomed into something remarkable. By the early 1980s, the festival had found its rhythm, attracting legendary composers like Olivier Messiaen, Terry Riley, Hans Werner Henze, and Elliott Carter. These weren't just performances but cultural watersheds, with premieres that would be discussed in musical circles for decades to come.

Steinitz's vision was never constrained by rigid doctrine. Instead, he sought to capture the full spectrum of contemporary composition across Europe and America. His programming reflected both the avant-garde and the accessible, creating a festival with unique character and depth.

When Steinitz stepped down in 2000, the baton passed eventually to Graham McKenzie, who brought fresh perspectives while honoring the festival's legacy. Under his direction, the festival tapped into new currents in music, embracing elements of jazz, electronica, and even rock. The programming expanded to welcome younger composers from across Europe, ensuring the festival remained at the cutting edge.

Yet something subtle shifted in the festival's atmosphere during this transition. The shared sense of purpose that had united audiences in the early days began to disperse, partly because the pioneering postwar generation of composers had nearly all passed on. What remained, however, was a testament to how a small team with unwavering dedication could transform a "provincial" town into an internationally recognized center for musical innovation.

Today, the Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival stands as proof that artistic vision, when pursued with patience and conviction, can flourish even in the most unexpected places, weathering cultural storms and changing tastes while continuing to tap into the pulse of contemporary musical expression.

Is there anything else I can help with?
column5:
In the late 1970s, a spark of innovation ignited in an unassuming part of West Yorkshire. At Huddersfield Polytechnic, a visionary lecturer named Richard stepped forward with a mission: to champion the new and experimental voices of the musical world. With a passionate bunch of like-minded colleagues behind him, he set up an event that would challenge the established order of London's music scene. 

In those early days, the environment was one of both quiet excitement and waiting, where every piece performed was a tap into a future yet imagined. Despite the challenges—a true storm of skepticism from the traditionalists—the team persevered with remarkable patience. They understood that art, like any revolutionary idea, needed nurturing to bloom.

As the festival grew into a celebrated annual event, it became a meeting place for composers and audiences alike. There was a dynamic energy as the festival programming expanded to include everything from the austere new music of postwar maestros to spontaneous, improvisational ventures today. The current director, Graham McKenzie, builds on the legacy, inviting fresh voices and diversifying the performances, ensuring that the festival remains a vibrant platform for the exploration of sound across genres.

This story of musical evolution is not only about a growing programme but also about a community that came together as a team and transformed local industry into an internationally recognized stage of creativity—a testament to the power of vision, patience, and the strength found in a bunch of kindred spirits who dared to dream during a storm of change.

Is there anything else I can help with?
column6:
The Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival (HCMF), a surprising bloom in the unprepossessing landscape of 1978 West Yorkshire, felt like a secret shared by a small, dedicated bunch. Back then, new music had no real home in the UK. London was the center of everything, but Richard Steinitz, a lecturer at Huddersfield Polytechnic, had a vision and, more importantly, boundless patience.

The early days were humble, a storm of experimental sounds brewing in a small space. Each performance felt like a tentative tap on a door, a question posed to a mostly bewildered audience. Steinitz's HCMF steadily grew, hosting premieres from giants like Messiaen and Henze. It was a golden age.

After Steinitz retired, Graham McKenzie took the helm, broadening the festival's reach. He brought in a new team, younger composers from across Europe, events that touched on jazz and electronica. He sought to expand the experience of the festival, which was necessary, because the atmosphere, a shared purpose in new music, had all but vanished along with the older composers.

Is there anything else I can help with?

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Today’s best bets, by Chris Cook In among the heady speculation at Jessica Harrington’s yard about what Sizing John might do this season, there was a moment of realism yesterday. It came when the trainer stated her baseline ambition for the horse. “I’d like to get him back to the Gold Cup because the last two Gold Cup winners haven’t even got back. That’s Plan A, to get him there. Whatever happens after that will be a bonus.” Harrington is right about this. Neither Coneygree nor Don Cossack made it back to the Gold Cup the year after winning it. This is part of being a top-class staying chaser, in my view; in most cases, you only get a year at the top. Winning a race like that comes at a cost, which can be that the winner is either unwilling or incapable of a reprise. “My only worry,” Harrington continued, “is maybe the three hard races last year might leave a mark on him. But he’d had a good few hard races the year before and he seemed to come out of it very well.” Sizing John is only seven, rising eight, and he looked a picture yesterday.
-------

Section 1

column4:
# Sizing John's Journey to Redemption

Section 1
In the lush green pastures of Jessica Harrington's yard, a quiet optimism hung in the air. Sizing John, the magnificent Gold Cup champion, grazed peacefully, unaware of the weight of expectations surrounding him. Harrington watched her prized racehorse from a distance, her experienced eyes assessing his condition. Despite the excitement and speculation about his prospects for the upcoming season, she remained grounded in reality. "I'd like to get him back to the Gold Cup because the last two Gold Cup winners haven't even got back," she had told reporters yesterday, her voice carrying both hope and caution. "That's Plan A, to get him there. Whatever happens after that will be a bonus."

Section 2
The path of a Gold Cup winner was notoriously difficult. Coneygree and Don Cossack had both fallen short of returning to defend their titles. It was the harsh reality of being a top-class staying chaser – brilliance often came at a steep price. The punishing nature of such races could leave invisible scars, diminishing either the will or the capability to achieve such heights again. Harrington understood this better than most. "My only worry," she had confessed, "is maybe the three hard races last year might leave a mark on him." Yet there was reason for optimism too. "But he'd had a good few hard races the year before and he seemed to come out of it very well."

Section 3
At seven years old, rising eight, Sizing John was in his prime. Yesterday, he had looked magnificent – his coat gleaming, muscles rippling beneath his skin, eyes alert and intelligent. The stable staff adored him, and he had become something of a celebrity in racing circles. Photographers regularly visited the yard, hoping to capture the essence of this remarkable athlete. Sizing John seemed to enjoy the attention, posing regally as if aware of his status. But behind the glamour lay months of meticulous preparation, careful training, and the constant monitoring of his physical and mental condition.

Section 4
As the new season approached, the racing world watched with bated breath. Would Sizing John join the elite few who had successfully defended their Gold Cup title? Or would he follow the path of his predecessors, unable to recapture past glories? Harrington and her team worked tirelessly, balancing ambition with caution, pushing their champion while remaining vigilant for any signs of strain. For now, seeing him look "a picture" was encouragement enough. The journey ahead would be challenging, but with Harrington's expertise and Sizing John's natural talent, there was reason to believe in the possibility of making history. Only time would tell if this magnificent animal could defy the odds and return triumphantly to Cheltenham's hallowed turf.

Is there anything else I can help with?

column6:
Section 1

The crisp morning air hung heavy with anticipation at Jessica Harrington’s stables. Sizing John, the reigning Gold Cup champion, stood proudly, his coat gleaming under the weak winter sun. While whispers of another glorious season and potentially unprecedented achievements filled the air, Harrington grounded the excitement with a dose of pragmatism. "I'd like to get him back to the Gold Cup because the last two Gold Cup winners haven’t even got back. That’s Plan A, to get him there. Whatever happens after that will be a bonus.” Her words echoed a stark reality of steeplechase racing.

Section 2

Harrington's observation was not merely cautious optimism; it was a reflection of historical truth. Coneygree, the powerful 2015 victor, and Don Cossack, the subsequent champion, both failed to return to defend their crowns. The unforgiving nature of the Gold Cup, and the intense preparation required to reach that pinnacle, often extracts a heavy toll. As Chris Cook, the racing journalist, notes, conquering such a prestigious race frequently comes at a price, leaving the victor either unwilling or unable to replicate their feat.

Section 3

The concern, subtly etched on Harrington’s face, was about the cumulative effect of Sizing John’s grueling campaign the previous year. "My only worry,” Harrington continued, “is maybe the three hard races last year might leave a mark on him. But he’d had a good few hard races the year before and he seemed to come out of it very well.” Had the relentless demands of those races, the thunderous gallops and the perilous leaps, left an indelible mark on the champion? Would the physical and mental strain ultimately prove too much to overcome?

Section 4

Despite the underlying apprehension, there was also reason for hope. Sizing John was still young for a staying chaser, only seven and approaching eight. He possessed the raw power, the innate talent, and the unwavering spirit necessary to defy the odds. As he was paraded before the assembled onlookers, he radiated health and vitality. He looked a picture, a testament to Harrington’s expert care and the horse’s own resilient constitution. The path to the Gold Cup would be arduous, fraught with challenges, but Sizing John appeared ready to face them.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Concordia International, the Canadian drug company, has overcharged the NHS by more than £100m in the past decade for a life-changing thyroid drug, according to Britain’s competition watchdog. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said it had provisionally found that Concordia had “abused its dominant position to overcharge the NHS” by hiking the price of liothyronine, used to treat patients with an underactive thyroid, by nearly 6,000% between 2007 and 2017. The regulator said the NHS had spent more than £34m on the drug last year, up from about £600,000 in 2006. The amount it paid per pack rose from £4.46 in 2007 to £258.19 by July 2017. The price of a single pill went up from 16p to £9.22, even though production costs remained broadly stable during that period, the CMA said. Concordia could be fined up to 10% of its worldwide annual turnover. Liothyronine tablets are used to treat hypothyroidism, a condition caused by a deficiency of the thyroid hormone that affects at least two in 100 people and can lead to depression, tiredness and weight gain. For many patients there is no alternative and, until this year, Concordia was the only supplier. This summer, the UK firm Morningside Healthcare and Israel’s Teva were granted licences to supply the drug. The medicine, a synthetic version of the hormone T3, is taken by patients who do not respond well to the cheaper alternative, levothyroxine.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. There should be 4 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 2 must start with word strategy.
column4:
"Concordia International, the Canadian drug company, has overcharged the NHS by more than £100m in the past decade for a life-changing thyroid drug, according to Britain's competition watchdog. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said it had provisionally found that Concordia had 'abused its dominant position to overcharge the NHS' by hiking the price of liothyronine, used to treat patients with an underactive thyroid, by nearly 6,000% between 2007 and 2017. This astronomical price increase meant that many patients with hypothyroidism, who relied on this medication to lead normal lives, were potentially facing barriers to treatment as the NHS struggled with ballooning costs for a medication that was once affordable.

Strategy experts at the CMA believe Concordia took advantage of being the sole supplier of liothyronine in the UK market, allowing them to raise prices unchecked for years. While production costs remained largely stable, the price of a single pill skyrocketed from just 16p to £9.22 - a markup that seemed designed to exploit the NHS's obligation to provide necessary medications to patients regardless of cost. The regulator noted that the NHS spent over £34 million on the drug in 2016, compared to just £600,000 a decade earlier, despite no significant changes to the medication itself.

The impact on patients has been profound, particularly for those with hypothyroidism who don't respond well to the cheaper alternative, levothyroxine. Hypothyroidism affects at least two in every 100 people in Britain and can cause debilitating symptoms including depression, chronic fatigue, and weight gain when untreated. For many patients, liothyronine is not simply an option but a necessity, making Concordia's price hikes especially problematic from a public health perspective. Patient advocacy groups have been vocal about their concerns, arguing that essential medications should not be treated as opportunities for excessive profit.

The landscape is finally changing, however, as this summer both Morningside Healthcare from the UK and Israel's Teva received licenses to supply liothyronine to the British market. This introduction of competition may help drive prices down, though the damage of a decade of overcharging has already been done. Concordia now faces potential fines of up to 10% of its worldwide annual turnover if the CMA's provisional findings are confirmed. The case highlights ongoing tensions between pharmaceutical profit motives and public healthcare needs, raising questions about how regulatory bodies can better protect healthcare systems from similar pricing abuses in the future."
column5:
"Concordia International, the Canadian drug company, has long been a key supplier of liothyronine, a synthetic thyroid hormone crucial for individuals with an underactive thyroid. For years, patients and the NHS alike trusted the steady supply and stable prices of this essential medication, unaware that beneath the surface, a dramatic price distortion was unfolding. The revelation that production costs had remained broadly stable while prices soared by nearly 6,000% sent shockwaves through the health community, marking the beginning of an intense regulatory probe.

Strategy drove the investigation as regulators at the Competition and Markets Authority began piecing together evidence of market abuse. They uncovered how the company gradually increased the drug’s per-pack price from £4.46 in 2007 to £258.19 by 2017, a move that left many questioning the fairness and ethics of such exponential hikes. This methodical approach aimed to not only penalize the wrongdoing but also to set a precedent that no supplier holds unchecked power over essential medicines—a strategy intended to safeguard patients' access to life-changing treatments.

The dramatic pricing shift had a profound impact on the NHS, which saw its expenditure on liothyronine climb from a modest sum in the early 2000s to over £34 million in one recent year. With hypothyroidism affecting at least two percent of the population, patients found themselves caught in a system where alternatives were scarce, and costs had spiraled uncontrollably. As competitors like Morningside Healthcare and Teva entered the market, the monopoly was finally challenged, offering hope that patient care might finally prevail over corporate profiteering.

In the aftermath of these revelations, the looming potential for a fine of up to 10% of Concordia’s worldwide annual turnover underscored the gravity of the situation. The scandal has not only brought to light significant questions regarding regulatory oversight and corporate accountability, but it has also ignited an urgent debate on how essential drugs should be priced and managed. Stakeholders from all corners—regulators, health professionals, and patient advocates—now stand at a crossroads, determined to reshape the landscape of pharmaceutical pricing for the better."
column6:
"Concordia International, a Canadian pharmaceutical company, faces severe scrutiny after allegedly overcharging the National Health Service (NHS) in Britain by over £100 million over the past decade for liothyronine, a crucial thyroid drug. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), Britain’s competition watchdog, has provisionally concluded that Concordia exploited its market dominance to impose exorbitant price hikes on the life-altering medication. Liothyronine is vital for patients suffering from an underactive thyroid, and the CMA reports a staggering nearly 6,000% increase in its price between 2007 and 2017.

Strategy employed by Concordia resulted in the NHS spending more than £34 million on liothyronine in the last year, a dramatic rise from approximately £600,000 in 2006. The cost per pack surged from £4.46 in 2007 to an astounding £258.19 by July 2017. The CMA highlighted the stark contrast between the soaring price of a single pill, jumping from 16p to £9.22, and the relatively stable production costs throughout the same period. The potential fine for Concordia could reach up to 10% of its global annual turnover, reflecting the seriousness of the alleged misconduct.

Liothyronine tablets are a lifeline for individuals with hypothyroidism, a condition caused by thyroid hormone deficiency impacting at least 2% of the population and causing debilitating symptoms like depression, fatigue, and weight gain. For many patients, there were no other options available, and Concordia held a monopoly as the sole supplier until recently. The entrance of UK-based Morningside Healthcare and Israel's Teva, who were granted licenses to supply the drug this summer, finally breaks Concordia's grasp on the market.

The drug itself is a synthetic version of the T3 hormone, specifically prescribed to patients who haven't responded well to levothyroxine, a cheaper alternative. The investigation raises serious questions about drug pricing practices and the potential exploitation of vulnerable patients who rely on life-sustaining medications. The CMA's findings, while provisional, underscore the need for robust oversight and accountability within the pharmaceutical industry to ensure fair pricing and access to essential treatments."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The Turnbull government has deployed new modelling on the national energy guarantee in an effort to step up pressure on state governments to sign up to its policy at a meeting of energy ministers on Friday. A summary of the modelling, circulated by the government in advance of the talks with the states, suggests household power bills between 2020 and 2030 would be “in the order of” $120 a year lower, in today’s dollars, than under a business-as-usual scenario, if the policy applied across the national electricity market. The material supplied by the government says wholesale electricity prices would be 23% lower than business-as-usual between 2020 and 2030, and it suggests the share of renewables in the market by 2030 “could range from 32% to 36%”. The full modelling, undertaken for the Energy Security Board by Frontier Economics, has not yet been distributed to state energy ministers and the documents circulated in Canberra are a summary of the findings, not the work itself. The Turnbull government announced in October it would dump the clean energy target recommended by the chief scientist, Alan Finkel, and proceed with the national energy guarantee – a policy that imposes new reliability and emissions reduction guarantees on energy retailers and large energy users from 2020. The policy requires cooperation from the states but some of the Labor governments, particularly South Australia, have been hostile. Part of the reason for that is the states were involved in the exhaustive consultations with Finkel about the clean energy target but were not kept in the loop about the national energy guarantee. Some state governments are also concerned the Turnbull policy will hard-bake coal into the system at the expense of renewables at a time when the energy market needs to transition to low-emissions power sources. A spokesman for the South Australian premier, Jay Weatherill, is continuing to insist that the state will not commit to sign on to the national energy guarantee in the absence of data showing its specific impact on the state. The Labor states have also commissioned their own work through the Council of Australian Governments energy council examining whether or not they could implement a clean energy target by themselves.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Answer with less than 267 words. Your answer must contain exactly 5 bullet points. Use the markdown bullet points such as:
* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2
column4:
# Turnbull Government Pushes National Energy Guarantee Plan

* The Turnbull government is intensifying efforts to gain state support for its national energy guarantee policy, releasing new modeling that projects household power bills would be approximately $120 lower annually between 2020-2030 compared to current trajectories.

* According to government summaries distributed before Friday's meeting with energy ministers, the policy would lead to a 23% reduction in wholesale electricity prices and renewable energy market share could reach between 32-36% by 2030.

* The full modeling details, conducted by Frontier Economics for the Energy Security Board, have not yet been shared with state energy ministers, who have only received summary documents rather than the complete analysis.

* The national energy guarantee, which would impose new reliability and emissions reduction requirements on energy retailers and large energy users starting in 2020, replaced the clean energy target previously recommended by chief scientist Alan Finkel, a change that occurred without state consultation.

* Labor-led state governments, particularly South Australia, remain skeptical of the plan, with Premier Jay Weatherill's office stating they won't commit without seeing data showing specific impacts on their state. Meanwhile, some states fear the policy will preserve coal's role in the energy market at the expense of renewable energy development, and have commissioned their own study exploring the possibility of implementing a clean energy target independently.
column5:
The Turnbull government has unveiled new modelling supporting its national energy guarantee aimed at delivering long-term savings and lower wholesale electricity prices. The plan is designed to persuade reluctant state governments to sign on to a policy that promises lower household power bills and a transition toward a cleaner energy mix. The modelling, prepared by Frontier Economics for the Energy Security Board, was distributed in summary form ahead of a crucial meeting with state energy ministers. However, several state governments have expressed caution and even opposition, due in part to concerns that the policy may favor coal over renewables.

* The modelling predicts household power bills could be about $120 per year lower (in today’s dollars) between 2020 and 2030.
* It indicates wholesale electricity prices might drop by 23% compared to a business-as-usual scenario.
* The national energy guarantee imposes new reliability and emissions reduction obligations on energy retailers and major users.
* Some Labor states, notably South Australia, remain hesitant without state-specific data on the policy’s impact.
* In response, state governments are exploring alternatives, including contemplating a self-managed clean energy target through the Council of Australian Governments energy council.
column6:
The Turnbull government is pushing hard for its national energy guarantee (NEG) to be adopted by all states, releasing new modelling ahead of a crucial energy ministers' meeting. The modelling claims that the NEG would result in household power bills being approximately $120 a year lower between 2020 and 2030 compared to a business-as-usual scenario. Wholesale electricity prices are also projected to decrease by 23% during the same period, with renewables potentially accounting for 32% to 36% of the energy mix by 2030.

However, the full modelling report from Frontier Economics hasn't been shared with state energy ministers, raising concerns about transparency. The NEG, which replaces the clean energy target, mandates reliability and emissions reduction guarantees for retailers and large energy users starting in 2020.

State governments, particularly Labor-led ones like South Australia, are wary of the policy. They feel excluded from the NEG's development after extensive consultations on the clean energy target. Concerns also exist that the NEG might favor coal power over renewable sources, hindering the transition to low-emission energy.

South Australia is demanding specific data on the NEG's impact on their state before committing. Labor states are also exploring the possibility of independently implementing a clean energy target.

Here are the main points of contention:

*   Lack of consultation with states in the NEG's development.
*   Concerns that the NEG favors coal over renewables.
*   Demand for specific data on the NEG's impact on individual states.
*   Labor states' consideration of implementing their own clean energy target.
*   Disagreement over the modeling that has been presented.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Northern Territory police failed to act on a string of self-harm and suicide attempts in caged police vehicles before the death of a vulnerable 23-year-old man last year, a coroner has found. NT coroner Greg Cavanagh has criticised police for failing to act on an internal report recommending CCTV cameras be installed in caged vehicles in 2013, following an earlier death in custody. In the three years between the two deaths, there were at least 16 attempted suicides in caged vehicles. “In six cases the persons were not detected until they were semi-conscious or unconscious,” Cavanagh found. “It wasn’t a matter of if a person would die in the back of a police van but when.” On 16 September last year, two officers were making their way through Darwin, on their way to investigate a noise complaint, when they came across the scene of a serious crash. A Toyota Hilux had smashed into a palm tree on the corner of the Stuart Highway and Bargot Road, not far from Darwin airport. Hiding behind some vegetation was Dale Scott Walkinshaw, 23. Walkinshaw was unharmed but held his passenger in his arms. The young woman, whom he had met earlier at a bar, was in and out of consciousness, having suffered an injury to her back. Walkinshaw was well over the limit, returning a reading of 0.149.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
column4:
"Dale Walkinshaw had not expected his night to end like this. It had started at a local bar in Darwin, where he had met a young woman. They had hit it off immediately, laughing over drinks as the evening wore on. His blood alcohol level had climbed to 0.149, well over the legal limit, but in his impaired state, driving seemed like a reasonable option.

The Toyota Hilux careened down the Stuart Highway near Darwin airport. Dale lost control at the corner of Bargot Road, and the vehicle smashed violently into a palm tree. The impact was deafening. Disoriented but uninjured, Dale stumbled from the wreckage and pulled his passenger out. She was drifting in and out of consciousness with a serious back injury. Panicking, he dragged her behind some vegetation, cradling her in his arms as sirens wailed in the distance.

Two police officers, originally responding to a noise complaint, came upon the crash scene. They found Dale hiding with the injured woman and quickly assessed the situation. Following protocol, they arrested Dale for drunk driving and placed him in the back of their caged police vehicle while paramedics attended to his passenger.

What these officers didn't know was that their seemingly routine arrest would become part of a tragic pattern in the Northern Territory. For years, the police force had failed to implement safety measures in their caged vehicles despite clear warning signs. An internal report from 2013 had recommended installing CCTV cameras following a death in custody, but the recommendation had been ignored.

In the three years since that report, at least sixteen people had attempted suicide in these vehicles. Six of those attempts had nearly succeeded, with the individuals not discovered until they were already semi-conscious or unconscious. As Coroner Greg Cavanagh would later state with chilling clarity, "It wasn't a matter of if a person would die in the back of a police van but when."

Dale Walkinshaw, 23 years old and vulnerable, would tragically become the answer to that question. His death in police custody would finally force a reckoning with the systemic failures that had been ignored for too long, adding another name to the toll of preventable deaths that plague Australia's detention systems."
column5:
"Under a scorching Darwin sun, the Northern Territory was rocked by revelations of tragic neglect that spanned over a decade. A recent inquest report by NT coroner Greg Cavanagh has brought to light a string of self-harm and suicide attempts in caged police vehicles—a bleak chapter that began with an internal report in 2013 recommending the installation of CCTV cameras following an earlier death in custody. Despite the clear warning signs, the police did not act, resulting in a disturbing pattern: in the three years between that earlier incident and the death of 23‐year‐old Dale Scott Walkinshaw, there were at least 16 attempted suicides in these vehicles. In six of these cases, vulnerable individuals were not detected until they had become semi‐conscious or unconscious, a grim reminder for Cavanagh that “it wasn’t a matter of if a person would die in the back of a police van but when.”

On 16 September of the previous year, two officers in Darwin were on routine duty when they were diverted from a noise complaint to attend the scene of a serious vehicle crash. A Toyota Hilux had collided violently with a palm tree at the intersection of Stuart Highway and Bargot Road near Darwin Airport. Amidst the wreckage and scattered debris, the officers discovered Walkinshaw crouched behind a cluster of overgrown vegetation. Though Walkinshaw escaped physical harm from the crash, his presence in a state of deep intoxication—recorded at a blood alcohol level significantly above the legal limit—painted a troubling picture that was immediately compounded by the sight of his passenger. The young woman, whom Walkinshaw had met earlier at a bar, was seen oscillating between consciousness and unconsciousness, her back bearing the brunt of the injury from the collision.

The coroner’s damning findings have sparked widespread calls for urgent reform in the handling of at-risk individuals within police custody. Critics argue that the failure to heed proactive recommendations from internal reviews reflects a systemic shortfall in safeguarding vulnerable populations, particularly those already teetering on the edge due to mental health struggles. As community leaders and advocates demand accountability, the unfolding tragedy serves as a stark reminder of the human cost of bureaucratic inertia.

In the aftermath of Walkinshaw’s death, public sentiment has turned against the institutions that allowed these warning signs to be ignored. The heartbreaking narrative of repeated missed opportunities—repeated pleas for intervention that went unanswered—raises poignant questions about the balance between law enforcement responsibilities and mental health care. Families of the victims and concerned citizens alike are now rallying for comprehensive policy changes, urging the installation of modern monitoring technology in police vehicles and revised protocols that emphasize swift intervention when a person’s life is at risk.

As the inquiry continues, the community remains vigilant, its collective hope that reform will finally replace the negligence that has too often left vulnerable members to face their demons alone. The story of Walkinshaw, intertwined with a wider pattern of ignored warnings, has become a catalyst for change—one that underscores the urgent need for a compassionate, proactive approach within both the criminal justice and mental health systems in the Northern Territory."
column6:
"The Northern Territory police are under fire after a coroner's inquest revealed a disturbing pattern of inaction leading to the death of a young man. Coroner Greg Cavanagh's report paints a damning picture of systemic failures within the NT police force, highlighting their negligence in addressing the known risks associated with transporting individuals in caged police vehicles. The report centers around the tragic death of 23-year-old Dale Scott Walkinshaw last year, but the roots of the tragedy extend much further back.

Cavanagh's investigation uncovered that a 2013 internal report had specifically recommended the installation of CCTV cameras in caged vehicles following a previous death in custody. This recommendation, aimed at preventing future tragedies, was inexplicably ignored. Between the 2013 recommendation and Walkinshaw's death, there were at least 16 documented attempts at self-harm and suicide within these vehicles. The coroner highlighted the severity of the situation, stating that in six of these cases, individuals were only discovered when they were already semi-conscious or unconscious. Cavanagh concluded that the lack of action transformed the back of a police van into a death trap, predicting not *if* another person would die, but *when*.

The events leading to Walkinshaw's death began on September 16th. Two officers, responding to a noise complaint in Darwin, stumbled upon the scene of a devastating car crash. A Toyota Hilux lay wrecked, embedded in a palm tree at the intersection of Stuart Highway and Bargot Road, near the Darwin airport. Hidden nearby, among the foliage, was Dale Scott Walkinshaw. Uninjured himself, Walkinshaw cradled his passenger, a young woman he had met at a bar earlier that evening. She was drifting in and out of consciousness, suffering from a severe back injury. Walkinshaw, found to be heavily intoxicated with a blood alcohol reading of 0.149, was subsequently taken into custody, unknowingly entering the very environment the 2013 report had warned about, and where repeated suicide attempts had already occurred."

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Turkey’s LGBT community says the government’s banning of LGBT events is not only an illegal curtailing of personal freedoms but further proof of the government’s anti-secular agenda, with some saying they are increasingly worried for their safety. Respondents to a Guardian callout said they thought Recep Tayyip Erdoğan was waging a war against them, and they felt a change in mood towards their community across the country – including in areas where they had previously enjoyed personal freedom. Authorities in Ankara imposed a ban on all LGBT cultural events on Sunday night, citing threats to public order and fear of “provoking reactions within certain segments of society”. Days earlier, they banned a festival of German-language gay films in the capital city. Idil, 25, who lives in a small city in southern Turkey, said he was used to the government’s lack of acceptance for the LGBT community, but he feared authorities were now acting on their words. “I wasn’t so surprised when I heard [the news]. I have participated in gay pride in Istanbul since 2009. The atmosphere was always really peaceful but, in the last years, it became a tour de force of the police. Brutal attacks have already given a clue about what we were going to experience. I think that this is just a start.” Last week, Erdoğan said empowering gay people was “against the values of our nation”, echoing a sentiment he expressed earlier in the year after cancelling Istanbul’s gay pride parade for a third year in a row.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Answer with one of the following options: ('My answer is yes.', 'My answer is no.', 'My answer is maybe.')
column4: My answer is no.
column5:
In the bustling heart of Istanbul, beneath flickering street lights and the persistent hum of urban life, a secret gathering took shape. Activists, students, and everyday citizens—all united by an unyielding belief in the right to love freely—met in a hidden café near the Grand Bazaar. They spoke in low voices about the latest government directives that had shuttered public celebrations and silenced their pride. Among them was Leyla, a longtime activist whose eyes held both the spark of defiance and the weight of recent losses. She recalled the days when vibrant parades had filled the streets with music and color; those moments of collective hope now replaced by whispers of fear and stories of brutal crackdowns.

Across Turkey, in a small southern town, Idil—a gentle soul with a quiet determination—shared her experience of witnessing the shift in atmosphere. Once a regular at Istanbul’s once-peaceful pride parades, she now recounted secret practices and coded affirmations exchanged among the community. In backroom meetings and clandestine video calls, people banded together to document the oppressive measures and to forge plans for peaceful resistance. Technology became their lifeline, sharing unheard stories of resilience from Ankara’s hidden corners to the isolated provinces of the south.

The underground movement slowly grew, a tapestry of bravery woven from individual acts of defiance. Secret festivals popped up in abandoned warehouses and intimate basements. As the government’s grip tightened, so did the resolve of those determined to be seen and heard. Their stories were interlaced with moments of tender joy—a stolen dance between friends, a whispered promise of tomorrow. Each act, however small, defied the narrative of fear and inequality.

In the midst of uncertainty, the community wondered if their quiet uprising would spark a broader change or if it was merely the prelude to deeper repression. And so, faced with relentless pressure but armed with unwavering conviction, they marched forward into an unknown future—a future where every heartbeat whispered the possibility of transformation.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The Czech tennis player Jana Novotná, who has died of cancer aged 49, had a career of consistent success that would have more than satisfied most players, but fell some way short of what she would have achieved had she possessed a much steadier nerve. In 1998, the year before she retired, Novotná became only the fifth female player to pass the $10m mark in career prize money and in the same year was within reach of being ranked No 1 in the world. As an athlete she was among the best of her era, possessed of consummate skill in the dying and difficult art of serve-and-volley and an ability to deliver a backhand smash that was the envy of her peers. And yet in her 14 years at the top of the women’s game she won only 24 tour singles titles. Even more disappointingly, she reached the last eight in 22 of the 50 grand slam singles events in which she competed but managed to convert that consistency into just one title. The American player and commentator Pam Shriver, who was a good friend, explained this by saying that Novotná was “as kind as she was athletic”. Others, mostly tennis writers such as myself, put it more brutally: she was a choker. Novotná herself said she hated the idea of choking, preferring instead to say that she “got a little tight”. Her most famous episode of getting a little tight is now a case study for sports psychologists. It came in the 1993 Wimbledon final when she led Steffi Graf 6-7, 6-1, 4-1, and at 40-30 in the sixth game of the deciding set had a service point for a 5-1 lead over the German.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Your response must have 5 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with SECTION X, such as:
SECTION 1
[content of section 1]
SECTION 2
[content of section 2]
column4:
# Jana Novotná: The Gentle Champion

SECTION 1
Jana Novotná stood at the baseline, bouncing the tennis ball three times—her ritual. The Centre Court at Wimbledon stretched before her like a verdant canvas, the audience hushed in anticipation. It was the 1993 final, and she led Steffi Graf 6-7, 6-1, 4-1. One more point and she'd be up 5-1 in the deciding set, practically guaranteeing her first Grand Slam title. The Czech player tossed the ball skyward, her serve crisp and precise. But as Graf returned it, something invisible yet palpable shifted in Novotná's demeanor. Her shoulders tensed. Her footwork, usually so fluid, became hesitant. The point slipped away, then the game, then the match. What sports writers would later call "choking," Novotná would gently describe as getting "a little tight."

SECTION 2
Growing up in Brno, Czechoslovakia, Jana had shown early promise as an athlete. Her natural grace and agility made her perfect for tennis, a sport that was gaining popularity in Eastern Europe. By the time she turned professional, she had developed a serve-and-volley style that was becoming increasingly rare in women's tennis. Her backhand smash became legendary—a weapon that opponents came to fear. Year after year, Novotná climbed the rankings, her consistency remarkable. She reached quarter-finals in 22 of the 50 Grand Slam singles events she entered, a testament to her skill and determination. Yet that final hurdle—converting those opportunities into championships—proved elusive.

SECTION 3
After the heartbreaking loss to Graf in 1993, Novotná found herself crying on the shoulder of the Duchess of Kent during the trophy ceremony—an unguarded moment of vulnerability that endeared her to fans worldwide. Despite the setback, she refused to be defined by failure. She continued to excel, especially in doubles play where the pressure was shared. Her partnerships on court resulted in 16 Grand Slam doubles titles, showing that her tennis acumen was never in question. As Pam Shriver, her friend and fellow player would observe, Novotná was "as kind as she was athletic." Perhaps therein lay both her strength and her weakness—a generosity of spirit that made her beloved but sometimes prevented the killer instinct needed in crucial moments.

SECTION 4
In 1998, five years after her devastating loss to Graf, Novotná finally achieved her dream. On the same Wimbledon Centre Court that had witnessed her greatest disappointment, she defeated Nathalie Tauziat to claim the championship. At 29, she became one of the oldest first-time Grand Slam singles winners in the Open Era. That same year, she came within reach of being ranked World No. 1 and surpassed $10 million in career prize money—only the fifth female player to achieve this milestone. Her perseverance had paid off, proving that her mental resilience was far stronger than critics had acknowledged. Jana retired the following year, having secured her place in tennis history not just as a skilled player, but as someone who had overcome her own psychological barriers.

SECTION 5
The news of Jana Novotná's death from cancer at just 49 sent shockwaves through the tennis community in 2017. Players, fans, and commentators reflected on her legacy—not merely her statistics or her 24 tour singles titles, but the grace with which she competed. Sports psychologists still study her 1993 Wimbledon final as a textbook case of performance anxiety, but they also reference her eventual triumph as evidence that such challenges can be overcome. In the end, Jana Novotná's story transcended tennis. It became a narrative about human frailty and strength, about facing one's demons and, eventually, conquering them. The "choker" label that once dogged her had long since been replaced by a more fitting epitaph: champion.
column5:
SECTION 1  
Jana Novotná’s career uniquely blended brilliance with moments of human frailty—a story that meshed dazzling talent, relentless dedication, and the haunting specter of pressure under the world's gaze. Known for her exceptional serve-and-volley style and an enviable backhand smash, Jana quickly ascended the echelons of women’s tennis, earning the respect of peers and audiences alike. Yet, despite achieving what many players only dream of, her journey was marked by the occasional lapse—moments when the weight of expectation proved almost too heavy to bear.

SECTION 2  
Throughout her 14 years at the top of the international circuit, Jana accumulated 24 tour singles titles along with landmark achievements, including becoming only the fifth female player in 1998 to surpass $10 million in career prize money. In the same year, as she edged close to claiming the world No 1 ranking, her record exhibited a blend of consistency and missed opportunities. Grand Slam finals, particularly the numerous times she reached the quarterfinals, became a testament to a talent at its peak yet occasionally overwhelmed by the spotlight and mounting pressure.

SECTION 3  
At the heart of Jana’s narrative was a technical prowess that set her apart. In an era dominated by power hitters, her mastery of serve-and-volley was both a revival of a classic style and a statement of her unique approach to the game. Watching her gliding across the court, one could recognize the artistry behind every calculated approach shot and every daring backhand smash. However, this brilliance came with a price: the inability, at crucial junctures, to deliver the final decisive stroke. Her self-described habit of “getting a little tight” illustrated the complex interplay between her innate athleticism and the mind’s struggle under enormous pressure.

SECTION 4  
The legends of tennis often pivot around defining moments, and for Jana, one such moment was the 1993 Wimbledon final. Leading a formidable match against Steffi Graf, the scoreline saw easing tides that shifted dramatically when, at a crucial stage in the deciding set, the pressure peaked. With a service point in the deciding game that could have furthered her advantage, her hand faltered at a score that had previously shown dominance. This episode not only became a case study for sports psychologists worldwide but also symbolized the harsh reality of competitive sports—where brilliance and vulnerability share equal ground.

SECTION 5  
Today, Jana Novotná’s legacy transcends the number of titles or her near-misses on history’s most coveted accolades. She is remembered as a compassionate competitor, beloved by peers and fans alike, and as someone who bore the pressures of her chosen sport with both grace and humanity. While critics might have labeled her a “choker” for the moments when success slipped away, those who witnessed her career understand that every athlete is a blend of achievement and struggle. In commemorating her journey, we celebrate not only her skill and victories but also the invaluable lessons learned from her passion, perseverance, and the indomitable spirit of a true champion.
column6:
Okay, here's a story based on the provided news article excerpt, divided into five sections:

SECTION 1

The Wimbledon Centre Court buzzed with an electric tension, a palpable hum that vibrated even the pristine white lines. Jana Novotná, a name whispered with respect and a tinge of pity, stood poised to serve. It was 1993. She had Steffi Graf, the indomitable champion, on the ropes. A decade of dedication, punctuated by near-misses and agonizing defeats, had led her to this very moment. The score: 6-7, 6-1, 4-1 in Jana’s favor. Forty-thirty. A simple serve, a routine volley, and she’d be five games to one up in the deciding set of the Wimbledon final. Victory, sweet and long-awaited, shimmered tantalizingly close. The crowd, a sea of expectant faces, held its breath.

SECTION 2

Jana tossed the ball, her arm a picture of graceful power. But as the ball reached its apex, a flicker of doubt, a whisper of fear, crept into her mind. *Don't choke. Don't let it slip away again.* The serve landed long. Fault. She bounced the ball, trying to regain her composure, the weight of expectation pressing down on her like a physical burden. Pam Shriver's words echoed in her ears, "As kind as she was athletic." Kind. Was that the problem? Was she too gentle, too unwilling to ruthlessly seize the opportunity? The second serve was tentative, lacking its usual bite. Graf pounced, a hawk seizing its prey.

SECTION 3

The next few games unfolded like a slow-motion nightmare. Graf, sensing weakness, unleashed a torrent of power and precision. Jana’s game, once so fluid and confident, began to unravel. Her volleys landed long, her backhand smashes lacked their customary venom. The crowd watched in stunned silence as the momentum shifted, irreversibly, towards the German champion. Game by game, Graf clawed her way back, her steely gaze unwavering, her determination absolute. Jana, meanwhile, felt the familiar tightening grip of pressure, the suffocating sensation she so desperately wanted to avoid. "I got a little tight," she would later say, a vast understatement for the emotional earthquake that was consuming her.

SECTION 4

Graf won the set, and with it, the match. The cameras captured Jana’s tears, her face etched with a mixture of heartbreak and humiliation. The Duchess of Kent, witnessing the raw emotion on display, offered a comforting shoulder, a gesture of kindness that momentarily eased the pain. The image of Jana weeping on the Duchess's shoulder became iconic, a symbol of both her vulnerability and her undeniable talent. She was forever branded as the player who choked at Wimbledon, a label that clung to her despite her other successes.

SECTION 5

Jana went on to have a successful career. She finally won Wimbledon in 1998, defeating Nathalie Tauziat. She broke the 10 million dollar prize barrier. She continued to be a force on the court, showcasing her exquisite skills and unwavering passion for the game. But the shadow of that 1993 final lingered, a constant reminder of what could have been. And yet, even in defeat, she inspired. Her story served as a cautionary tale and a testament to the immense pressure faced by athletes at the highest level. It was a story of talent and temperament, of triumph and tragedy, forever etched in the annals of tennis history.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 EasyJet saw its profits fall 17% last year, with more than £100m lost due to the slump in the pound after the Brexit vote. The airline reported a record year for passenger numbers, flying 80.2 million people, almost 10% more than in 2015-16, on ever fuller planes. But while revenues exceeded £5bn in 2016-17, fares dipped to fill seats in what the chief executive, Carolyn McCall, said was “a difficult year for the aviation industry”. McCall said: “Our planned approach of achieving number one or two positions at Europe’s leading airports, friendly and efficient customer service and a continuous focus on sustainable cost control, has put easyJet at a strategic advantage during a period when there have been bankruptcies and some airlines have struggled operationally.” Profits before tax fell from £494m to £408m. Despite paying a lower dollar price for fuel, the continued weakness of sterling brought additional costs of £101m, easyJet said. The airline will also be prompted by Brexit to change its rules to ensure easyJet is majority owned and controlled by EU nationals after 2019. About a third of shares are owned by the easyJet founder, Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who has dual UK-Cypriot nationality, and will be classed as EU-owned. But easyJet will ask at its 2018 AGM for new powers to force UK shareholders to sell up if necessary to allow it to continue operating in Europe. McCall said the move was “a technical, administrative thing” and the airline had “no concerns” about getting enough EU shareholders. Shares rose by more than 5% in early trading, on the back of the airline reporting high levels of forward bookings and better revenue so far in its 2017-18 financial year, which it said was “primarily as a result of some capacity leaving the market”.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['dare', 'fishing', 'society', 'tower', 'treat'] in the response. Do not include keywords ['calm', 'coffee', 'combination', 'count', 'pool'] in the response. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>. Your response must have 3 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Section X, such as:
Section 1
[content of section 1]
Section 2
[content of section 2]
column4:
<<EasyJet: Navigating Through Brexit Turbulence>>

Section 1
In a daring move amidst the post-Brexit economic climate, EasyJet continues to forge ahead despite reporting a 17% fall in profits last year. The budget airline lost more than £100 million due to the slump in the pound following the Brexit vote, a bitter financial treat that many UK-based companies have had to swallow. Despite these challenges, EasyJet achieved record passenger numbers, flying 80.2 million people—almost 10% more than the previous financial year—on increasingly full planes.

The airline's chief executive, Carolyn McCall, acknowledged the difficulties facing the aviation industry while highlighting EasyJet's strategic positioning at Europe's leading airports. Like a skilled fishing expedition that knows where to cast its nets, EasyJet has maintained its focus on sustainable cost control while competitors have faced bankruptcies and operational struggles. This approach has helped the company weather the storm, though profits before tax still declined from £494 million to £408 million.

Section 2
The Brexit referendum has cast a long shadow over British society and businesses alike, forcing companies like EasyJet to adapt to new realities. Much like a tower needs solid foundations to withstand strong winds, EasyJet must now ensure its corporate structure complies with EU regulations after 2019. The airline plans to change its rules to remain majority-owned and controlled by EU nationals—a requirement for continuing its operations across Europe.

Approximately one-third of EasyJet shares belong to founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who holds dual UK-Cypriot nationality and will be classified as an EU owner. However, the company will seek new powers at its 2018 Annual General Meeting to potentially force UK shareholders to sell their stakes if necessary—a measure McCall described as "a technical, administrative thing" rather than a cause for concern.

Section 3
Despite these challenges, EasyJet's market position appears to be strengthening. The company's shares rose by more than 5% in early trading following reports of high levels of forward bookings and improved revenue at the start of its 2017-18 financial year. This positive trend was attributed primarily to reduced capacity in the market as some competitors scaled back or ceased operations altogether.

The airline's resilience in the face of Brexit-related uncertainties demonstrates how even established businesses must adapt to changing political landscapes. As UK-based companies across various sectors prepare for Britain's departure from the European Union, EasyJet's proactive approach offers a case study in corporate adaptation. The airline industry, often seen as a barometer for wider economic conditions, continues to reflect the complex relationship between business, politics, and society. EasyJet's strategy to maintain its European market presence while addressing the challenges of Brexit shows that even when faced with substantial headwinds, determined companies dare to chart a course forward.
column5:
<<Flight of Change>>

Section 1  
In the wake of Brexit and a turbulent year for the aviation industry, EasyJet found itself navigating stormy skies. Despite a record year for passenger travel, the airline faced a 17% drop in profits as losses mounted due to the weakened sterling. As profits before tax dipped from £494m to £408m and extra costs of over £100m were recorded, the airline had no choice but to re-assess its strategies. EasyJet’s chief executive, Carolyn McCall, emphasized the importance of sustainable cost control and operational efficiency to survive in an increasingly competitive market. This financial turbulence prompted the airline to explore bold new directions in order to secure its future and safeguard its standing in the European aviation society.

Section 2  
While many in the industry shuddered at the thought of potential setbacks, a determined team within EasyJet dared to reimagine their approach. They embarked on a journey akin to fishing in uncharted waters—seeking out innovative practices and nurturing strategic partnerships to transform challenges into opportunities. Their plan involved revisiting ownership rules in response to Brexit, ensuring that the airline remained majority EU-owned. Like a watchful tower guiding a ship through a storm, these initiatives provided a steady course through a period marked by bankruptcies and operational struggles among peers. The company's resilience was further buoyed by high levels of forward bookings and improved revenue trends in the subsequent financial year.

Section 3  
At its 2018 AGM, EasyJet introduced measures that, while technical and administrative in nature, symbolized a broader commitment to future growth and innovation. The proposed powers allowing EasyJet to require UK shareholders to sell up if necessary were seen as a treat to investors, reaffirming the airline’s resolve to maintain its strong position in Europe. This bold move, much like standing atop a tower with a panoramic view of potential horizons, underscored the company’s willingness to take calculated risks and transform adversity into an opportunity for renewal. As the airline continues to soar into the future, its journey serves as a reminder that even in times of economic strain, strategic vision and decisive action can help rebuild a resilient aviation society.
column6:
<<EasyJet's Brexit Turbulence>>

Section 1
EasyJet faced a turbulent year, with profits plummeting by 17% due to the post-Brexit pound slump, costing them over £100 million. Despite this financial hit, the airline boasted a record-breaking 80.2 million passengers, a near 10% increase from the previous year, filling their planes to the brim. Revenues surpassed £5 billion, but fares were lowered to maintain occupancy, painting what CEO Carolyn McCall described as "a difficult year for the aviation industry." McCall emphasized that their strategy of dominating key European airports, providing excellent customer service, and relentlessly managing costs placed them at a strategic advantage during a period where other airlines faced bankruptcies and operational struggles. Some might even *dare* say they navigated the storm with surprising skill.

Section 2
While pre-tax profits fell from £494m to £408m, the continued weakness of sterling offset lower fuel prices, adding £101m to their expenses. The airline is also compelled by Brexit to restructure its ownership, ensuring that a majority of shares are held by EU nationals post-2019. Currently, about a third of shares belong to founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who, with his dual UK-Cypriot nationality, will be considered an EU shareholder. However, easyJet plans to request new powers at their 2018 AGM, allowing them to force UK shareholders to sell their shares if needed to maintain European operating permits. It’s like a desperate attempt at *fishing* for EU shareholders in a sea of uncertainty. The company has been compared with a *tower* in the modern aviation *society*.

Section 3
McCall dismissed this as "a technical, administrative thing," expressing confidence that easyJet would secure sufficient EU shareholders. The news boosted shares by over 5% in early trading, fueled by high forward bookings and improved revenue in the initial period of their 2017-18 financial year, attributed primarily to reduced market capacity. The company hopes for a smoother flight moving forward, and shareholders may consider this year's result a sweet *treat* compared with some other airlines that have ceased operation.
