column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 There are three broad categories of microbiome, named by Atlas, a company that will analyse the bacterial environment in your gut: the Urban Citizen, the Village Peasant and the Indigene. Your type can change if you significantly alter your diet. Anyone with any sense wants to be an Indigene, since the Urban Citizen is associated with the “western diet” (code for: “some Cinnamon Grahams and a KFC, what of it?”) and the Village Peasant sounds a bit, you know, dumpy. However, the Indigene is most prevalent in isolated tribespeople from the Amazon and Africa, or failing that, vegetarians. I got my results back from the £125 test I did in August, a complicated business of trapping poo on a piece of paper. I did this because your gut environment is as vital to your overall health as your hormonal one, or your brain chemistry; its health is determined by bacterial balance, which in turn is affected by your diet. I’m a Village Peasant. It turns out, now that I am one, they’re the best. I have bacteria from the Dorea genus to reduce inflammation of the gut, making it less likely that I’ll get Crohn’s disease. I have eubacterium, built by bananas and barley which, since I hate bananas, I can only ascribe to my high consumption of Ovaltine.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Answer with at least 335 words. Include keywords ['mention', 'music', 'smoke', 'stick', 'value'] in the response. Your response should contain less than 14 sentences.
column4:
# The Village Peasant's Microbiome Odyssey

I never thought I'd be proud of being labeled a "Village Peasant," but here I am, practically boasting about my gut bacteria classification. When I first heard about Atlas, a company that would analyze my microbiome by examining—rather indelicately—a sample of my feces trapped on paper for the princely sum of £125, I was skeptical about its value. My friends would often mention their "clean eating" regimens while I quietly nursed my Ovaltine, wondering if my occasional cigarette smoke was undoing whatever good my somewhat balanced diet was achieving.

The results arrived with three possible categories: Urban Citizen (essentially the processed food junkie), Indigene (the holy grail of gut health, found primarily in remote tribespeople and zealous vegetarians), and Village Peasant—which turned out to be my classification, a revelation that initially felt like being handed a participation trophy until I discovered its hidden advantages. My gut houses the inflammation-reducing Dorea genus bacteria, apparently thriving in my intestines like a well-rehearsed orchestra, each microbe playing its part in a symphony of digestive harmony that protects me from conditions like Crohn's disease.

The eubacterium in my system—supposedly built by consuming bananas and barley—puzzled me since I'd sooner use a banana as a decorative stick than actually eat one, until I realized my nightly Ovaltine ritual was likely responsible. As I sat digesting this information (both mentally and literally), I played some classical music, finding it oddly appropriate for contemplating the complex ecosystem flourishing within me—billions of microscopic creatures collaborating in an intricate dance of survival that directly impacts my health in ways science is only beginning to understand.

The Urban Citizens may have their convenience foods and the Indigenes their purity, but we Village Peasants exist in a practical middle ground, nurturing gut gardens that are remarkably resilient despite our occasional dietary transgressions—perhaps not perfect, but surprisingly well-adapted to modern life's contradictions.
column5:
I had always been fascinated by the idea that the tiny, unseen world inside me could define so much about my health and identity, so when I discovered Atlas’s test could categorize my gut into types as curious as the Urban Citizen, the Village Peasant, and the Indigene, I couldn’t help but get involved, even if it cost me a cool £125.  

When the day finally arrived to receive my results, I was met with a mix of apprehension and excitement that was almost as pervasive as the rich bass notes and soulful music drifting in the background of my small, sparsely furnished living room; that music served as a comforting reminder that life’s rhythm was about more than just scientific labels.  

To my surprise, my gut microbiome classified me as a Village Peasant—a label that, contrary to any negative connotation, imbued me with a reassuring sense of balance and health, as the presence of Dorea genus bacteria promised to reduce inflammation and protect me from ailments like Crohn’s disease, proving that even in the complex tapestry of the human microbiome, every detail held value.  

I found it interesting that, despite the seemingly simple concept of scoring your gut flora, this process became a personal journey replete with moments that made me stop and truly appreciate how our daily choices—like the food we eat or even the smoke we sometimes casually inhale without a thought—could radically alter the internal landscape of our bodies.  

Much like selecting the right stick when building a campfire, every decision I made, from avoiding foods I disliked, such as bananas, to savoring unexpected treats like barley-infused recipes, played a part in maintaining my body’s equilibrium.  

The study also mentioned that while the Indigene type was admired for its association with remote tribespeople and vegetarians, my Village Peasant designation quietly underscored that I was doing something right; it wasn’t about trying to emulate a distant ideal, but about understanding and nurturing what nature had provided me.  

I often pause to mention to curious friends how my journey into the world of gut bacteria not only reshaped my view on personal health but also redefined what it means to live in harmony with one’s own biology, all while enjoying life’s everyday treasures, no matter how small.  

In embracing this new identity, I learned that achieving health was not about a grand revolution, but rather about making thoughtful, incremental changes—each one as essential as a carefully chosen piece of music that can set the perfect tone for a long and rewarding journey.  

Ultimately, I discovered that the real story lay not in the laboratory results or in the high cost of tests, but in the quiet, determined commitment to improving oneself, much like nurturing a flame that burns steadily, guided by the understanding that every choice, every meal, and even every stick of resolve contributes to a healthier, happier life.
column6:
Agnes slumped onto her threadbare sofa, the Atlas microbiome results clutched in her hand. Village Peasant. The name conjured images of stout women in dirndls, churning butter and smelling faintly of manure – not the sleek, sophisticated image she cultivated. The Urban Citizen, with its implied cosmopolitan lifestyle fueled by Cinnamon Grahams and KFC, seemed equally unappealing. To Agnes, these options lacked significant value. Everyone secretly craved the Indigene status, a badge of honor awarded to those who subsisted on rainforest fruits and mystical herbs, or at the very least, embraced the dietary discipline of vegetarianism.

Her own journey into the world of gut bacteria had begun with a £125 test and the undignified task of paper-trapping her own stool. Agnes knew that the microbiome held the key to overall health, as influential as hormones or brain chemistry, dependent on a delicate balance orchestrated by diet. The Village Peasant designation stung at first, but a closer reading revealed unexpected perks. She possessed Dorea bacteria, tiny warriors against gut inflammation, shielding her from the dreaded Crohn's disease. Eubacterium thrived within her, a gift from bananas and barley. Since she loathed bananas, Agnes suspected her nightly Ovaltine ritual was responsible.

A sudden urge for something more rebellious took over. She pulled out a pack of cigarettes from her handbag, despite having quit months ago. As she stepped onto the balcony and lit one, the smoke swirling around her head like fleeting thoughts, she considered what to do next. The nicotine buzzed through her system, a faint rebellion against the strictures of gut health and designated microbiome categories. On the radio, a jazz program played a mournful melody, the music seemed to echo her own internal struggle.

Agnes pictured her friend, Beatrice, an Urban Citizen who swore by processed snacks. Beatrice was always mentioning the latest health trends, completely missing the significance of a healthy lifestyle. Agnes tapped the cigarette ash into a small ceramic ashtray shaped like a cow. She imagined herself as a bohemian Village Peasant, trading butter-churning for experimental pottery, a quirky artist with a healthy gut. Throwing the stick into the trash, she smiled. Perhaps Village Peasant wasn’t so bad after all. Maybe it was just a matter of reframing the narrative, adding her own twist. And maybe, just maybe, she would try to like bananas.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The campaign group that encouraged Paperchase to apologise for its marketing activities with the Daily Mail is pushing for John Lewis, the department store chain, to stop advertising with the newspaper as well as with the Sun and Daily Express. John Lewis has become a prime target for Stop Funding Hate on the back of the launch of its Christmas advert and as retailers increase their spending on advertising as the festive season approaches. Stop Funding Hate has produced a mock advert that depicts the star of last year’s John Lewis Christmas advert – Buster the dog – as unhappy because the retailer is buying adverts with the Mail, Sun, and Express. The video has been shared almost 10,000 times on Twitter and Facebook. Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer and Waitrose are also being targeted by Stop Funding Hate. The organisation was founded last year and says its aim is to take on “divisive hate campaigns” by the Mail, Sun and Express, and persuade advertisers to cease their financial input. Richard Wilson, the founder of Stop Funding Hate, said: “[John Lewis] are a company well known for their ethical values and one that people have a lot of respect for. Customers are saying there is a clash between what the brand stands for and these newspapers. It would be great if John Lewis made a move, but another company could make a move too.” However, John Lewis said it would continue advertising with the newspapers and not bow to the pressure. A spokesperson said: “Withdrawing advertising on the basis of editorial coverage would be inconsistent with our democratic principles, which include freedom of speech and remaining apolitical.” Paperchase announced on Monday that it would not run any marketing campaigns with the Daily Mail and said it was “truly sorry” for running a front-page promotion in Saturday’s edition of the newspaper.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Do not include keywords ['bottle', 'district', 'general', 'stroke', 'tap'] in the response. There should be 3 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 1 must start with word classic.
column4:
Classic campaigning tactics are evolving in the digital age as Stop Funding Hate pushes retailers to reconsider their advertising choices. The group, which previously convinced Paperchase to apologize for marketing with the Daily Mail, has now set its sights on John Lewis, urging the department store chain to cease advertising with the Daily Mail, the Sun, and Daily Express. Their strategy includes a mock advertisement featuring Buster the dog from last year's John Lewis Christmas campaign, portraying him as unhappy due to the retailer's advertising decisions. This creative approach has gained significant traction on social media platforms.

The pressure campaign extends beyond John Lewis to other major UK retailers including Sainsbury's, Marks & Spencer, and Waitrose, particularly as holiday advertising spending increases. Stop Funding Hate, founded in 2016, states its mission is to combat what it describes as "divisive hate campaigns" by certain newspapers by persuading advertisers to withdraw financial support. Richard Wilson, who established the organization, emphasized John Lewis's reputation for ethical values, suggesting there's a disconnect between the company's brand identity and the content of these publications.

Despite mounting pressure, John Lewis has taken a firm stance on the issue, declining to alter its advertising strategy. A company spokesperson defended this position by stating that withdrawing advertising based on editorial coverage would contradict their democratic principles, including freedom of speech and political neutrality. This response highlights the complex tensions between commercial decisions, consumer activism, and principles of free expression. Meanwhile, Paperchase took a different approach, announcing it would discontinue marketing campaigns with the Daily Mail following similar pressure, even issuing a public apology for a recent front-page promotion in the newspaper.
column5:
classic controversy unfolded as a well-known campaign group, which previously spurred a major retailer to reconsider its media engagements, now urged another respected brand to rethink its advertising ties. The group, synonymous with its advocacy against contentious media partnerships, has critiqued the department store’s decision to invest in advertisements alongside certain newspapers. Highlighting a perceived misalignment between the retailer’s ethical values and the editorial stances of these publications, the campaign has employed creative satire to underscore its message.

The movement’s momentum surged with the release of a mock advertisement that cleverly reimagines a figure from a much-loved Christmas campaign. The parody, skillfully crafted to resonate with a broad audience, has quickly become a social media sensation, sparking vigorous debate across various online communities. Alongside this targeted call to action, the campaign has set its sights on other prominent retailers, urging them to reflect on the implications of their advertising investments.

In response, the department store in question has maintained its position, emphasizing its dedication to upholding principles of free speech and impartiality. A spokesperson explained that any decision to alter their advertising strategy would fundamentally conflict with the company’s commitment to democratic values. As discussions surrounding ethical advertising practices continue to intensify in the lead-up to the festive season, the story reflects an evolving conversation about the influence of media partnerships on brand identity.
column6:
Classic British retailer John Lewis finds itself in the crosshairs of the Stop Funding Hate campaign, known for pressuring businesses to cut ties with certain newspapers. Following Paperchase's apology for its Daily Mail marketing, the group is now urging John Lewis to cease advertising with the Daily Mail, Sun, and Daily Express. Stop Funding Hate has amplified its message with a mock advert featuring Buster the dog, the star of a previous John Lewis Christmas campaign, looking dejected due to the retailer's newspaper advertising choices. Their social media video has quickly gone viral, garnering significant attention and highlighting the perceived conflict between the retailer's ethical image and the newspapers' content. Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer and Waitrose are also being targeted by Stop Funding Hate.

The campaign, founded last year, aims to challenge what it considers "divisive hate campaigns" perpetuated by the targeted newspapers by persuading advertisers to withdraw their financial support. Richard Wilson, the founder of Stop Funding Hate, has emphasized the dissonance felt by customers, stating that John Lewis's ethical reputation clashes with the values represented by these newspapers. While hoping for a proactive move from John Lewis, Wilson suggests any company taking a stand could significantly impact the situation.

However, John Lewis has firmly stated its intention to continue advertising with the newspapers, rejecting the pressure exerted by the campaign. A company spokesperson articulated the retailer's position, emphasizing that withdrawing advertising based on editorial coverage would compromise its commitment to democratic principles, specifically freedom of speech and political neutrality. This stance sets the stage for a continued debate as Stop Funding Hate persists in its efforts to influence advertising strategies within the UK retail landscape.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 It was the frog that pushed me over the edge. I’ve never been a Harry Potter fan myself – I was already out of kids’ books when they first came out, and those clever grown-up covers weren’t enough to tempt me back – but I’d always admired JK Rowling from afar. Who wouldn’t? A writer whose imagination transfixed the world, whose riches now exceed those of the Queen, but who has founded a children’s charity, pays her taxes in full, and remains both poised and politically engaged: as role models go, it is hard to think of a better one. So I was pleased when my seven-year-old son went Harry Potter crazy. Having never read to himself before, he was suddenly racing through book after book, his bedside light on late into the night. His brother and several of his friends caught the bug – just as the Suez canal flowed through Clarissa Eden’s drawing room, Hogwarts overshadowed our house, as children constantly dashed about on broomsticks, casting spells and looking for snitches. It was impressive to see the “Harry Potter effect” in action: the magical power that, in the two decades since its first publication, has revitalised the children’s publishing industry, encouraged millions of children to read, sold more than 400m copies across the world, and generated a cultural empire worth £20bn. Less pleasant, however, was the realisation that there was a marketing juggernaut poised to capitalise on my son’s enthusiasm. Unlike those first readers 20 years ago, the children discovering Harry Potter now are immediately faced with a multibillion-pound industry trading in Potter-themed “experiences” and paraphernalia.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with less than 177 words. There should be 2 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: ***
column4:
The article begins with the author admitting their disinterest in Harry Potter while expressing admiration for J.K. Rowling's accomplishments. Despite never reading the books themselves, they respect Rowling as a successful author who maintains charitable work, pays taxes properly, and remains politically active. When their seven-year-old son became captivated by the series, the author witnessed firsthand how the books inspired reading habits among children, including their son who had previously shown little interest in reading independently.

***

However, the author soon realized that today's young Potter fans face immediate exposure to a massive merchandising industry. Unlike the original readers twenty years ago who simply enjoyed the books, children now encounter an overwhelming array of Potter-themed products and experiences. The "Harry Potter effect" has not only revitalized children's publishing and sold over 400 million copies worldwide but has also generated a £20 billion cultural empire that aggressively markets to enthusiastic young readers.
column5:
I wasn’t always a fan of children’s books, yet I admired JK Rowling from a distance for her imaginative wizardry and impressive achievements. When my seven-year-old son discovered Harry Potter, his newfound love for the series transformed bedtime into a late-night reading adventure, with his friends quickly joining in. The magical spark that revitalized children’s literature over the past two decades was now alive in our home.

*** 

However, alongside the enchantment came the stark realization that a massive marketing machine was eager to benefit from his enthusiasm. What began as a cultural phenomenon that spurred millions of young readers has also evolved into a multibillion-pound industry, trading in Potter-themed experiences and merchandise far beyond the simple joy of reading the books.
column6:
The author, not a Harry Potter enthusiast initially, admired J.K. Rowling for her success, philanthropy, and political engagement. When the author's seven-year-old son became engrossed in the series, it was a welcome surprise. This enthusiasm mirrored the widespread "Harry Potter effect," which boosted children's literature, motivated countless children to read, and created a vast cultural and economic phenomenon.

***

However, the author soon realized that this enthusiasm was being exploited by a massive marketing machine. Today's young readers are instantly bombarded with a multibillion-pound industry that is trading in Potter-themed merchandise and experiences.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 OK, so a mysterious, cigar-shaped, 400m-long object is speeding through the solar system and astronomers are checking it for evidence of alien technology. So what do we do if it turns out that Oumuamua, as they have named it, is broadcasting extraterrestrial radio signals? John Chambers, Leeds Post your answers – and new questions – below or email them to nq@theguardian.com
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with less than 274 words. Your response must have 1 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Section X, such as:
Section 1
[content of section 1]
Section 2
[content of section 2] At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
Section 1
Astronomers are currently investigating an enigmatic, cigar-shaped object measuring 400 meters in length that's rapidly moving through our solar system. They've named this mysterious visitor "Oumuamua" and are specifically examining it for any signs of alien technology. The article poses an intriguing question to readers: What should humanity's response be if we discover this object is actually transmitting extraterrestrial radio signals? The Guardian is inviting readers to share their thoughts on this provocative scenario, either by posting comments below the article or by emailing their responses to nq@theguardian.com.

P.S. This appears to be from a Guardian piece seeking reader input on a hypothetical first contact scenario, using the real interstellar object Oumuamua (discovered in 2017) as a conversation starter.
column5:
Section 1  
A strangely shaped, cigar-like object roughly 400 meters long is currently racing through our solar system, and astronomers are investigating whether it could be linked to alien tech. Named Oumuamua, this mysterious body has raised the question: what would our course of action be if it turns out that the object is actually sending out extraterrestrial radio signals?

Section 2  
Readers are invited to share their views and ask further questions. You can join the discussion by responding in the comments or sending an email to nq@theguardian.com.

P.S. Thank you for engaging with this intriguing astronomical mystery!
column6:
Section 1
A peculiar, elongated object, roughly 400 meters in length, has been detected hurtling through our solar system, prompting astronomers to investigate the possibility of it being an alien artifact. This object, named Oumuamua, has sparked the question: what should be our course of action if it's discovered that Oumuamua is transmitting extraterrestrial radio signals? The Guardian is soliciting public opinions, questions, and ideas regarding this hypothetical scenario, inviting responses via the comments section or through email.

P.S. This is a hypothetical scenario presented by the Guardian to engage the public in a discussion about the potential implications of detecting extraterrestrial signals from the object Oumuamua.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 In France, thanks to our social security system, prenatal and postnatal care is fully covered in public hospitals. Wage-earning women are also entitled to a maternity leave of 16 weeks, with compensation ranging from €9,29 ($10.94) to €84,90 ($100) per day (according to how much they made before taking leave). As for pregnancy and the weeks around childbirth, finances are no more a problem than outside this period: precarious households are still struggling, but not more than before, and well-off households remain well off. If we look at how supported a mother is, however – well, nothing is planned to help the young mother. Paternity leave lasts only 11 days, which is not even enough for mothers to recover from childbirth. Young mothers must therefore manage the daily, non-stop demands of their new life while they try and heal. They must also seek childcare, knowing that programs proposed by the state are not sufficient, especially in the Paris region. The cost of child care varies greatly. In daycare centers, the less well-off households can get by for €1,000 ($1,177.59) per year – but there is only one place for every eight children. Households therefore use private services such as childminders or home care.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Finish your response with this exact phrase Any other questions?. No other words should follow this phrase. Do not include keywords ['adult', 'inflation', 'schedule', 'war', 'writing'] in the response.
column4: In France, the social security system provides full coverage for prenatal and postnatal care in public hospitals. Working women receive 16 weeks of maternity leave with daily compensation between €9.29 and €84.90 based on their previous earnings. While financial concerns during pregnancy aren't generally worse than at other times—struggling families continue to struggle and comfortable households remain comfortable—there's a significant gap in support for new mothers. The brief 11-day paternity leave isn't enough time for mothers to recover from childbirth, leaving them to manage constant newborn demands while healing. Additionally, they must secure childcare, with state programs being insufficient, particularly around Paris. Childcare costs vary widely; daycare centers can cost less-advantaged families about €1,000 annually, but with only one spot available for every eight children, many households resort to private options like childminders or home care services. Any other questions?
column5: In France, the public healthcare system completely covers both prenatal and postnatal care in state hospitals. Women who earn wages benefit from a 16‐week maternity leave, receiving daily compensation between €9.29 ($10.94) and €84.90 ($100) based on their previous income. Financial circumstances during pregnancy and the weeks immediately following childbirth remain consistent; households that were struggling continue to do so, while well-off households maintain their status. However, there is no additional support planned for new mothers. Paternity leave lasts only 11 days, which is insufficient even to allow mothers adequate time to recuperate. As a result, young mothers are left to juggle the constant demands of their new responsibilities while needing to find childcare—especially since government programs, notably in the Paris region, fall short of meeting the need. Childcare costs widely vary; in daycare centers, less well-off households might pay about €1,000 ($1,177.59) per year, yet only one spot is available for every eight children, prompting families to rely on private childminders or home care. Any other questions?
column6: In France, public hospitals fully cover prenatal and postnatal care, and employed women receive 16 weeks of paid maternity leave. Pregnancy and childbirth do not significantly alter existing financial situations for families. However, new mothers receive inadequate support. Paternity leave is only 11 days, insufficient for a mother's recovery. Mothers must cope with the constant demands of caring for their new baby while also arranging childcare, which is expensive and scarce, particularly in Paris. Subsidized daycare is limited, forcing many families to rely on costlier private options. Any other questions?

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 New Kettle’s Yard, Cambridge, by Jamie Fobert Not an art gallery, but a home for “stray objects, stones, glass, pictures, sculpture, in light and in space,” is how former Tate curator Jim Ede described Kettle’s Yard, the Cambridge house where he arranged his stunning collection of 20th-century art alongside found objects, later donated to the university. Originally extended by modernist architect Leslie Martin in 1970, it has now received a sensitive £8.7m expansion by Jamie Fobert, including remodelled gallery spaces and an education wing, cafe and shop around a new courtyard. • Opens 10 February, Kettle’s Yard, Cambridge. Hope to Nope: Politics and Graphics 2008-2018 at the Design Museum From the endless imitations of Shepard Fairey’s seminal Hope poster for Barack Obama’s 2008 presidential campaign, to the inventive plethora of Donald Trump memes, this exhibition will show how graphic design’s engagement with politics has evolved over the last decade. Featuring the work of high-profile and amateur designers, in campaign billboards, T-shirts and cartoons, it will show graphic design’s power as a tool for political discussion, debate and provocation. • Opens 28 March, Design Museum, London. Windermere Jetty Museum by Carmody Groarke A cluster of copper-clad sheds nestles on the edge of Windermere in the Lake District, signalling the new home for the Jetty Museum, a fascinating little institution that has been telling the story of boats and boatsmen since the 1940s. The new £16m complex includes a wet dock, allowing boats to be displayed on water within the museum, and a new workshop for visitors to see the conservation of steam launches, sailing yachts and motor boats in action. • Opens 2018, Windermere Jetty Museum, Bowness-on-Windermere. Royal Academy of Arts development by David Chipperfield “A small amount of architecture for a profound result,” is how Sir David Chipperfield describes his £50m series of surgical interventions in the Royal Academy’s two-acre site, designed to link Burlington House on Piccadilly with Burlington Gardens, behind it, for the first time.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
column4: "The Guardian article opens by describing Jamie Fobert's new extension to Kettle's Yard in Cambridge, a unique space that founder Jim Ede envisioned not as a traditional gallery but as a home for art and found objects. Following a £8.7m expansion, the former residence now features additional gallery spaces, educational facilities, and amenities arranged around a courtyard. The article continues by previewing upcoming exhibitions and architectural projects, including 'Hope to Nope' at the Design Museum, which explores the evolution of political graphic design over the past decade; the copper-clad Windermere Jetty Museum designed by Carmody Groarke; and David Chipperfield's £50m development connecting two buildings of the Royal Academy of Arts."
column5:
"New Kettle’s Yard in Cambridge, originally a residence and art shelter for random objects – stones, glass, photos, sculptures – has gained a new lease on life. Former Tate curator Jim Ede once described this home as an unexpected gallery where 20th-century art met found objects, later donated to the university. The property, which received an extension by modernist architect Leslie Martin in 1970, now benefits from a carefully designed £8.7m upgrade by Jamie Fobert. The expansion features renovated gallery spaces plus a new education wing, café, and shop arranged around a newly created courtyard, set to open on 10 February at Kettle’s Yard, Cambridge.

Meanwhile, the Design Museum in London will launch an exhibition titled Hope to Nope: Politics and Graphics 2008-2018 on 28 March. This show will explore the evolution of political engagement in graphic design, spanning from the ubiquitous renditions of Shepard Fairey’s iconic 2008 Barack Obama Hope poster to a diverse array of Donald Trump memes. By presenting work from both established and emerging designers in forms ranging from campaign billboards to T-shirts and cartoons, the exhibition will highlight how graphic design acts as a catalyst for political dialogue and provocation.

In the Lake District at Windermere, the Jetty Museum finds a new home with a £16m development by Carmody Groarke. A group of copper-clad sheds now houses this unique institution, which has been chronicling the story of boats and their crews since the 1940s. The newly built complex, opening in 2018 in Bowness-on-Windermere, now includes a wet dock that allows boats to be exhibited on water, as well as a workshop where visitors can observe the conservation work being done on historic steam launches, sailing yachts, and motor boats.

Additionally, Sir David Chipperfield’s work at the Royal Academy of Arts is described as “a small amount of architecture for a profound result.” His surgical £50m interventions have transformed the Academy’s two-acre site by creating a vital link between Burlington House on Piccadilly and Burlington Gardens behind it, marking the first time these spaces have been directly connected."
column6: "Kettle's Yard in Cambridge, once the home and curated collection of Jim Ede, has been expanded by Jamie Fobert with new gallery spaces, an education area, cafe, and shop. The Design Museum will host "Hope to Nope: Politics and Graphics 2008-2018," showcasing the evolution of graphic design in political discourse through various mediums, including campaign materials and memes. Carmody Groarke's Windermere Jetty Museum, featuring copper-clad buildings, will open in the Lake District, displaying boats on water and offering conservation workshops. Finally, David Chipperfield's project at the Royal Academy of Arts aims to connect Burlington House with Burlington Gardens through architectural interventions."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Cheyenne Mangold’s hands shook ever so slightly as she reached with a long metal instrument to catch hold of what looked like the cervix. The medical student was attempting, for the very first time, the rudiments of performing an abortion. As she inexpertly brought the pincers together on the soft flesh, you might have expected a little yelp of pain from the patient. There was silence. Not because the “patient” was brave, but because it was a papaya. Mangold was at a special workshop organized by a not-for-profit group whose mission is to make up for the lack of instruction on contraception and abortion at many US medical programs. But it doubled as a lesson in using a no-frills kit of basic instruments that, in the event of the practice becoming illegal in the US, could be stashed and carried discreetly, to perform covert abortions safely. And it so happens that the papaya, with its little fruity neck and a central cavity full of seeds and pulp, is a serviceable approximation of a woman’s cervix and womb for the purposes of basic initiation for a medic in training. Mangold was in a roomful of 60 rookies from across the country. They juggled fruit and tools as they began their journey, come what may, to become the next generation of abortion providers – an increasingly scarce species in some parts of the US.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with at least 169 words. Your answer must contain exactly 3 bullet points. Use the markdown bullet points such as:
* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2
column4:
# Medical Students Learn Abortion Techniques Using Unconventional Methods

* At a specialized workshop organized by a not-for-profit organization, medical student Cheyenne Mangold practiced abortion procedures for the first time using a papaya as a model. The fruit's structure - with its neck and seed-filled cavity - serves as a surprisingly effective anatomical approximation of a woman's cervix and womb, allowing students to practice with basic medical instruments in a low-pressure environment.

* This training aims to compensate for the insufficient instruction on contraception and abortion procedures in many American medical programs. Beyond standard medical education, the workshop had a dual purpose: teaching students how to perform the procedure using minimal equipment that could potentially be transported discreetly if abortion becomes illegal in various states.

* The session brought together approximately 60 medical students from across the country who are committed to becoming abortion providers despite the increasingly challenging landscape. As these healthcare professionals train with improvised models and basic tools, they represent a new generation of abortion providers - a medical specialty becoming increasingly rare in certain regions of the United States due to legal restrictions and challenges.
column5:
Cheyenne Mangold’s hands trembled slightly as she reached with a long, metal tool toward an object resembling a cervix. In this first attempt at simulating an abortion procedure, the nervous medical student used a papaya in place of a human patient. One might have anticipated a reaction—perhaps even a grimace or a small cry—when the pincers were closed on the soft surface, but there was only silence because the “patient” was merely a papaya. Mangold was participating in a special workshop organized by a non-profit group dedicated to alleviating the lack of instruction on contraception and abortion in many US medical schools. The session also served as training on using a basic, portable kit of instruments that could one day be used to perform covert abortions safely, should legal restrictions intensify. The papaya, with its narrow neck and seed-filled cavity, provided a practical simulation of a woman’s cervix and womb. For clarity in practice, consider that:  
* The papaya effectively mimics human cervical anatomy.  
* Around 60 new trainees from across the country participated.  
* They practiced handling both fruit and medical instruments with meticulous care.  

In this way, these future abortion providers are preparing themselves to maintain safe care even under increasingly challenging circumstances.
column6:
Here is a paraphrase of the provided text:

Cheyenne Mangold, a medical student, participated in a workshop focused on abortion techniques, her hands betraying a slight tremor as she used a metal instrument to grasp what resembled a cervix. This marked her initial attempt at performing the fundamental steps of an abortion. Instead of a human patient, Mangold practiced on a papaya, a fruit chosen for its anatomical similarities to a woman's reproductive organs.

The workshop, organized by a non-profit organization, aimed to address the deficiency in contraception and abortion training within many US medical programs. It also served as a practical lesson in utilizing a simple kit of essential instruments. This kit, designed for discreet storage and portability, could be crucial for performing safe, clandestine abortions if the procedure becomes illegal nationwide. The papaya, with its distinct shape and internal structure, provided a suitable model for teaching basic abortion techniques.

Mangold was among 60 novice participants from across the country, all embarking on a path to become abortion providers. This group represents a vital resource, particularly given the increasing scarcity of abortion providers in certain regions of the United States. The workshop underscored the commitment of these aspiring medical professionals to ensure access to abortion services, regardless of potential legal restrictions.

Here are the bullet points:

*   The workshop directly addresses the limitations in current medical education by offering comprehensive training on abortion procedures and contraception.

*   The use of papayas as training models enables students to develop crucial skills in a safe and controlled environment, preparing them for real-world scenarios.

*   The program's emphasis on portable instrument kits highlights the organization's proactive approach to ensuring continued access to safe abortion services, even in the face of potential legal challenges.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Quique Setién says he has told Atlético Madrid’s manager Diego Simeone exactly what he thinks of him but Simeone hasn’t told him back. He can guess, though: it doesn’t take a genius. “He might not like what I do, but he has the decency not to say so,” admits the chess-playing, beach football international, former manager of Equatorial Guinea (for one night only) and defender of an aesthetic footballing faith who briefly made Las Palmas the best thing in the league and is now at Real Betis, if maybe not for much longer. “He might go: ‘Bloody hell, this bring-the-ball-out thing, I shit on its mother!’ He’s good enough not to say that, but I’m sure he thinks it.” So is everyone else, and more than before. Because if Simeone never told Setién, on Sunday afternoon he showed him. Really, really showed him. It was easy to imagine him barely suppressing a smirk, winking his way back to the dressing room at the Benito Villamarín and breaking into a giggle as soon as he got through the door, points won and point made. At the same time as he arrived, midfielder Koke stood pitchside. Talking to the telly, Koke’s opening line couldn’t have been clearer: “Betis were spectacular,” he said. “They played very well, they play very nice football.” Antonio Adán, Betis’s goalkeeper, agreed: “The football we played was incredible,” he insisted, “our opponents were truly dominated.” The problem was, a ‘but’ hung in the air and it was a big one.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Entire output should be wrapped in JSON format. You can use markdown ticks such as ```. Do not include keywords ['brain', 'guest', 'kitchen', 'pool', 'president'] in the response.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 It is rare to come across a work of history that so obviously wants to be a literary masterpiece. Roughly the length of War and Peace, The House of Government aims to capture the rise and fall of Bolshevism through a building and its residents, via a study in eschatology – the creation of an apocalyptic cult, its unexpected success, and its equally unexpected failure. It is a dizzying book, a hall of mirrors, panoramic and bizarre, as puzzlingly esoteric and thrillingly fervent as the doctrines it describes. Whether it succeeds in what it tries to do – essentially, to write a totally new history of the Russian revolution, cast in the mould of a teeming historical novel – is questionable. That there is nothing else like it is indisputable. We should begin where the author does not, with the building. Slezkine is best known to non-specialists for The Jewish Century, a lively revisionist history that placed the Soviet Union at the heart of 20th-century Jewish experience, but in the academy he might be better known for his essay The USSR as a Communal Apartment, a pivotal study of Soviet multinationalism through the spatial/architectural metaphor of a crowded, thinly subdivided “kommunalka” flat. The House of Government was another, larger block of flats, completed in 1931, “a place where revolutionaries came home and the revolution came to die”. It was designed in the late 1920s by the architect Boris Iofan for the Soviet elite. Its tenants were decimated in the Great Purge, leading to the later nickname “the House of Preliminary Detention”.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Your response should contain less than 11 sentences. Do not include keywords ['article', 'explanation', 'save', 'stand', 'stranger'] in the response.
column4: This ambitious historical work rivals War and Peace in length, attempting to chronicle Bolshevism's trajectory through one building and its inhabitants. It explores the movement as an apocalyptic cult—its unexpected rise and collapse. The book presents a dizzying, panoramic view with fervent intensity matching the doctrines it examines. While its success at reimagining Russian revolutionary history through a novel-like approach remains questionable, its uniqueness is certain. The author, Slezkine, previously wrote The Jewish Century and a notable essay on Soviet multinationalism using architectural metaphors. The titular House of Government was a residential complex built in 1931 by Boris Iofan for Soviet elites. This building, where "revolutionaries came home and the revolution came to die," later earned a grim nickname after many residents perished in the Great Purge.
column5: It is unusual to encounter a historical work that openly strives to be a literary masterpiece. Roughly as lengthy as War and Peace, The House of Government delves into the rise and fall of Bolshevism by focusing on a building and its occupants, exploring the birth, unexpected success, and downfall of an apocalyptic cult. The work is intricate and labyrinthine, both puzzlingly abstract and intensely passionate like the very doctrines it investigates. However, its success in creating a completely new narrative of the Russian revolution, infused with the energy of a bustling novel, remains debatable. Its uniqueness is indisputable. The focus shifts to the building itself, which the writer leaves for us to consider independently. Slezkine first gained attention among non-specialists with The Jewish Century, a vivid reimagining that positioned the Soviet period at the heart of twentieth-century Jewish experience. In academic circles, he is also recognized for The USSR as a Communal Apartment, a key study of Soviet multinationalism using the metaphor of a congested, partitioned living space. The House of Government, a massive complex finished in 1931 and designed by Boris Iofan for the Soviet elite, later earned the grim nickname “the House of Preliminary Detention” after its residents were decimated in the Great Purge.
column6: Slezkine's "The House of Government," a massive historical work, seeks to portray the story of Bolshevism through a building, its residents, and the study of eschatology. The book, ambitious in scope and novelistic in style, aims to offer a fresh perspective on the Russian Revolution. Its success in this endeavor remains debatable, but its uniqueness is undeniable. Slezkine, known for works like "The Jewish Century" and an insightful essay on Soviet multinationalism using the metaphor of a communal apartment, focuses on a large apartment block completed in 1931 for the Soviet elite. This building, designed by Boris Iofan, became known as "the House of Preliminary Detention" due to the Great Purge.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Theresa May has declared that tackling climate change and reducing its effects on poorer countries is a “moral imperative”, as the Conservative party renewed its push to portray itself as environmentally friendly. The prime minister set out her commitment to dealing with climate change in an article for the Guardian, echoing David Cameron’s 2005 efforts to show the Tories cared about global warming. Ahead of this week’s climate change summit in Paris, May said: “There is a clear moral imperative for developed economies like the UK to help those around the world who stand to lose most from the consequences of manmade climate change.” She described coal as “one of the dirtiest and most destructive ways of generating power” and hailed the “enormous commercial opportunity which the shift to cleaner forms of energy represents”. May’s commitment to the issue of climate change was questioned when she abolished the Department for Energy and Climate Change shortly after taking office last year. Later, her appointee as environment secretary, Andrea Leadsom, had to ask officials whether climate change was real. However, the prime minister insists “tackling climate change and mitigating its effects for the world’s poorest are amongst the most critical challenges the world faces”. At the summit she will announce a £140m boost to funding for poorer communities affected by climate change through deforestation or vulnerability to natural disasters and extreme weather, plus £15m of additional support for reconstruction on Dominica in the Caribbean, which was devastated by Hurricane Maria in September. It comes at a time when Conservative MPs are being asked by party officials to show off their green credentials after internal polling showed the level of concern among younger voters about environmental issues. The party has been alarmed by the backlash against May’s support for a free vote on foxhunting, the omission of a ban on the ivory trade from the manifesto and its lack of support for an amendment that would have recognised in UK law that animals feel pain. They have since backtracked on all three issues.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
# Theresa May Emphasizes Climate Change as a "Moral Imperative"

Prime Minister Theresa May has emphasized that addressing climate change and mitigating its impact on developing nations is a "moral imperative," as part of the Conservative party's renewed efforts to present itself as environmentally conscious. In a Guardian article, May followed in former Prime Minister David Cameron's footsteps by highlighting the Tories' concern about global warming.

Before the Paris climate summit, May stated that wealthy countries like the UK have a clear moral obligation to assist those most vulnerable to climate change effects. She criticized coal as a highly polluting power source while highlighting the economic opportunities in clean energy.

May's environmental commitment had previously been questioned after she dissolved the Department for Energy and Climate Change upon taking office, and when her appointed environment secretary, Andrea Leadsom, reportedly asked officials about the reality of climate change. Despite this, the Prime Minister now asserts that tackling climate change is among the world's most critical challenges.

At the summit, May will announce £140 million in funding for poorer communities affected by climate change, plus an additional £15 million to help rebuild Dominica following Hurricane Maria's devastation.

This environmental push comes as Conservative MPs are being instructed to showcase their green credentials, after party polling revealed significant environmental concerns among younger voters. The party has been working to recover from controversies including May's support for a foxhunting vote, the exclusion of an ivory trade ban from their manifesto, and their opposition to recognizing animal sentience in UK law—positions they have since reversed on all three issues.

P.S. This paraphrase summarizes the key points from the original text while maintaining the core message about Theresa May's climate change stance and the Conservative party's environmental positioning.
column5:
Theresa May has declared that addressing climate change and its impact on poorer nations is not just necessary but a moral duty. Speaking in an article for the Guardian, she reiterated the Conservative party’s renewed effort to cast itself as a champion of environmental issues—a move reminiscent of David Cameron’s earlier attempts to signal the Tories’ concern over global warming back in 2005. With the upcoming climate change summit in Paris in mind, May emphasized that developed countries such as the UK have a clear responsibility to support regions most affected by human-induced climate change. While she criticized coal as an extremely harmful method of power generation and highlighted the vast business potential in shifting to cleaner energy, her commitment to environmental priorities has been questioned. Critics pointed to her decision to dismantle the Department for Energy and Climate Change shortly after taking office and an incident where her environment secretary, Andrea Leadsom, had officials confirm whether climate change was even real. Nonetheless, May maintained that combating climate change and easing its burdens on the world’s poorest communities are among the most crucial challenges global leaders face. In a bid to further this goal, she announced that at the summit the UK would pledge an extra £140 million to support vulnerable communities facing deforestation and severe weather, along with an additional £15 million for renovations in Dominica following the devastation wrought by Hurricane Maria. This initiative comes at a time when Conservative MPs are being encouraged by party officials to demonstrate stronger environmental credentials, especially after internal surveys revealed high levels of concern among younger voters. The party has also been under pressure after controversially supporting a free vote on foxhunting, neglecting to ban the ivory trade in its manifesto, and not backing a motion to legally recognize that animals experience pain—all issues on which it has since reversed its stance.

P.S. If you have any questions about this summary or need further details, feel free to ask!
column6:
Theresa May has asserted that addressing climate change and mitigating its impact on less developed nations is a moral necessity, as the Conservative party tries to project a green image. May emphasized her commitment to tackling climate change in a Guardian article, reminiscent of David Cameron's attempts in 2005 to demonstrate the Conservative party’s concern about global warming. Ahead of the Paris climate change summit, May stated that developed economies like the UK have a moral obligation to assist those most vulnerable to man-made climate change. While describing coal as a polluting energy source, she highlighted the economic potential of transitioning to cleaner energy. May's dedication to climate change was previously questioned when she eliminated the Department for Energy and Climate Change shortly after assuming office. The Prime Minister is now set to announce a £140m increase in funding to assist poorer communities affected by climate change, through deforestation or vulnerability to natural disasters and extreme weather, along with £15m in additional support for reconstruction on Dominica in the Caribbean, which was devastated by Hurricane Maria in September. This comes as Conservative MPs are being encouraged to highlight their environmental credentials after internal polling revealed concerns about environmental issues among younger voters. The Conservative party is looking to improve its environmental image after criticism over May's initial support for a free vote on foxhunting, the lack of a ban on the ivory trade in the manifesto, and insufficient support for animal rights. They have since reversed course on these controversial issues.

P.S. This paraphrase focuses on summarizing the main points of the article's opening, highlighting Theresa May's statements, the context of the Conservative party's environmental image, and the specific actions being taken or announced.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Vladimir Putin has declared mission accomplished for Russian forces in the fight against Islamic State in Syria, as he made a surprise visit to the Russian airbase in the country. “Friends, the motherland is waiting for you,” Putin told the Russian air force detachment based at the Khmeimim airbase during his visit on Monday morning. “You are coming back home with victory.” Earlier this month, the head of the Russian army said Syria had been entirely liberated from Isis forces. Putin said a significant part of Russian forces would be withdrawn from Syria, though scepticism was warranted given that two previous announcements have been met with little noticeable scaling down. This time, however, could be different. Talk of the total defeat of Isis may be premature, but there is no doubt that Russian air power, combined with Syrian forces and Iran-backed Shia militias on the ground, has decisively shifted the balance of power in the long Syrian civil war. President Bashar al-Assad was on the brink of defeat when Russia entered the conflict in 2015. With sustained airstrikes on both moderate rebel groups and extremists, Moscow has helped Assad win back control of much of the country. The Russian and Syrian air forces were accused of brutal bombing tactics, including deliberately targeting civilian infrastructure, which the Russian military has always denied. Assad’s departure from office, long demanded by western powers, is no longer on the immediate agenda.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  There should be 1 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 1 must start with word silly.
column4: Silly display from Vladimir Putin as he visited a Russian airbase in Syria, claiming victory in the fight against ISIS and announcing a withdrawal of forces. The Russian president's declaration echoes earlier statements from the Russian army about Syria being liberated, though previous withdrawal announcements haven't resulted in significant reductions. This time might prove different, as Russian air power alongside Syrian forces and Iran-backed militias has undeniably shifted the balance in Syria's civil war. Since Russia's 2015 intervention, President Assad has regained control of much of the country that he was close to losing, though both Russian and Syrian forces face accusations of deliberately targeting civilian infrastructure - claims Moscow denies. Western powers have seemingly abandoned their previous demand for Assad's removal from office.
column5: silly Vladimir Putin announced a triumphant end to Russian operations against Islamic State in Syria during an unannounced visit to the Khmeimim airbase, where he encouraged the air force detachment with words about their homeland awaiting a victorious return. Earlier in the month, he declared the entire country freed from ISIS, though he mentioned plans to withdraw a large segment of Russian forces—a promise that, given past experiences of minimal withdrawals following similar statements, is met with healthy skepticism. Despite lingering doubts about the complete defeat of ISIS, Moscow's extensive air campaign in tandem with Syrian troops and Iran-backed Shia militias has undeniably altered the course of the civil war that once nearly brought President Bashar al-Assad to his knees in 2015. Accusations persist regarding the deliberate targeting of civilian infrastructure by both Russian and Syrian air forces—charges that the Russian military continues to deny—while any immediate prospects for Assad’s departure from power, long demanded by Western nations, have effectively faded away.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Make this Rather than burning or shredding prunings from winter work in the garden, repurpose them into a dead hedge instead. This will act as a fabulous windbreak, a refuge for wildlife and a way to divide areas of your plot. Bang in stakes or old fence posts in two rows 50cm apart, then slot material in between, with larger branches at the base. As you add material, it will settle over time. Read this Didn’t get anything decent for Christmas? Well, cheer yourself up by pre-ordering a copy of The Book Of Seeds (Ivy Press, £30), by Paul Smith, the former head of Kew’s Millennium Seed Bank. Published in February, it’s a sumptuous guide to 600 of the world’s weirdest and most beautiful species, from the black seed with hair like Donald Trump to pinhead-sized orchid seeds. Plant this Winter-flowering clematis is a wondrous thing: if you can offer it a sunny, sheltered spot, you’ll be rewarded by flushes of blooms from December to February. Clematis cirrhosa ‘Advent Bells’ (3m x 1.5m) and C. cirrhosa var. balearica (2.5m x 1.5m) both have creamy, scented blooms with maroon splashes, while C. cirrhosa ‘Jingle Bells’ has pure white blooms and reaches 5m x 2m.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with at least 170 words. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Finish your response with this exact phrase Is there anything else I can help with?. No other words should follow this phrase.
column4:
"The article suggests an eco-friendly alternative to disposing of garden prunings by creating a 'dead hedge.' Rather than burning or shredding winter garden waste, repurpose these materials between two rows of stakes or fence posts placed 50cm apart. This structure serves multiple purposes: a windbreak, wildlife sanctuary, and garden divider. Start with larger branches at the bottom and continue adding material, knowing it will naturally compress over time.

For gardening enthusiasts disappointed with their Christmas gifts, the article recommends pre-ordering 'The Book Of Seeds' by Paul Smith, former head of Kew's Millennium Seed Bank. Publishing in February at £30, this comprehensive guide showcases 600 remarkable seed species, from Trump-like hairy black seeds to tiny orchid seeds barely visible to the naked eye.

The piece also highlights winter-flowering clematis varieties as garden gems. When planted in sunny, sheltered locations, these climbers produce beautiful blooms from December through February. Options include Clematis cirrhosa 'Advent Bells' and 'var. balearica,' both featuring cream-colored, maroon-splashed flowers, and 'Jingle Bells,' which produces pure white blooms and grows significantly larger than other varieties. Is there anything else I can help with?"
column5:
"Instead of burning or shredding your garden’s winter prunings, consider giving them a second life as a ‘dead hedge.’ This clever technique transforms old branches into a practical windbreak that doubles as a haven for wildlife and a natural divider between different parts of your garden. What you need to do is hammer in stakes or repurpose some old fence posts in two neat rows, positioned 50cm apart. Then, neatly insert the prunings between these rows, making sure to place sturdier branches at the bottom. Gradually, as you add more material, the structure will settle down and establish itself.

If you’re feeling a little down about not receiving a particularly exciting Christmas gift, why not treat yourself? There’s an option to pre-order The Book Of Seeds by Paul Smith (Ivy Press, £30), an authoritative guide published in February. This lavishly produced book explores 600 of the world’s most peculiar and enchanting seed varieties—from the uniquely dark seed with hair resembling Donald Trump’s style to orchid seeds so minute they’re almost invisible. Additionally, you might consider planting a winter-flowering clematis to add vibrancy to your garden; its various forms, like Clemtatis cirrhosa ‘Advent Bells’ and ‘Jingle Bells’, offer both visual appeal and delightful fragrance throughout the cold months. Is there anything else I can help with?"
column6:
"Instead of discarding your winter garden prunings by burning or shredding them, consider transforming them into a dead hedge. This repurposed structure offers multiple benefits, serving as an effective windbreak, a safe haven for wildlife, and a natural divider for different sections of your garden. To construct it, simply drive stakes or old fence posts into the ground, arranging them in two parallel rows approximately 50cm apart. Then, fill the space between the rows with the pruned material, starting with larger branches at the base for stability. Over time, the material will settle and compact, creating a dense and functional hedge.

If you were disappointed with your Christmas gifts, consider treating yourself to a copy of "The Book Of Seeds" by Paul Smith, the former director of Kew's Millennium Seed Bank. This book, published in February, serves as a lavish exploration of 600 of the world's most peculiar and visually stunning plant species, offering insight into everything from seeds with hair like Donald Trump to orchids with pinhead-sized seeds.

For a touch of winter beauty, plant winter-flowering clematis. If you can provide a sunny and sheltered location, you'll be rewarded with fragrant blooms from December to February. Popular choices include Clematis cirrhosa 'Advent Bells' (3m x 1.5m) and C. cirrhosa var. balearica (2.5m x 1.5m), both featuring creamy, scented flowers with maroon splashes. Alternatively, Clematis cirrhosa 'Jingle Bells' offers pure white blossoms and can reach a height of 5m x 2m.

Is there anything else I can help with?"

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Last year, my New Year resolution was to go for a run first thing every morning. It started well: 1 January was a great success. On 2 January, though, I hit snooze and went back to sleep. I tried to get it going again, I really did – I even wore my gym clothes to bed – but nothing worked. This year, I’ve resolved to wean myself off scrolling mindlessly through social media on my phone, but when it comes to making resolutions – or, rather, breaking them – it feels as though there are forces at work far stronger than my willpower. I know I’m not alone in that; if I were, there wouldn’t be nearly 6,000 books on Amazon under the category “self help – habits”, nor so many psychologists researching the subject. So, could they help me keep my resolution this year? Charles Duhigg, the author of The Power of Habit, certainly thinks so. He tells me there is “a ton of research” to show that New Year resolutions are an effective way to make changes: they create a sense of expectation and ceremony, while the link to a particular day helps to fit our experiences into a narrative of before and after, which makes change more likely. “There are people who will decide on 1 January to lose two stone and who will keep it off for the rest of their lives, others who have been smoking two packs a day for over a decade who will decide to quit and who will still not smoke this time next year,” he says.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Finish your response with this exact phrase Any other questions?. No other words should follow this phrase. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
"Last year, I committed to a daily morning run as my resolution. I succeeded on New Year's Day but faltered immediately after, despite trying tactics like sleeping in workout clothes. This year, I'm aiming to reduce mindless social media scrolling, but I recognize that willpower alone often falls short against deeper influences. Many share this struggle, evidenced by thousands of habit-forming self-help books and extensive psychological research. Could experts help me maintain my resolution this time? Charles Duhigg, who wrote 'The Power of Habit,' believes so. He notes substantial research showing New Year's resolutions can effectively drive change because they establish expectations and ceremony. The specific date helps create a before-and-after narrative that facilitates transformation. He points out that some people successfully make permanent life changes on January 1st, like maintaining significant weight loss or quitting long-term smoking habits. Any other questions?

P.S."
column5:
"Last year, I made a New Year’s resolution to start my days with a run. It began promisingly on January 1st, but by January 2nd I couldn’t resist my snooze button and ended up sleeping in. Despite multiple attempts—even donning my workout clothes to bed—my routine never took off. This year, I’ve decided to cut back on the endless scrolling through social media; however, when it comes to making resolutions (or, more accurately, breaking them), it feels like forces far stronger than my own will are at play. I’m not the only one experiencing this, after all; if I were, there wouldn’t be nearly 6,000 books listed as “self-help – habits” on Amazon or countless psychologists studying the subject. So, could these resources actually help me stick to my resolution this year? Charles Duhigg, author of The Power of Habit, certainly believes they can. He explains that a wealth of research supports the idea that New Year’s resolutions are effective in fostering change: they imbue our actions with a sense of expectation and ritual, and linking a resolution to a specific day helps us create a clear narrative of before and after, which in turn makes change more achievable. “Some people decide on January 1st to lose weight and manage to keep it off for life, while others, who may have smoked two packs a day for years, finally manage to quit by this time next year,” he remarks.
Any other questions?
P.S. I hope this paraphrase captures the essence of the original text to your satisfaction."
column6:
"The author recounts a failed New Year's resolution to run every morning, highlighting the common struggle to maintain such commitments. Despite good intentions and even wearing gym clothes to bed, the resolution quickly fell apart. This year, the author aims to reduce social media usage. The widespread availability of self-help resources and psychological research suggests many share this difficulty in sticking to resolutions. Expert Charles Duhigg believes New Year's resolutions can be effective by creating anticipation and a clear before-and-after narrative, citing examples of people successfully making significant, lasting changes. Any other questions?

P.S. This paraphrase summarizes the author's personal experience with failed resolutions, the universality of this struggle, and an expert's optimistic perspective on the potential of New Year's resolutions for lasting change."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Theresa May has been forced to accept more scrutiny of Brexit lawmaking to head off a Tory revolt but is still heading for a showdown over how MPs get to vote on the final deal and whether the date for leaving should be fixed in law. The prime minister made a concession on Monday by agreeing to set up a new committee of MPs to monitor any proposed legal changes as EU legislation is converted into the British statute book. She had been facing a parliamentary defeat over the issue during the debate on the EU withdrawal bill on Tuesday, after a widespread backbench revolt among remain- and leave-supporting MPs. However, the government has not backed down on its intention to fix the day of Brexit as 29 March 2019 or acceded to the demands of soft Brexit Tory MPs who wanted a meaningful vote on the terms of the final deal before that date. One Conservative rebel said May was in trouble over these two issues because there were enough dissatisfied Conservatives combined with Labour, SNP, Liberal Democrat and other opposition MPs to defeat the government. The MP said the government and the rebels were currently in a standoff with neither side prepared to back down. However, government sources were confident May had managed to convince enough of her backbenchers not to defy the whip by indicating that a vote was likely to happen well before the date of leaving and promising a second vote on legislation implementing the EU withdrawal agreement hammered out in Brussels on Friday. The appetite for rebellion among Conservative MPs will become clearer during the two days of debate and voting on the EU withdrawal bill on Tuesday and Wednesday. Up to 25 had threatened to revolt unless May promised more scrutiny over Brexit lawmaking, but No 10’s concessions appear to have allayed concerns among the would-be troublemakers. The government will agree to establish a new committee of MPs to help weed out the overuse of “Henry VIII powers”, which allow ministers to make changes to secondary legislation as it is transposed.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  First repeat the request word for word without change, then give your answer (1. do not say any words or characters before repeating the request; 2. the request you need to repeat does not include this sentence)

Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.

Prime Minister Theresa May has conceded to greater oversight of Brexit legislation to prevent a Conservative Party rebellion, though conflicts remain over the fixed exit date and parliamentary voting on the final agreement. On Monday, she agreed to create a new MP committee to oversee legal modifications as European Union laws are incorporated into British law, avoiding a potential parliamentary defeat during Tuesday's EU withdrawal bill debate. However, the government maintains its position on setting Brexit for March 29, 2019, and has not yielded to demands from moderate Conservative MPs for a meaningful pre-exit vote on the final terms. According to one rebel Conservative, May faces significant opposition as dissatisfied Conservatives could join with opposition parties to defeat the government, with neither side currently willing to compromise. Despite this, government officials believe May has secured enough support by suggesting a vote would occur well before the exit date and promising an additional vote on implementing the withdrawal agreement. The level of rebellion will become evident during debates on Tuesday and Wednesday. The government has appeased potential rebels by agreeing to establish a committee to limit ministers' use of "Henry VIII powers" for changing secondary legislation.

Theresa May has had to accept increased oversight of Brexit lawmaking to avoid an uprising within the Tory party, yet she still faces a potential clash over how MPs will vote on the final agreement and whether the Brexit exit date should be enshrined in law. In a recent compromise, the prime minister agreed to establish a new MPs’ committee tasked with reviewing legal changes as EU rules are incorporated into British law. Previously, she was at risk of losing parliamentary support during the EU withdrawal bill debate, which saw a significant rebellion from backbenchers across both remain and leave camps. Despite this setback, the government remains determined to set Brexit’s date as 29 March 2019 and has not yielded to demands from soft Brexit Conservatives for a full vote on the final deal’s terms prior to that deadline. A dissident Conservative MP warned that May was in a precarious position, given that a coalition of dissatisfied members from Conservatives, Labour, SNP, Liberal Democrats, and other parties could potentially defeat the government. Both sides seem entrenched in a standoff, with neither willing to make concessions. However, government insiders felt confident after indicating that an early vote would occur well before Brexit and promising a second vote on the transposition of the EU withdrawal agreement finalized in Brussels on Friday. The extent of the Conservative rebellion will become clearer over the next two days of debate and voting on the bill. Although up to 25 MPs had signaled their intention to revolt unless there was greater oversight of Brexit lawmaking, the new concessions appear to have appeased those potential dissenters. Additionally, the government has agreed to form a committee to scrutinize the frequent use of “Henry VIII powers,” which allow ministers to alter secondary legislation during the conversion process.
