column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 When you try ballet (surely, on mysemi-recommendation a few months back, you tried ballet?) it is tremendously difficult at first. You look around at all the people who are better than you, and get a vivid snapshot of the intense, technical precision, the practice and the perfectionism involved, which is what makes it work for them and not for you. Well, a Zuu class is the opposite of that. You move like an animal, it’s incredibly hard and everybody else covers way more ground, whether as a sideways gorilla or a crawling bear. But no matter how fast they are, how fit, how unruffled or how well-dressed, everybody looks ridiculous. It’s quite elaborate, the Virgin Active I visit: vast and futuristic, a bit like the spaceship in Wall-E, except there is nobody fat there. The instructors are the capital’s finest, sleek, slick, focused: and also, at least while doing a frog squat, ridiculous. The exercise is exactly what it sounds like: very short bursts of traversing a gym floor on your hands and knees. The frog squat starts much like a regular deep squat – think sitting on an imaginary step a few inches off the floor – except you press your elbows against your knees.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Do not include keywords ['depth', 'escape', 'scheme', 'soft', 'ticket'] in the response. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S Your response must have 1 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Section X, such as:
Section 1
[content of section 1]
Section 2
[content of section 2]
column4:
Section 1
In contrast to ballet, which requires technical precision and practice to look graceful, Zuu classes embrace looking comical while performing animal-inspired movements. Despite being physically demanding, with participants crawling like bears or moving sideways like gorillas, everyone appears amusing regardless of their fitness level or attire. The author describes the Virgin Active gym as spacious and modern, resembling a futuristic vessel, with exceptionally fit clientele. Even the polished instructors can't avoid looking silly when performing exercises like the frog squat. This particular movement involves a low position similar to sitting on an imaginary low stool, but with elbows pressed against knees, while participants travel across the floor using hands and knees in brief, intense intervals.

P.P.S. I've paraphrased the text while maintaining its essence about the Zuu exercise class experience.
column5:
Section 1
Trying ballet can be incredibly challenging at the outset. You quickly notice the expertise of those around you—their precision, thorough practice, and relentless drive for perfection—that makes a world of difference compared to your own tentative moves. In contrast, attending a Zuu session offers a completely different experience. Here, you find yourself moving with a wild, animalistic energy, executing exercises that cause you to feel both awkward and amused as you watch others, whether mimicking a sideways gorilla or a low crawling bear, cover the room. No matter how swift, fit, composed, or stylish they are, everyone appears amusingly out of place. The Virgin Active gym I visited is an expansive, futuristic space, evoking images of a spacecraft reminiscent of that seen in Wall-E, noticeably devoid of any less fit bodies. The instructors, representing the pinnacle of the city’s fitness scene, are sleek and focused—even during moves like the frog squat, which starts off like a deep squat (imagine lowering yourself onto an invisible step) before you press your elbows into your knees.

P.P.S I hope this paraphrase captures the unique charm and humor of the original article.
column6:
Section 1
Ballet is initially challenging, highlighting others' superior skills and demanding precision. In contrast, a Zuu class involves animalistic movements that are equally demanding, yet everyone appears awkward, regardless of fitness level. The Virgin Active gym where the class takes place is large and modern, staffed by highly skilled instructors who also look comical while performing exercises like the frog squat. This exercise consists of brief periods of moving across the floor on hands and knees, starting from a deep squat position with elbows pressed against the knees.

P.P.S. This was a fun exercise!

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Why are people on the left so exercised about how we pay for social care? After all, better-off care home residents who pay their own way are each quietly subsidising to the tune of £12,000 a year those with fewer assets who are funded by councils that negotiate lower fees. What could be more socialist? The truth is that this is an unofficial, unregulated and profoundly unfair tax levied not by the state but, with the state’s connivance, by private care businesses that declare it the only way to make a broken system work. It is also a tax – and a system – unknown to alarming numbers: as a survey published today shows, one in four middle-aged people still think that care and support is free, rising to more than one in three when you include those who aren’t sure. The state of social care shames us all. When the minister responsible, Jackie Doyle-Price, slipped into the Commons one morning last week to administer the last rites to the latest attempt at reform, she was marking 20 years of failure. It was in 1997 that the then Labour health secretary, Frank Dobson, launched a royal commission on the issue with a warning that things “cannot be allowed to continue for much longer”. Since then we have had a dozen white and green papers and plenty of warm words from all sides, but no action – at least none in England, the rest of the UK having gone separate ways. And we shouldn’t expect action any time soon: another green paper setting out proposals is now promised next summer and, as Doyle-Price said, “it is right that we take the time needed to debate the many complex issues and listen to the perspectives of experts and care users”.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['activity', 'alcohol', 'cap', 'minor', 'wheel'] in the response. Your answer must contain exactly 4 bullet points. Use the markdown bullet points such as:
* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2 Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>.
column4:
<<Social Care Funding Crisis>>

* People on the left are deeply concerned about social care funding, despite the fact that wealthier care home residents effectively subsidize those with fewer assets by approximately £12,000 annually, which seems like socialist activity but is actually an unfair system operated by private companies with government approval, not unlike how excessive alcohol consumption is taxed.

* There's a shocking lack of awareness about social care costs, with a recent survey revealing that one in four middle-aged people believe care is free, and even more are uncertain, highlighting the need for a cap on personal contributions to make the system more transparent and fair.

* The current state of social care is deplorable, with minister Jackie Doyle-Price recently announcing the failure of the latest reform attempt, marking two decades of minor progress since 1997 when Labour health secretary Frank Dobson warned that the situation couldn't continue much longer.

* Despite a dozen policy papers and verbal commitments from all political parties, England (unlike other UK regions that have moved forward) is still spinning its wheels with another green paper promised for next summer, as the government claims more time is needed to address complex issues and gather stakeholder input.
column5:
<<poem of joy>>
* The article opens by questioning why those on the left are so insistent on scrutinizing social care funding, pointing out that wealthier residents end up unwittingly supporting others—much like a wheel that drives the continuous activity of these financial transfers.
* It argues that instead of a straightforward state tax, a covert levy is imposed by private care businesses with official backing, creating an arrangement as surprising as finding alcohol served without clear guidelines.
* The piece reveals that better-off care home residents pay about £12,000 a year, effectively placing a de facto cap on costs as they subsidize care for those with fewer assets.
* Despite 20 years of repeated reform attempts and endless policy papers, only a minor promise of further debate remains, leaving a deeply flawed system that still shames public confidence.
column6:
<<Social Care Failures: A System in Crisis>>

*   The current system of social care in England relies on wealthier care home residents effectively subsidizing those with fewer resources, which is seen as an unregulated tax benefitting private care businesses. This system, unknown to many, is viewed as unfair.

*   Decades of inaction and failed reform attempts, dating back to 1997, have plagued social care, despite numerous government papers and promises. The government needs to consider **activity** as it continues to delay implementing meaningful change.

*   Public awareness regarding social care costs remains shockingly low, with a significant portion of the middle-aged population unaware that care and support aren't free. The lack of resources for people with a **minor** condition needing help is appalling.

*   Further delays are anticipated, with another green paper promised next summer, highlighting the government's continued procrastination in addressing the complex issues surrounding social care. There is no **cap** on how long the elderly have to wait for the government to help, and this is a big problem, so people turn to **alcohol** for relief and end up needing a **wheel** chair due to falling.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Forgive me, my darling girl, we are going to make a decision for you. It is a big one, and we can’t wait – it is now or never. We can’t ask you what you want. We can only hope it is the right choice. Right now, you don’t know that you are different, that we inhabit different worlds. I always knew you were special, but I expect all parents feel that way about their children. We didn’t find out you were deaf until you were one, and for that I am grateful. I know early intervention is essential, but if I had found out you were deaf at birth, I would have been terrified. When we found out, there was no sadness, shock, anger or grief. Just a feeling of: “Oh, that makes sense.” Every time someone says to me, “I’m sorry to hear that” in response to the news that you are deaf, I want to say: “Why?
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  There should be 5 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 5 must start with word train.
column4:
The author addresses their deaf daughter, explaining they've made a significant decision for her without her input, hoping it's the right choice. They acknowledge the enormity of this decision and its time-sensitive nature, recognizing that their daughter doesn't yet understand how different her world is from theirs.

Initially, the parent always sensed their child was special, but recognizes this feeling is common among parents. They express gratitude for not discovering their daughter's deafness until she was one year old, acknowledging that while early intervention is crucial, learning this at birth would have been overwhelming.

Upon discovering their daughter was deaf, the parent experienced clarity rather than negative emotions. There was no sadness, shock, anger or grief—just a realization that explained previous observations and behaviors that hadn't quite made sense before.

The parent feels frustrated when people respond with pity to news about their daughter's deafness. When others say "I'm sorry to hear that," the parent wants to question why deafness should be viewed as something sorrowful or unfortunate.

Train of thought aside, the parent seems to view their daughter's deafness not as a tragedy but as simply another aspect of who she is—a difference rather than a deficit. Their protective instinct emerges in how they shield their daughter from society's often misguided perceptions about deafness.
column5:
My dearest daughter, please understand that we must make an important decision on your behalf. This decision is weighty and time-sensitive, leaving us with no room to delay.

We are not in a position to ask what you might want; we can only hope that our choice turns out to be the right one. At this moment, you remain unaware of your differences or the fact that we live in separate worlds.

From the start, I always knew you had a special quality—just as every parent feels about their own child. We only discovered you were deaf when you turned one, and in that sense, I feel grateful.

I recognize that early intervention is crucial. Yet, had I known at birth that you were deaf, fear would have overwhelmed me. Instead of experiencing sadness, shock, or anger when we learned the truth, there was merely an understanding—a simple recognition that everything made sense.

train your understanding to question the automatic sympathy expressed by others when they say, "I’m sorry to hear that." Rather than admitting sorrow, I find myself wondering why such pity is offered.
column6:
We're making a significant decision for our daughter, one we can't postpone. She's too young to understand or participate in the choice. We can only hope we're doing what's best for her.

\
\

She's unaware of the differences between us, the different worlds we inhabit. As parents, we naturally feel she is special.

\
\

Her deafness wasn't discovered until she was a year old, a fortunate delay in our view. Early intervention is important, but knowing from birth would have been frightening.

\
\

Upon learning of her deafness, we didn't experience sadness or any negative emotions. Instead, it was a moment of understanding.

\
\

Train of thought leads to the realization that when people express sympathy for her deafness, I question their sentiment. There is nothing that I would apologize for.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 International affairs Iran nuclear deal, 15 January We should know by mid-January how serious Donald Trump is about seeking a confrontation with Iran over its nuclear programme. The US president refused in October to continue to certify the 2015 multilateral agreement under which Tehran accepted strict curbs on its activities in return for sanctions relief. Trump said that either Congress or US allies should fix the “serious flaws” in the deal, or he would “terminate it. The Senate has since opted out of dealing with the matter, and Washington’s allies have insisted that the 2015 agreement cannot be renegotiated. If Trump refuses to sign a six-monthly presidential waiver due on 15 January, nuclear-related sanctions against Iran will no longer be suspended and the US will be in violation of agreement. The other signatories, including the UK, France, Germany, Russia and China, would then have to decide whether to try to carry on without the US or allow the agreement to collapse. Either way, the Trump administration would have taken a very significant step toward open confrontation. Winter Olympics, 9 February The Winter Olympics in South Korea will be both a festival of sport and a test of the increasingly fragile peace in the region. If the war of words between Trump and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, is defused, the Olympics could offer the opportunity for a thaw. Seoul has suggested a lull in joint manoeuvres with the US during the Games, potentially opening the way for dialogue.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Your response should contain less than 14 sentences. Do not include keywords ['career', 'commission', 'employee', 'training', 'watch'] in the response. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
<<Global Tensions and Winter Games>>

By mid-January, we'll understand Donald Trump's intentions regarding Iran's nuclear program. In October, he declined to certify the 2015 multilateral agreement that restricted Tehran's nuclear activities in exchange for lifting sanctions. Trump demanded that Congress or allies fix the deal's "serious flaws" or he would end it.

The Senate has avoided addressing this issue, while international allies maintain the agreement cannot be renegotiated. If Trump refuses to sign the required waiver on January 15, nuclear-related sanctions against Iran will resume, putting the US in violation of the agreement.

Other signatories including the UK, France, Germany, Russia, and China would then face a difficult choice: proceed without US participation or let the agreement collapse. Either outcome would signal the Trump administration moving toward direct confrontation with Iran.

Meanwhile, the Winter Olympics in South Korea will serve as both an athletic competition and a test of regional stability. If tensions between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un can be reduced, the Games might provide an opportunity for diplomatic progress. Seoul has proposed pausing joint military exercises with the US during the Olympics, potentially creating space for dialogue.

P.S. The original text comes from a Guardian article examining upcoming international events and potential diplomatic flashpoints in early 2018.
column5:
<<Global Crossroads>>

By mid-January, the world may learn how far President Trump is willing to go in confronting Iran over its nuclear program. Back in October, he declined to reauthorize the 2015 agreement that saw Iran accept strict limits on its nuclear activities in exchange for relief from sanctions and insisted that fixes to serious flaws must be made by either Congress or allied nations, or the agreement would be scrapped. Since then, the US Senate has withdrawn from the issue, and key allies maintain that the deal's terms are non-negotiable; failure to sign the required presidential waiver by January 15 would lead to the automatic reinstatement of nuclear-related sanctions, placing the US in breach of its commitments. Meanwhile, the upcoming Winter Olympics in South Korea are set to become a stage not only for athletic competition but also for testing the tenuous regional peace, as a de-escalation in rhetoric between Trump and North Korea's Kim Jong-un might open the door to renewed dialogue, with Seoul hinting at a temporary pause in coordinated military exercises with the US to facilitate this.

P.S. Thank you for engaging with this global update.
column6:
<<Trump's Iran Stance and the Winter Olympics' Geopolitical Significance>>

By mid-January, it will become apparent whether President Trump intends to escalate tensions with Iran regarding its nuclear program. Trump previously declined to certify the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, demanding revisions from Congress or US allies. With the Senate's inaction and allies' refusal to renegotiate, Trump's decision on a crucial waiver due January 15th will determine the agreement's fate. A refusal to sign would reinstate sanctions, violating the deal and potentially leading to its collapse. Other signatories would then face a difficult decision.

Separately, the Winter Olympics in South Korea presents both a sporting event and a crucial moment for regional stability. The Games could offer an opportunity to de-escalate the heated rhetoric between Trump and Kim Jong-un. Seoul has proposed suspending joint military exercises with the US during the Olympics, potentially paving the way for discussions.

P.S. This summary focuses on the potential for conflict and de-escalation in two separate geopolitical scenarios.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 There is a raw kind of beauty to the Tripadvisor review. Let your eye flow down the page and poetry emerges. “Like a plate of blood / I wanted to scream / The worst / The worst / The worst pasty in London.” My boyfriend runs a deli – they had their favourite bad Tripadvisor review printed on tea towels: “When I’m lying on my deathbed, I’ll regret the hour I spent here.” People email him with threats – if you don’t give me and my wife a free meal on Saturday, I’ll post a bad review. Tripadvisor holds plenty of such secrets in its one star reviews, while hiding up at the other end, in the lush grass of its five star hits, are writers paid to push restaurants up the charts. It was an earlier job doing just this, at £10 a go, that gave Vice writer Oobah Butler the idea of going a step further, from creating fake restaurant reviews to creating a fake restaurant. The Shed, reads its website, is “an appointment-only restaurant located in south London”. It’s not. There are vivid photographs of burrata and scallops, and miniature chocolate soufflés and something clever with an egg. Except they’re shaving foam, toilet bleach blocks and a sponge covered in instant coffee. As his friends began posting five star reviews and the Shed climbed Tripadvisor’s ranks, the phone started ringing.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with less than 100 words. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>. There should be 5 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: *** At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
<<The Art of Fake Reviews>>

Tripadvisor reviews can be unexpectedly poetic, with dramatic one-star complaints like "The worst pasty in London" becoming unintentional art. Some business owners even celebrate particularly scathing reviews by printing them on merchandise.

***

Behind the scenes, Tripadvisor harbors extortion attempts, with customers threatening bad reviews unless given free services. Meanwhile, the five-star section often contains paid content designed to boost restaurants' rankings.

***

Writer Oobah Butler, who previously wrote fake reviews for £10 each, decided to take deception further by creating an entirely fictitious restaurant called "The Shed."

***

This supposed "appointment-only" South London establishment featured appetizing photos of gourmet dishes that were actually household items: shaving foam, toilet bleach blocks, and coffee-covered sponges.

***

As Butler's friends posted fake five-star reviews, "The Shed" climbed Tripadvisor's rankings, eventually generating real reservation requests despite being completely imaginary.

P.S. The original article explores how easily review platforms can be manipulated, raising questions about their reliability.
column5:
<<Fake Reviews Unveiled>>

There is a raw, poetic beauty to odd Tripadvisor reviews.

***

A deli owner finds both amusement and threats in harsh, memorable critiques.

***

Inspired by paid reviews, a writer once fake-built a restaurant.

***

The fictitious Shed flaunts culinary images that hide bizarre substitutes.

***

As five-star ratings arrive, the phone begins to ring.

P.S. Fake reviews walk a fine line between art and deceit.
column6:
<<The Fake Restaurant>>

Tripadvisor reviews can be unintentionally poetic, with some hilariously negative and others potentially fabricated.

***

One deli owner even printed a particularly scathing review on tea towels, while others face threats of bad reviews if they don't provide free meals.

***

Vice writer Oobah Butler, who used to write fake positive reviews for money, took it a step further by creating a completely fake restaurant called The Shed.

***

The website featured enticing photos of food, but they were actually made from household items.

***

Despite being non-existent, The Shed climbed Tripadvisor's rankings due to fake five-star reviews, leading to actual reservation requests.

P.S. This article highlights the absurdity and potential manipulation within online review systems.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Although football has long been America’s favorite child among professional sports, there are clear indicators that the ole pigskin is starting to deflate in fans’ eyes. Football fanatics need not panic: polls show it’s still far ahead of both baseball and basketball in popularity. The 2017 NBA finals averaged 20.4m viewers (a 20-year record), which is roughly the same as the NFL’s regular Sunday night audience of 20.3m, and nowhere near the 2016 Super Bowl über-audience of 111m. Based on just those numbers, football is still kicking professional basketball, baseball and hockey through the goal posts. But America can be fickle. And the Magic 8-Ball of our cultural zeitgeist says, “All signs point to the NBA replacing the NFL as the league of America’s future.” This prediction has nothing to do with the athletes themselves, their level of skill, their heart, or their commitment to their sport. Professional athletes are generally the highest expression of what the human body is capable of doing and therefore inspiring to the fans to reach higher and strive harder. In that way, no sport is superior to any other sport. But when it comes to professional sports, some are more inspirational, more exciting and more entertaining to the general public than others and those sports take on a symbolic meaning for Americans. They come to represent our core values.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['bag', 'edge', 'kiss', 'passenger', 'wear'] in the response. Your response should contain at least 13 sentences. Your answer must contain exactly 3 bullet points. Use the markdown bullet points such as:
* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2 At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
# Football's Downward Trend and the Rise of the NBA

Despite football's longstanding position as America's preferred professional sport, there are indications that its popularity is beginning to wane, much like a deflating bag left at the edge of a field. Football enthusiasts shouldn't worry excessively though, as polls confirm it still maintains a significant lead over baseball and basketball in terms of public interest. 

The 2017 NBA finals drew in 20.4 million viewers (a 20-year high), comparable to the NFL's regular Sunday night audience of 20.3 million, though still far from approaching the massive 2016 Super Bowl viewership of 111 million. Based solely on these figures, football continues to dominate professional basketball, baseball, and hockey, carrying its competitors through the goal posts like a passenger on a victory ride.

However, American preferences can shift unexpectedly, similar to how one might suddenly wear a different team's jersey. The cultural indicators suggest the NBA is positioned to replace the NFL as America's premier sports league in the future. 

* This assessment isn't about the athletes themselves - it doesn't question their skill level, passion, or dedication to their sport. Professional athletes generally represent the pinnacle of human physical capability, inspiring fans to reach higher goals, much like a kiss of motivation to pursue excellence.

* When examining professional sports, some inevitably prove more inspirational, thrilling, and entertaining to the general public than others. These sports evolve to embody symbolic meaning for Americans, essentially becoming reflections of our fundamental values and societal preferences.

* The changing landscape of American sports preferences demonstrates how even seemingly unshakeable institutions can face challenges to their dominance. The NFL, while still wearing the crown of America's favorite sport, now stands at the edge of a potentially significant shift in cultural relevance as the NBA gains momentum.

This transition in sports popularity mirrors broader cultural shifts in American society, where traditional preferences are increasingly being questioned and reevaluated. The potential ascendancy of the NBA over the NFL represents more than just changing entertainment preferences - it signals evolving values among American sports consumers.

Professional sports leagues must recognize these shifting trends and adapt accordingly to maintain their relevance. For the NFL, this might mean addressing concerns about player safety and political controversies that have pushed some viewers to the edge of abandoning their viewership.

Meanwhile, the NBA continues to build momentum by connecting with younger demographics and embracing global expansion. The passenger on this journey is the American sports fan, whose changing preferences will ultimately determine which league truly represents America's sporting future.

P.S. The cultural significance of this potential shift extends beyond mere entertainment value, suggesting deeper changes in how Americans identify with professional sports and what values they prioritize in their cultural institutions.
column5:
American football has long been the sport America carries in its cultural bag of cherished traditions.  
Despite its long-held status as the nation’s favorite, recent trends hint that the excitement for football might be slowly deflating among fans.  
Polls now suggest that even though football still maintains the edge over baseball and basketball in popularity, subtle shifts in public interest are emerging.  
Television ratings for events like the NBA finals have shattered long-standing records, showcasing a burst of enthusiasm in other sports arenas.  
In contrast, the NFL continues to draw a robust regular audience, even if its numbers don’t match the astronomical viewership of the Super Bowl.  
That massive Super Bowl audience serves as a kiss of reassurance that football still holds significant cultural prestige.  
However, as America’s audience becomes more discerning, the captivating style of professional basketball grows increasingly appealing.  
This shift indicates that the passenger riding along in the evolution of American sports is ready for a fresh, new experience.  
Every sport, regardless of its field, symbolizes core American values, intertwining athletic prowess with cultural narratives.  
Athletes across these leagues showcase the incredible limits of the human form, a spectacle that inspires millions regardless of the sport they play.  
Some games stand out in their excitement and entertainment value, much like the precise way one might carefully choose what to wear for a special occasion.  
The ongoing transformations in viewer tastes can be encapsulated by three key observations:  
* Viewership records in other sports indicate that the cultural spotlight is gradually shifting.  
* The symbolic narrative of sports merges athletic excellence with broader societal aspirations.  
* Even as football appears to lose a fraction of its longtime allure, another sporting discipline emerges to capture the imagination of millions.  

P.S. Stay tuned as the dynamic journey of American sports continues to surprise and reshape our cultural landscape.
column6:

While American football remains popular, there are signs its grip on the top spot is loosening, like an old bag starting to tear at the seams. It's still more popular than baseball and basketball, but the NBA is gaining ground. The NBA finals viewership almost matched the NFL's regular Sunday night numbers, though the Super Bowl still dwarfs everything, like a giant passenger plane compared to a small car. Football maintains a competitive edge, but America's tastes are prone to change. The cultural indicators suggest the NBA could surpass the NFL in the future. This shift isn't about the athletes themselves, their abilities, or their dedication to their sport; it's not about whether they are willing to kiss the ground for their teams.

The quality of athleticism is consistent across sports, they all inspire us to push our limits. One might say, any athlete would want to wear the winner's medal. However, some professional sports resonate more deeply with the public than others.

*   These sports become symbolic, representing our core values, the values in our bag.
*   This creates an edge in their level of popularity and how they are received.
*   These sports must ensure that no passenger is left behind.

This isn't about inherent superiority; it's about entertainment, inspiration, and cultural relevance.

P.S. This analysis suggests a possible transition in America's sports preferences, emphasizing the importance of entertainment value and cultural resonance.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The career of Keith Chegwin, who has died aged 60, is characterised by having presented both one of the most popular children’s TV shows in history and a contender for the medium’s most notorious adult entertainment. Viewers saw the best of him in Multi-Coloured Swap Shop (BBC1, 1976-82) and its successor, Saturday Superstore (1982-87), on which Chegwin became an honorary big brother to several generations of goggle-eyed British children, through his cheeky grin and giggle, high-pitched Liverpudlian-accented enthusiasm, and psychedelic knitwear. His presentational worst occurred when Chegwin threw off the novelty sweaters – and, indeed, all clothing except a hat – to front the naturist show Naked (Channel 5, 2000), described by a parliamentarian at the time as the “most disgusting programme ever shown” on British TV. But, while he should be remembered for the work he did with his jolly jumpers on, it was hard not to feel some sympathy for Chegwin, even in his most desperate televisual enterprises. This was due to a natural likability. Only the most sympathetic TV presenters earn nicknames from viewers, and, just as Bruce Forsyth transmuted into “Brucie”, Chegwin rapidly and indelibly became “Cheggers”. That identity was cemented by the title of the third huge success of his children’s career: the music-based gameshow, Cheggers Plays Pop (BBC1, 1978-86), which extended his presenting empire to weekdays. In less prosperous times, though, audiences also admired the impressive and affecting determination with which Cheggers, in the three decades after his Saturday morning career ended, tried to reinvent himself, often against considerable odds. In addition to a common problem for children’s presenters – becoming too old to maintain the required fantasy-sibling dynamic – Chegwin suffered health problems, including alcoholism. Apart from the established presenter-rehab route of reality TV – appearing on Dancing on Ice, Celebrity Big Brother and Celebrity MasterChef – Chegwin also offered ironic spins on his showbiz rise and fall in 10 projects, including Ricky Gervais’s Extras and Life’s Too Short, and Kill Keith (2011), an improbable comedy-horror Brit film spoof of Tarantino’s Kill Bill.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Your answer must contain exactly 5 bullet points. Use the markdown bullet points such as:
* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2
column4:
"* Keith Chegwin, who died at 60, was known for hosting both beloved children's television programs and controversial adult content.
* He gained popularity through shows like Multi-Coloured Swap Shop and Saturday Superstore, where his cheerful personality and colorful sweaters made him a favorite among young British viewers.
* His reputation suffered when he appeared nude on the naturist show Naked in 2000, which was harshly criticized as "the most disgusting program ever shown" on British TV.
* Despite his missteps, Chegwin (affectionately known as "Cheggers") maintained audience sympathy due to his likable nature and determination to reinvent himself despite challenges including alcoholism.
* After his children's TV career ended, he appeared on reality shows like Celebrity Big Brother and made self-deprecating appearances in comedy projects including Ricky Gervais's shows and the film spoof Kill Keith."
column5:
" 
* Keith Chegwin’s career spanned from hosting iconic children’s TV shows to taking on adult entertainment challenges. 
* He charmed generations with hits like Multi-Coloured Swap Shop and Saturday Superstore, where his warm, cheeky personality made him a beloved figure. 
* His venture into adult programming peaked with a naturist show, Naked, which sparked controversy and negative reactions from some quarters. 
* Known affectionately as “Cheggers” by the public—a nickname cemented much like Bruce Forsyth’s “Brucie”—he earned enduring sympathy through his natural likability. 
* Despite battling issues such as aging and alcoholism, Chegwin continually reinvented himself over three decades with diverse projects in both reality TV and scripted comedy. 
"
column6:
"Keith Chegwin, who passed away at 60, had a diverse career marked by both immense popularity and notoriety.

*   He achieved fame as a beloved figure on children's TV shows like Multi-Coloured Swap Shop and Saturday Superstore, endearing himself to young viewers with his cheerful personality and distinctive style.
*   However, he also faced criticism for hosting the controversial naturist show Naked, which drew strong negative reactions.
*   Despite the highs and lows, Chegwin maintained a likable persona that earned him the affectionate nickname "Cheggers" and led to the success of Cheggers Plays Pop.
*   Following his children's television success, Chegwin encountered challenges and health issues, including alcoholism, but persistently sought to reinvent himself in various projects.
*   He participated in reality TV shows and made ironic appearances in comedy series, demonstrating resilience in navigating the ups and downs of his career."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 ‘I am still not sure if myself and my children will be landlocked’ Kate, 49, project manager, has lived in the Netherlands for 17 years. I am still not sure whether myself and my children will be landlocked or will be able to live our lives as we did before the vote. I only hope we can continue to plan and have the same aspirations as any other EU citizen in the EU. My children will probably get Dutch citizenship: I think that is a good thing as they would have so many rights and benefits as EU citizens. I have worked so much abroad, and always in a very international environment, though I’m not fluent in Dutch yet. We were thinking of moving near Maastricht in a few years and it was definitely on our radar to move to Germany as I have to cross borders to Germany, Poland and France all the time for my work. Now we don’t know if we can do that. Will I need to get visas? The latest agreement means nothing has changed; we British citizens feel the least cared for group in the negotiations as nobody cares about us – not like the EU cares for EU nationals. ‘We are being ignored’ Ken Wood, 68, retired, has lived in France for four years.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  There should be 3 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: *** Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Answer with at least 343 words. Do not include keywords ['loss', 'object', 'phrase', 'solid', 'whole'] in the response. Your response must have 3 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with SECTION X, such as:
SECTION 1
[content of section 1]
SECTION 2
[content of section 2]
column4:
"SECTION 1
Kate, a 49-year-old project manager who has resided in the Netherlands for 17 years, expresses uncertainty about her future mobility and that of her children following the Brexit vote. She wonders whether they will remain restricted to one country or maintain the freedom of movement they previously enjoyed. Kate hopes they can continue planning their lives with the same opportunities as other European Union citizens within the EU community.

***

SECTION 2
Regarding her children, Kate believes obtaining Dutch citizenship would benefit them considerably, granting them numerous rights and advantages as EU citizens. Despite working extensively abroad in international environments, Kate acknowledges she hasn't yet mastered the Dutch language. The family had considered relocating near Maastricht eventually and potentially moving to Germany, as her work frequently requires travel across borders to Germany, Poland, and France. However, these plans now hang in the balance due to Brexit-related uncertainties.

***

SECTION 3
Kate worries about potential visa requirements for cross-border work and travel. She expresses disappointment with the latest agreement, feeling it resolves nothing substantial. British citizens abroad, in her view, constitute the most neglected group in the Brexit negotiations, receiving inadequate attention compared to how the European Union protects its nationals. The article then transitions to another expatriate's perspective - Ken Wood, a 68-year-old retiree who has lived in France for four years, who similarly feels British expatriates are being overlooked in the ongoing discussions between the UK and EU. These testimonials highlight the personal anxieties and practical concerns facing British nationals residing in EU countries during this period of political transition and uncertainty about their legal status and rights."
column5:
"SECTION 1
Kate, aged 49, works as a project manager and has established her life in the Netherlands over the past 17 years. In recent reflections, she admitted that the outcome of political changes has left her feeling uncertain about how her family's future will unfold. She remains unsure if she and her children will find themselves confined within a more restricted environment, or if they will continue to enjoy the same freedoms and lifestyle they knew before the recent vote. As her children might acquire citizenship in their new home, she recognizes that this change could enhance the rights and myriad benefits available to residents of the region. Even though she has spent much of her career working abroad and flourishing in varied international settings, her limited command of the local language adds another layer of complexity to her situation. Her concerns extend beyond just linguistic integration, as she faces broader questions about how these political shifts will impact everyday life, family stability, and the ability to plan for the future with confidence.

***
SECTION 2
Prior to the vote, Kate and her family contemplated relocating to an area near Maastricht, a plan that underscored the importance of mobility and access to neighboring countries. For her, work frequently involves crossing borders to Germany, Poland, and France, making international travel an integral part of her professional routine. However, the advent of the new agreements now casts a shadow over these future plans. She wonders if upcoming changes in regulations might necessitate additional travel permits or visas, altering the ease with which she previously journeyed between countries. This potential requirement raises worries about the possibility of facing new bureaucratic hurdles that could complicate not only employment logistics but also personal aspirations and cross-border relationships. The adjustments stirred by the evolving political climate are forcing her to reexamine plans that once seemed secure, causing significant apprehension about the level of personal freedom that may be diminished in the near future.

***
SECTION 3
Beyond her own predicament, Kate’s situation mirrors a wider sentiment of neglect felt by many citizens from her homeland living across European borders. Recently finalized arrangements have done little to alleviate the disquiet among the British community, who are beginning to sense that they are not being given the same consideration as their counterparts within the European Union. This sentiment of being overlooked is echoed in the experiences of others, such as Ken Wood, a retired individual who has resided in France for several years. Ken expressed that, amid all the negotiations, British nationals seemingly occupy a peripheral position, a view that intensifies the collective anxiety about diminished rights and guarantees. As both Kate and Ken grapple with these emerging uncertainties, a broader narrative is unfolding—one in which longstanding international ties are being questioned, and where the security of familiar cross-border lifestyles is being undermined by evolving political realities. This confluence of personal and communal apprehensions underscores the depth of change and the enduring desire for reassurance that every citizen will continue to enjoy the privileges they have long taken for granted."
column6:
"SECTION 1

Kate, a 49-year-old project manager who has called the Netherlands home for 17 years, expresses deep uncertainty about her and her children's future. She questions whether they will be effectively trapped, unable to move and live as freely as they did before a recent vote, likely referring to Brexit. Her greatest desire is that they can maintain their ability to plan and pursue their aspirations, mirroring the opportunities available to other EU citizens within the Union. She mentions her children's potential acquisition of Dutch citizenship, seeing it as a positive step that would grant them numerous rights and advantages as EU citizens. Kate's professional background is heavily international, involving frequent work across borders in Germany, Poland, and France, despite her still developing fluency in Dutch. The family had entertained the idea of relocating near Maastricht in the near future and even considered a move to Germany, given the constant need for cross-border travel in her job.

***
SECTION 2

However, the current situation has cast significant doubt on these plans. Kate wonders about the potential necessity of obtaining visas for her work-related travel, emphasizing the disruption and uncertainty that has been created. She conveys a sense of frustration and disappointment with the latest agreement, suggesting it has failed to address the concerns of British citizens living abroad. She feels that British citizens have been overlooked and neglected in the negotiations, contrasting this with the care and attention given to EU nationals by the European Union. This sentiment highlights a perceived disparity in how different groups have been treated throughout the process, leading to feelings of marginalization and a lack of support for British expats. She expresses the feeling of being ignored.

***
SECTION 3

The article then shifts to another perspective with Ken Wood, a 68-year-old retiree who has been living in France for four years. He echos Kate's sense of British citizens being disregarded and neglected. Although the provided text abruptly introduces Ken's perspective and doesn't elaborate on the specifics of his concerns, it establishes a pattern of anxiety and discontent among British citizens residing within the European Union. The joint statements suggest a widespread feeling of being overlooked during crucial negotiations and a questioning of their future prospects living abroad, underlining the broader implications and uncertainties stemming from recent political decisions. Both individuals communicate a strong feeling of being unsupported by their own government, leaving them to navigate a changed landscape with concerns about freedom of movement and future opportunities."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 A couple of years ago, Hayley Squires decided to get a new tattoo. “I’d been romantically involved with somebody for a little while, and it had driven me a bit nuts,” she explains. “Then he was out of my life, and it was coming up to my birthday.” She kept thinking up various symbols and signs that might mean something, but nothing rang true. Then she remembered this line. It’s a quote from A Midsummer Night’s Dream, and it’s tucked nearly underneath the crook of her left arm. It reads: “And though she be but little, she is fierce.” Squires, 29, is both of those things. She’s also direct, talks a lot, and quickly, and is a genuine laugh, despite her talent for plumbing the depths of despair in the Ken Loach film, I, Daniel Blake. When we meet, she’s wearing a Tupac T-shirt – one of four Tupac T-shirts she owns – and a pilot’s jacket, which she bought because it looked a bit like the one Tom Hardy wears in the film Dunkirk. “Because I’ve got a bit of an obsession with him, I walked into Topshop and saw it and thought: ‘Ahhh!’” she says, smiling. She’s about to star in The Miniaturist, a gorgeous three-part BBC adaptation of Jessie Burton’s bestselling novel, though she almost decided not to go for it at all.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with less than 167 words. Do not include keywords ['career', 'country', 'information', 'secretary', 'shower'] in the response.
column4:
Hayley Squires recently got a tattoo with a quote from Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" reading "And though she be but little, she is fierce," which she chose after ending a relationship that had troubled her. At 29, Squires embodies this phrase—small in stature but powerful in presence. She's talkative, straightforward, and genuinely funny, despite her notable role portraying hardship in Ken Loach's "I, Daniel Blake." 

When interviewed, she wore one of her four Tupac shirts and a jacket resembling Tom Hardy's in "Dunkirk," purchased due to her fondness for the actor. Squires is set to appear in the BBC's three-part adaptation of "The Miniaturist," based on Jessie Burton's popular novel, though she nearly passed on the opportunity.
column5: A few years ago, Hayley Squires chose to get a tattoo after a brief, tumultuous relationship ended just before her birthday. Unsure of what symbol to use, she remembered a line from A Midsummer Night’s Dream—“And though she be but little, she is fierce”—and had it inked near her left arm. At 29, Squires lives up to that description with her direct and animated manner. Despite her knack for exploring darker themes, as seen in her role in Ken Loach’s I, Daniel Blake, she remains warm and engaging. When we meet, she sports one of her four Tupac T-shirts alongside a pilot’s jacket that caught her eye because it echoed Tom Hardy’s style in Dunkirk. Although she nearly opted out, she is now set to star in The Miniaturist, the stunning three-part BBC adaptation of Jessie Burton’s bestselling novel.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Generally, the trick in storytelling is to make the reader forget about the building blocks of language, and concentrate on the larger structure. As a reader, you might subconsciously pick up on rhythms. Sometimes you will notice a sharp phrase or two, a rhetorical flourish, perhaps the odd bit of alliteration and assonance. If you let him, Will Self might bash you over the head with his dictionary. But, on the whole, it’s what the words do that matters, rather than what they are. You focus on the broader picture, not the pigment and paint, even if you can also appreciate the colours. Attrib. is different. Right from the start, Williams isolates and focuses on single words. Here’s the opening: “The plot of this is not and will not be obvious.
-------

column4:
Section 1
Typically, effective storytelling helps readers forget about language basics and engage with the broader narrative. Readers might unconsciously notice rhythms or occasionally appreciate clever phrases, rhetorical techniques, or sound patterns.

Section 2
Some authors like Will Self overtly display their vocabulary prowess. However, generally what matters most is the function of words rather than their individual presence - readers focus on the complete picture instead of individual brushstrokes.

Section 3
The work titled "Attrib." takes a different approach. Williams deliberately draws attention to individual words from the beginning of the text.

Section 4
This is exemplified in the opening statement: "The plot of this is not and will not be obvious," which immediately signals a departure from conventional narrative structure and highlights the importance of specific linguistic elements.
column5:
Section 1
Storytelling works best when readers overlook the mechanics of language and embrace the overall design of the narrative.

Section 2
Often, you subconsciously pick up on subtle rhythms and occasional striking phrases, noticing clever uses of sound and style within the text.

Section 3
While some writers, like Will Self, might overwhelm you with an expansive vocabulary, ultimately the impact of the expressions matters more than the individual words.

Section 4
In contrast, Williams takes a different approach by honing in on each word's role. He begins his piece by declaring, “The plot of this is not and will not be obvious,” setting a tone that focuses on the power of select language elements.
column6:
Section 1
Good storytelling usually involves the reader becoming immersed in the narrative and overlooking the individual components of language. Readers might notice subtle aspects like rhythms or striking phrases, but the overall effect is more important than the specific linguistic techniques used.

Section 2
However, the writer Will Self seemingly disregards this principle. He may overwhelm the reader with elaborate vocabulary and complex language.

Section 3
The emphasis should be on the impact of the words in conveying the story's message, rather than simply admiring the words themselves, like appreciating a painting's subject matter over the paint.

Section 4
Attrib. takes a different approach by isolating and emphasizing individual words from the very beginning. The article quotes the book's opening line to illustrate this point, indicating a non-traditional and perhaps challenging narrative style.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Sports Personality of the Year 2017 6.45pm, BBC One SPOTY used to be an annual TV highlight, back when it was a recap of actual footage rather than the meddlesome mess of graphics, spoken-word doggerel and laboured comedy bits it is today. Hard to predict a winner; might Mo Farah finally get the nod? Or Anthony Joshua for his epic defeat of Wladimir Klitschko? Is Adam Peaty high-profile enough to take the award? It’s presented by Logan, Lineker and Balding from Liverpool’s Echo Arena. David Stubbs Coastal Railways with Julie Walters 8pm, Channel 4 National treasure, rugged coastline, nostalgic mode of transport: this feels like something created by a basic commissioning algorithm. But before you can say “Joanna Lumley’s Paddlesteamer Vacation”, Walters has explained her mission (picturesque railway journeys; cute social history) and charmed the locals. Tonight’s trip to Liverpool takes in Tywyn in mid Wales, the inspiration for Thomas the Tank Engine, and Europe’s fastest zipwire. John Robinson The Apprentice 9pm, BBC One It hasn’t been a vintage year for Lord Sugar and friends, but there are definitely worse ways to spend a Sunday night than watching this year’s final. With consistent candidates Michaela, Elizabeth and Joanna all sent packing following last week’s interviews, James and Sarah are an unexpected final two.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Do not include keywords ['championship', 'imagination', 'player', 'scene', 'today'] in the response. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>.
column4:
<<Television Highlights Review>>

The Sport Personality of the Year 2017 broadcast begins at 6:45pm on BBC One. SPOTY was once a television milestone featuring actual footage, but has transformed into a cluttered production with excessive graphics, poetry, and forced humor segments. The winner remains uncertain - perhaps Mo Farah will finally receive recognition, or Anthony Joshua following his victory over Wladimir Klitschko, or swimming star Adam Peaty might claim the award despite lower public profile. Logan, Lineker and Balding host from Liverpool's Echo Arena.

At 8pm on Channel 4, "Coastal Railways with Julie Walters" premieres. While seemingly formulaic in concept (beloved actress, shoreline vistas, nostalgic transportation), Walters quickly establishes her engaging approach to exploring rail journeys and local histories. Her Liverpool-bound episode includes stops at Tywyn in Wales, which inspired the famous tank engine children's stories, plus an exciting zipwire adventure.

BBC One presents The Apprentice finale at 9pm. Though not an exceptional season overall, the conclusion offers worthwhile Sunday evening viewing. With strong contenders Michaela, Elizabeth and Joanna eliminated after interviews, James and Sarah form a surprising final pairing.
column5:
<<Evening Broadcast Roundup>>

The long-established Sports Personality award show has changed from a simple recap of actual footage into an event filled with pronounced graphics, spoken verses, and carefully crafted humor. Speculation abounds as to whether Mo Farah might finally gain recognition, if Anthony Joshua will be honored after his significant victory over Wladimir Klitschko, or if rising star Adam Peaty will capture sufficient public appeal. The festivities are led by Logan, Lineker, and Balding at Liverpool’s Echo Arena.

At 8pm on Channel 4, Julie Walters takes viewers on a nostalgic journey with Coastal Railways. Emphasizing a blend of treasured heritage, rugged coastlines, and historical transport, the program offers more than just a picturesque railway ride. With a swift introduction of her mission—featuring charming trips, a touch of social history, and witty interactions with local residents—Walters reveals stops including Tywyn in mid Wales, the inspiration for Thomas the Tank Engine, and even a ride on Europe’s fastest zipwire.

Following that, a 9pm BBC One show presents the final installment of a well-known business-themed reality contest. While it hasn’t been an exceptional year for Lord Sugar and his team, the program remains an engaging way to spend an evening as previous contenders Michaela, Elizabeth, and Joanna have been eliminated, leaving an unforeseen final duo in James and Sarah.
column6:
<<TV Highlights Tonight>>

The annual BBC sports award show, once a genuine highlight featuring actual highlights, is burdened by excessive graphics and forced comedy. The winner is anyone's guess, with Mo Farah, Anthony Joshua, and Adam Peaty as possible contenders. Elsewhere, Julie Walters explores scenic railways and local history on Channel 4. Finally, the business competition "The Apprentice" concludes on BBC One, with an unexpected final two.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Police investigating a suspected arson attack that killed three people in Salford have arrested four men and a woman. Four fire engines were called to a street in Walkden, Greater Manchester, after the fire broke out at the house at about 5am on Monday. A 14-year-old girl was declared dead at the scene and an eight-year-old boy and seven-year-old girl died in hospital. A three-year-old girl was said to be in a critical condition on Monday afternoon, while a woman, 35, who is understood to be the children’s mother, was in a serious condition. Police are yet to formally identify the victims, but the mother and her 14-year-old daughter have been named locally as Michelle Pearson, 35, and Demi Pearson. Drew Povey, the headteacher at Harrop Fold school in Little Hulton, where Demi was a pupil, said: “We are devastated at the tragic loss of life today in our community. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family involved.” Greater Manchester police said they had arrested three men, aged 23, 20 and 18, and a 20-year-old woman on Monday on suspicion of murder. A 24-year-old man is also being questioned in custody on suspicion of assisting an offender. Police had previously urged a murder suspect to hand himself in, saying there was “an active manhunt” to find an individual who they did not name. “All I would say is he knows who he is and he should give himself up immediately,” said Ch Supt Wayne Miller.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with at least 352 words. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. There should be 2 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: ***
column4:
"Police have detained five individuals following a suspected deliberate fire that resulted in three fatalities in Salford. Emergency services responded with four fire engines to a home in Walkden, Greater Manchester, where a blaze erupted around 5am on Monday. The tragic incident claimed the life of a 14-year-old girl at the scene, while an eight-year-old boy and a seven-year-old girl later succumbed to their injuries in hospital. Additionally, a three-year-old girl remains in critical condition as of Monday afternoon, and a 35-year-old woman, believed to be the mother of the children, is seriously injured. Although formal identification of the victims is pending, community members have identified the mother and her teenage daughter as Michelle Pearson, 35, and Demi Pearson, respectively. The headteacher at Demi's school, Harrop Fold in Little Hulton, Drew Povey, expressed profound sorrow over the incident, stating the school community is devastated by this tragic loss of life and extending thoughts and prayers to the affected family. Greater Manchester Police confirmed they have taken three men into custody—aged 23, 20, and 18—along with a 20-year-old woman, all on suspicion of murder. A fifth individual, a 24-year-old man, is being questioned regarding potential assistance provided to an offender.

***

Prior to these arrests, law enforcement had issued a public appeal for a murder suspect to surrender, indicating there was 'an active manhunt' underway for an individual they did not specifically name. Chief Superintendent Wayne Miller emphasized the urgency of the situation, stating directly to the suspect that 'he knows who he is and he should give himself up immediately.' The investigation into this apparent arson attack continues as authorities work to determine the circumstances surrounding this devastating fire that has left a community in mourning. The incident has deeply affected the local area, with the school community particularly shaken by the loss of one of their students. As medical teams continue to treat the surviving victims, including the critically injured three-year-old, police are pursuing all leads to establish the full details of this apparent criminal act that has resulted in multiple fatalities and left two others fighting for their lives. The case highlights the devastating impact of suspected arson and has prompted a swift and significant police response to bring those responsible to justice."
column5:
"Police in Salford are investigating what appears to be an intentional fire that resulted in the loss of three lives. The blaze broke out early on Monday at a residential property in Walkden, Greater Manchester, prompting the dispatch of four fire engines to the scene around 5am. Initial reports indicate that a 14-year-old girl tragically died on the spot, while an eight-year-old boy and a seven-year-old girl succumbed to their injuries later in hospital. Additionally, a three-year-old girl remains in critical condition as of Monday afternoon. Among those affected, a 35-year-old woman—allegedly the mother of the children—is reported to be in a serious state, although authorities have yet to make a formal identification of the victims. Locally, this woman and her daughter, the 14-year-old, have been named Michelle Pearson, 35, and Demi Pearson, respectively. Drew Povey, headteacher at Harrop Fold School in Little Hulton where Demi attended, expressed deep sorrow, stating, 'We are devastated at the tragic loss of life today in our community. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family involved.' The incident has sent shockwaves throughout the area, and the community's grief is compounded by the abrupt and violent nature of the event.

*** 

In the midst of this unfolding tragedy, Greater Manchester police have acted swiftly by arresting four individuals on suspicion of murder—three men aged 23, 20, and 18, and a 20-year-old woman—while a 24-year-old man has been detained for questioning on charges relating to aiding an offender. This series of arrests comes after a previous call for a suspect to surrender, with the police emphasizing that there remains an active search for another individual whose identity has not been released. A senior officer, Ch Supt Wayne Miller, was quoted as urging, 'All I would say is he knows who he is and he should give himself up immediately,' as part of the ongoing investigation. The case, believed to involve a premeditated arson, now draws significant public and media attention as investigators compile evidence and piece together the sequence of events that led to the catastrophic fire. The grim incident, which inflicted such grievous losses on a local family, has stirred a complex mixture of grief and outrage, highlighting the urgency for a thorough investigation. Community members continue to express their anguish and disbelief while calls for justice escalate as the details of this tragic event are gradually revealed."
column6:
"Police have apprehended four men and one woman in connection with a suspected arson attack in Salford that resulted in the deaths of three individuals. The incident occurred on a street in Walkden, Greater Manchester, prompting a response from four fire engines following a house fire that ignited around 5 am on Monday. Tragically, a 14-year-old girl was pronounced dead at the scene, while an eight-year-old boy and a seven-year-old girl succumbed to their injuries in the hospital. As of Monday afternoon, a three-year-old girl remained in critical condition, and a 35-year-old woman, believed to be the children's mother, was in serious condition. Formal identification of the victims is pending, but local sources have identified the mother and her 14-year-old daughter as Michelle Pearson, 35, and Demi Pearson, respectively. The headteacher of Harrop Fold school in Little Hulton, Drew Povey, where Demi was a student, expressed the community's devastation at the tragic loss of life, extending thoughts and prayers to the affected family. Greater Manchester Police confirmed the arrest of three men, aged 23, 20, and 18, along with a 20-year-old woman, all on suspicion of murder. Additionally, a 24-year-old man is being questioned while in custody on suspicion of assisting an offender. Prior to these arrests, the police had publicly appealed to a murder suspect to surrender, indicating an active search for an unnamed individual. Chief Superintendent Wayne Miller directly addressed the suspect, stating that the individual knows their identity and should immediately turn themselves in to authorities. The swift action by the police underscores the seriousness with which they are treating this case, signaling a determined effort to bring those responsible for this horrific crime to justice.

***

The details emerging from this tragic event paint a grim picture of loss and devastation. The fire, which erupted in the early hours of the morning, has claimed the lives of three young children, leaving a community reeling in shock and grief. The critical condition of the three-year-old girl and the serious condition of their mother further amplify the heartbreak surrounding this incident. The local community has already begun to identify the victims, demonstrating the profound impact this tragedy has had on those who knew the family. The swift response of the Greater Manchester Police, resulting in multiple arrests, indicates a concerted effort to hold those responsible accountable for their actions. The police's previous appeal to a suspect to surrender highlights the urgency and determination with which they are pursuing justice for the victims and their family. The headteacher's statement reflects the deep sense of sorrow felt within the school community, emphasizing the lasting impact this tragedy will undoubtedly have on students, staff, and the wider community. As the investigation unfolds, further details are expected to emerge, shedding more light on the circumstances surrounding this devastating incident. The focus remains on ensuring justice for the victims and providing support to the affected family and community during this incredibly difficult time."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, is to launch plans for an opt-out system of organ donation, asking people to overcome their “fatal reluctance” to discuss the issue with family and friends. Under the plans, everybody in England would be presumed to be happy to donate their organs on their death, unless they have signed up to a register stating that they do not want that to happen. In practice, however, it is unlikely that organs would be taken against the wishes of the family. The government’s ambition to change the NHS organ donation programme was announced by Theresa May in her Conservative party conference speech in October. Last year, she said, “500 people died because a suitable organ was not available. And there are 6,500 on the transplant list today.” NHS Blood and Transplant’s figures show that 1,100 families in the UK decided not to allow organ donation because they were unsure, or did not know whether their relatives would have wanted to donate an organ or not. “Every day, three people die for want of a transplant, which is why our historic plans to transform the way organ donation works are so important. We want as many people as possible to have their say as we shape the new opt-out process,” said Hunt. “As well as changing the law, we also need to change the conversation – it can be a difficult subject to broach, but overcoming this fatal reluctance to talk openly about our wishes is key to saving many more lives in the future.” The consultation will ask three questions: how much say should families have in their deceased relative’s decision to donate their organs? When would exemptions to “opt-out” be needed, and what safeguards will be necessary?
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with less than 271 words. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Your answer must contain exactly 5 bullet points. Use the markdown bullet points such as:
* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2 Include keywords ['alcohol', 'expert', 'structure', 'tell', 'white'] in the response.
column4:
"* Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt is introducing an opt-out organ donation system, urging people to overcome their hesitation to discuss this important topic with loved ones. This new structure would automatically consider all English citizens as organ donors unless they explicitly register their objection.

* Despite this change, it remains unlikely that organs would be harvested against family wishes. Prime Minister Theresa May announced this policy shift at the Conservative party conference last October, citing that 500 people died last year due to organ unavailability while 6,500 remain on transplant lists.

* NHS Blood and Transplant reports that 1,100 UK families prevented organ donation because they were uncertain about their deceased relative's wishes. Hunt emphasized that three people die daily waiting for transplants, making these changes vital to tell more patients they have a chance at life.

* The health expert stressed that beyond legal changes, cultural conversation must shift around organ donation. Overcoming what he called a 'fatal reluctance' to discuss these wishes openly is essential to saving more lives in the future.

* The government consultation will address three key areas: the level of family influence in deceased relatives' organ donation decisions, necessary exemptions to the opt-out system, and what safeguards should be implemented. This represents a significant shift from the current system, as white papers on the topic have previously indicated."
column5:
" 
* The health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, is set to introduce an opt-out system for organ donation in England, aiming to shift the conversation about organ donation, a change that even an expert in policy reform would call transformative.
* Under the new proposal, everyone is presumed willing to donate unless they opt out, though in practice families retain considerable influence, which some critics warn could sometimes make it difficult to tell the true wishes of the deceased.
* Senior figures, including former Prime Minister Theresa May, highlighted that 500 people died last year due to the shortage of organs, with 6,500 individuals currently awaiting transplants – a stark reminder that even initiatives as universally accepted as white-light reforms can face entrenched challenges.
* Figures from NHS Blood and Transplant indicate that around 1,100 families declined donation because they were uncertain about their relatives' wishes, underscoring the need to change the societal conversation and to overcome a deep-seated reluctance in discussing sensitive topics.
* The upcoming consultation will address questions about the appropriate level of family involvement, when exemptions to the opt-out model might be necessary, and what safeguards to implement; this will include rethinking the structure of the current system, even considering how occasions involving alcohol might serve as informal opportunities to discuss such personal decisions.
"
column6:
"Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt is initiating an opt-out organ donation system in England, urging people to discuss their wishes with loved ones, even if it is a difficult white conversation.

*   The proposal presumes consent for organ donation upon death unless individuals register their objection. However, family wishes will likely be respected in practice. The government's aim to overhaul the NHS organ donation process follows Theresa May's announcement, motivated by the fact that 500 people died last year due to organ shortages, and 6,500 remain on transplant lists.

*   NHS data reveals 1,100 families declined organ donation due to uncertainty about their relative's wishes. Hunt emphasizes the importance of transforming organ donation to save lives, as three people die daily waiting for transplants. Experts in the structure of the donation process will be consulted.

*   Hunt stresses that in addition to changing the legal framework, open dialogue about organ donation preferences is crucial. People can tell their families their desires, and in doing so, save lives.

*   The consultation will address the extent of family influence in deceased relatives' donation decisions. It will also consider necessary safeguards and exemptions to the opt-out system.

*   While unrelated to organ donation, remember excessive alcohol consumption can damage organs, underscoring the importance of health and responsible choices."

-------
 Name: Bee Movie Age: 10 years old. Appearance: insect-based, feature-length animation. Do you mean Antz? No. Antz is about ants. This one’s about bees. What about A Bug’s Life? That’s another insect-based animation, but it’s not this one. I don’t think I’ve ever seen Bee Movie. You’re not alone.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Finish your response with this exact phrase Is there anything else I can help with?. No other words should follow this phrase. Your response must have 3 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with SECTION X, such as:
SECTION 1
[content of section 1]
SECTION 2

column4:
SECTION 1
The Bee Movie, a decade-old animated film featuring insects, is distinct from other similar animations such as Antz (which focuses on ants) and A Bug's Life (which is about various insects). Many people haven't watched Bee Movie, so if you haven't seen it, you're not alone in that experience.

SECTION 2
This animated feature film about bees has reached its 10th anniversary. It should not be confused with other insect-themed animations like Antz or A Bug's Life, which are completely different movies. The text suggests that Bee Movie wasn't particularly popular, as many people haven't viewed it.

SECTION 3
The Guardian article discusses Bee Movie, an animated film about bees that is now 10 years old. It clarifies that this movie is different from other insect animations like Antz (about ants) and A Bug's Life. The article acknowledges that many people haven't seen Bee Movie, suggesting it wasn't as widely watched as other animated features. Is there anything else I can help with?
