column4:
This article presents a trainer form table tracking the performance of 35 major jumps racing stables over the past fortnight. The percentages indicate each trainer's win strike-rate, with the number of runners shown in brackets. Currently, trainers named Nicky are performing well, with Nicky Richards leading at 30% despite having fewer runners than others. The Henderson, Tizzard, and Skelton stables continue to show good form, while Donald McCain is experiencing his best performance in years. In contrast, previously successful trainer Harry Fry has dropped significantly in the rankings, though this is expected to be temporary. The article notes that Philip Hobbs and Neil Mulholland's yards are underperforming, and Venetia Williams hasn't reached her usual form yet, though January typically brings her better results. The column concludes with a tip for Archie Stevens at the Southwell races, offered at 7-2 odds.

Is there anything else I can help with?
column5: Our updated trainer form table shows Nicky Richards leading with a 30% win rate over 10 runs, followed by Nicky Henderson with 27% from 33 outings, and then Dan Skelton at 25% from 40 races. Every Monday during the core jumps season, we track how 35 prominent jumps stables are performing; the percentages indicate their win rates for the past fortnight and the numbers in brackets represent the total runners in that period. It’s an apt moment for someone named Nicky to stand out. Richards, who had been struggling, now tops the list after clinching three hurdle wins in the past 10 days from just a few races. On the flip side, Harry Fry, who had been enjoying strong form, has fallen considerably, recording only one win with Overtown Express out of 13 runs—though he’s expected to bounce back soon. The stables managed by Henderson, Tizzard, and Skelton are maintaining their strong performances, while Donald McCain is experiencing his most successful period in years. Meanwhile, the typically formidable yards of Hobbs and Mulholland have been notably quiet. Venetia Williams hasn’t quite hit her mark yet, despite a couple of near misses, but January often turns out well for her. Today’s tips are provided by John O’Hara, although his current nap has made him absent from the picks. In his place, Archie Stevens (priced at 3.30) could be the standout choice on the Southwell card at odds of 7-2. Is there anything else I can help with?

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The rather unexpected allusion by the prime minister this week in a speech to the Business Council of Australia to the government’s pursuit of further income tax cuts is not one that should be treated with too much respect until he also talks about how to pay for them. With the return to surplus built on income tax revenue, any income tax cuts are unlikely to come before the next decade without either increases in other taxes or big cuts to government services. Amid the usual “free markets are great” rah-rah that the prime minister doled out to the Business Council of Australia on Monday night, Malcolm Turnbull also slipped in a line on income tax cuts, noting that he was: “Actively working with the treasurer and all my cabinet colleagues to ease the burden on middle-income Australians, while also meeting our commitment to return the budget to surplus.” This was a bit of a surprise given the current state of the budget is such that the government is projecting that a return to surplus only in 2020-21and that net debt at that point will total $366bn, or 17.6% of GDP. Even in the best of times, promising income tax cuts as the budget is in deficit is a courageous position to take for a political party that likes to prides itself on “budget responsibility”.It is even more courageous when the path back to surplus is built on a foundation of income tax revenue. Individual’s income tax has always been the biggest tax in the budget. During the mining-boom years it declined slightly in importance as company tax exploded in value from 3.3% of GDP in 1998-99 to5.3% of GDP in 2005-06. But in the current financial year, individual income tax accounts for just over half of all tax revenue. Now that in itself is a bit of a problem (the IMF and OECD have made calls for Australia to lessen its reliance on income tax) but it is a bigger problem for Turnbull and his call for tax cuts while also “meeting our commitment to return the budget to surplus.” The issue it that of the extra $88.1bn in tax revenue the government hopes to gain between now and 2020-21, $48.5bn of it is to come from individual income tax. This means that income tax is actually bearing a greater burden of the increase in tax than would be expected. Income tax makes up 50.6% of total tax revenue, but accounts for 55% of the increase in tax revenue between now and 2020-21.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with at least 311 words. Do not include keywords ['metal', 'painting', 'peak', 'player', 'she'] in the response. There should be 5 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 1 must start with word technology.
column4:
Technology has not been the focus of Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's recent speech to the Business Council of Australia, where he surprisingly mentioned potential income tax cuts. This statement should be approached with caution until he provides details on how these cuts would be funded. Given that the projected return to budget surplus relies heavily on income tax revenue, implementing tax reductions before the next decade would likely require either increasing other taxes or significantly reducing government services.

During his address filled with typical free-market rhetoric, Turnbull mentioned working with the treasurer and cabinet to reduce the burden on middle-income Australians while still achieving the government's commitment to restore budget surplus. This announcement comes as somewhat unexpected considering the current fiscal situation, where surplus is only projected for 2020-21, at which point net debt is expected to reach $366 billion, representing 17.6% of GDP.

Promising tax cuts while operating in deficit appears to be a bold move for a political party that emphasizes budget responsibility. This becomes even more challenging when considering that the pathway back to surplus is fundamentally dependent on income tax revenue. Individual income tax has consistently been the largest source of taxation in the budget. While its relative importance decreased slightly during the mining boom years as corporate tax revenues grew substantially, individual income tax currently accounts for more than half of all tax revenue collected.

This heavy reliance on income tax presents a significant challenge, one that both the International Monetary Fund and Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development have advised Australia to address. However, this dependency creates an even greater dilemma for Turnbull's simultaneous commitments to tax reduction and budget restoration. The government's fiscal projections reveal that of the additional $88.1 billion in tax revenue anticipated between now and 2020-21, $48.5 billion is expected to come from individual income taxes.

The implications of these figures demonstrate that income tax is shouldering a disproportionate burden of the projected revenue increase. While income tax constitutes 50.6% of total tax revenue, it accounts for approximately 55% of the expected growth in tax revenue through 2020-21. This imbalance makes Turnbull's dual commitment to tax cuts and budget surplus particularly difficult to reconcile without significant adjustments to other aspects of fiscal policy.
column5:
technology marks an unexpected twist in the prime minister’s recent address to the Business Council of Australia, where he hinted at additional income tax cuts without offering corresponding details on how these reductions would be financed. In his speech, he referenced the government’s ongoing efforts to lighten the tax load on middle-income earners while maintaining a commitment to eventually achieve a budget surplus. This early mention of tax cuts appears somewhat premature given the current fiscal landscape, which is heavily reliant on individual income tax revenues. The government's strategy for reaching a surplus involves an intricate balance; any reduction in income tax would necessitate either a rise in other forms of taxation or significant cuts in public services, thus provoking critical debates among political commentators.

The announcement took many observers by surprise, as it came against the backdrop of a projected timetable that sees a return to a surplus only in the fiscal years 2020-21. With national debt reaching substantial figures relative to the country’s gross domestic product, the forward-looking promise of tax cuts seems audacious. The commentary draws attention to the irony of advocating for tax reductions at a time when balancing the budget is already a formidable challenge. The prime minister’s remarks were delivered amidst his standard celebration of free markets and economic optimism, yet his words also exposed an inherent contradiction in planning additional tax cuts while relying on income tax revenue as a cornerstone of fiscal consolidation.

Examining the budget’s details reveals that individual income tax contributes slightly more than half of the overall tax revenue. Yet, it also accounts for a disproportionate share of the planned revenue increase—an extra $88.1 billion—with a significant fraction stemming directly from personal income tax collections. This dynamic raises concerns about the sustainability of such a fiscal framework. Financial experts and international organizations have previously suggested that the nation should consider diversifying its revenue sources to mitigate the risks associated with overreliance on this single tax.

The prime minister’s approach represents a politically bold maneuver, trying to walk a tightrope between fiscal responsibility and tax relief for middle-income households. This approach has ignited a debate among economists and political analysts alike, highlighting the delicate balance required in managing national finances in a volatile economic climate. While the agenda is rooted in the objective of fostering a stronger, surplus-based fiscal policy, doubts remain about the long-term feasibilities of such strategies given the current fiscal architecture.
column6:
Technology and innovation are not included in this particular piece; thus, the analysis focuses on the economic and political aspects. The Prime Minister's recent remarks to the Business Council of Australia regarding the government's intention to pursue further income tax reductions should be viewed with skepticism unless accompanied by a clear explanation of how these cuts will be financed. Given that the projected return to a budget surplus relies heavily on income tax revenue, any reduction in income tax is unlikely to occur before the next decade without either raising other taxes or significantly reducing government services. The Prime Minister's statement is particularly surprising given the current budgetary situation, which projects a return to surplus only in 2020-21 and a net debt of $366 billion, or 17.6% of GDP, at that time.

Even under favorable economic conditions, promising income tax cuts while the budget is in deficit is a bold move for a political group that prides itself on "budget responsibility." This is especially true when the path back to surplus depends on income tax revenue. Individual income tax has historically been the largest source of tax revenue in the budget. While its importance declined somewhat during the mining boom as corporate tax revenues surged, individual income tax currently accounts for just over half of all tax revenue.

This dependence on income tax is problematic, as international organizations like the IMF and OECD have urged Australia to diversify its tax base. However, it poses an even greater challenge for the Prime Minister's call for tax cuts while simultaneously aiming to "meet our commitment to return the budget to surplus." The issue lies in the fact that of the additional $88.1 billion in tax revenue that the government expects to generate between now and 2020-21, $48.5 billion is projected to come from individual income tax.

This indicates that income tax is bearing a disproportionate share of the increase in tax revenue. While income tax constitutes 50.6% of total tax revenue, it accounts for 55% of the increase in tax revenue between now and 2020-21. The government's reliance on increased income tax revenue to achieve a budget surplus makes the prospect of income tax cuts before 2020-21 difficult to believe.

The article expresses doubt that the government is able to cut taxes because the surplus is based on income tax revenue. Cutting income taxes would likely be contradictory to the government's aims to return the budget to surplus. A surplus would be even more unattainable should income tax revenue lessen, which is the main source of the budget increasing.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Olivia Mead, a millionaire heiress whose list of expenses included a $1.2m crystal-encrusted grand piano and $2,000 annual upkeep of her pet axolotl, has had her inheritance cut from $25m to $6.14m following an appeal from her deceased father’s estate. The 22-year-old is the youngest daughter of the Perth mining billionaire Michael Wright, whose father, Peter Wright, was a business associate of the late Lang Hancock. He was worth $2.7bn upon his death in 2012. Mead was not publicly connected to the powerful Wright family or her half-siblings until she challenged her father’s will, arguing that it did not adequately provide for her needs. She had originally been bequeathed a $3m trust fund that she would be able to access once she turned 30, provided she did not become an alcoholic, be convicted of a crime, knowingly have “any involvement or association whatsoever” with illicit drugs, or convert to any faith other than “traditional” Christian options. The supreme court found in Mead’s favour in early 2015 and increased her inheritance eight-fold to $25m, an amount the court’s master, Craig Sanderson, said would “not fall outside of the reasonable expectation of most members of the community”. It was more than the $20m Mead had demanded, which her lawyers had revised down to $12m before the surprise decision. Wright’s estate, acting on behalf of Wright’s much older children from his second marriage, filed an appeal one month later. On Wednesday, the full bench of the Western Australian supreme court set aside Sanderson’s orders, ruling that while Sanderson was correct to say that Mead had been inadequately provided for in the original will: “The exercise of his discretion to order that provision be made for the respondent in the sum of $25m was flawed.” In a lengthy written judgment, the court found that Sanderson made a number of “material errors” in calculating the size of Mead’s inheritance, saying the focus should have been on what constituted “proper maintenance” and that the initial finding that Mead was “honest” and “not a gold-digger” were not relevant. “The capital sum should be sufficient to enable the respondent to purchase a reasonably substantial house with part of the capital sum and to invest the balance so that she will receive a reasonably substantial annuity for the remainder of her life,” the appeal court’s president, Michael Buss, said.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Answer with less than 240 words. Do not include keywords ['commission', 'focus', 'gate', 'order', 'room'] in the response. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
Olivia Mead, a 22-year-old heiress who listed expenses including a $1.2m crystal-covered piano and $2,000 yearly maintenance for her pet axolotl, has had her inheritance reduced from $25m to $6.14m after an appeal by her late father's estate. She is the youngest daughter of Perth mining billionaire Michael Wright, whose father was business partners with Lang Hancock. Wright was worth $2.7bn when he died in 2012.

Mead wasn't publicly linked to the Wright family until she contested her father's will, claiming it didn't adequately provide for her needs. She had initially been left a $3m trust fund accessible at age 30, with conditions that she avoid alcoholism, criminal convictions, drug associations, and non-traditional Christian faiths.

In early 2015, the supreme court ruled in Mead's favor, increasing her inheritance to $25m. However, Wright's estate, representing his older children, appealed. The Western Australian supreme court has now ruled that while Mead was inadequately provided for originally, the $25m award was excessive.

The court determined that several errors were made in calculating the inheritance, stating that the amount should allow her to purchase a substantial house and invest the remainder to produce a lifetime annuity.

P.S. The court emphasized that the central consideration should have been what constituted "proper maintenance" rather than character assessments.
column5:
Olivia Mead, a millionaire heiress known for lavish spending—such as paying $1.2m for a crystal-encrusted grand piano and $2,000 annually for her pet axolotl—saw her $25m inheritance slashed to $6.14m after her deceased father’s estate appealed the initial decision. At 22, she is the youngest daughter of Perth mining magnate Michael Wright, whose father, Peter Wright, was a business associate of the late mining figure, Lang Hancock. Previously, Mead had not been widely linked with the influential Wright family until she challenged her father’s will, arguing it did not sufficiently support her. Originally, she was set to receive a $3m trust fund accessible at 30, provided she avoided alcoholism, criminal behavior, involvement with illicit drugs, or conversion from traditional Christianity. In early 2015, a supreme court judgement sided with her, multiplying her share eight-fold to $25m—a sum described as within what many in the community might reasonably expect. Despite her team revising her claim downward from $20m to $12m, an appeal by the estate representing her older half-siblings led the full bench of the Western Australian supreme court to later overturn that decision, stating that calculating her provision as $25m was flawed. The written judgement emphasized that she needed enough capital to purchase a substantial home and invest so as to secure a reliable lifetime annuity.

P.S. Let me know if you need any further adjustments or clarifications.
column6:
Olivia Mead, heiress to a mining fortune and known for extravagant requests like a $1.2 million crystal piano and lavish axolotl care, saw her inheritance significantly reduced from $25 million to $6.14 million after an appeal. Mead, the youngest daughter of the late billionaire Michael Wright, challenged her father's will, arguing it didn't adequately meet her needs. Initially, she was to receive a $3 million trust fund with strict conditions relating to lifestyle choices.

A court initially sided with Mead, increasing her inheritance substantially. However, Wright's estate, representing his older children, appealed. The court overturned the prior decision, stating that while Mead was initially under-provided for, the initial sum awarded was excessive.

The appeal judges determined that the previous court had made errors in calculating Mead's inheritance, emphasizing that the correct measurement was the "proper maintenance" that she was owed. They instructed that her inheritance should allow her to buy a sizable home and generate a substantial, ongoing income.

P.S. The court's decision highlights the complexities of inheritance disputes and the legal interpretations of "adequate provision."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The former top official for internet censorship in China, who travelled to the heart of Silicon Valley to promote China’s vision for the web, is under investigation for corruption, the Communist party’s anti-corruption agency has said. Lu Wei was the powerful and flamboyant head of the Cyberspace Administration of China from 2014 until June 2016 and he came to personify China’s model for internet control. He travelled to the United States, meeting with the CEOs of Facebook, Amazon and Apple, and held court when tech titans visited China. Lu was being investigated for “serious disciplinary violations”, a euphemism for graft, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection said on its website. He stepped down from running the Cyberspace Administration in 2016, leading to rumours he had fallen out of favour. President Xi Jinping has led a far reaching anti-corruption drive since coming to power five years ago and has said graft is the paramount threat to the ruling Communist party. The campaign has seen nearly 1.4m party members punished and Xi vowed to continue rooting out graft during his second five-year term which began last month. Critics say elements of the anti-graft campaign have been used to eliminate Xi’s enemies and root out political factions that oppose him. Lu is the most prominent official to fall since Xi’s second term began and the anti-corruption agency pointed to Lu’s case as a sign the drive will continue. “Lu Wei being investigated by the organisation is the best proof of this determination and resolve,” the agency said in a commentary.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Entire output should be wrapped in JSON format. You can use markdown ticks such as ```.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 As the Queensland election campaign heads into its final stretch, Labor’s main message of “chaos” under a Liberal National party-One Nation government has been damaged by one of its own, while Adani continues to cause headaches for both major parties. With Queenslanders preparing to head to the polls on Saturday, no clear victor has emerged, leaving both the LNP and Labor scrambling to bed down seats. Labor has consolidated its message to one line – “a clear choice” – as it seeks to highlight what it says will be the “cuts and chaos” under a Tim Nicholls-led government. The LNP leader has said he is willing to work with One Nation in the event of a hung parliament. But the Labor campaign is reeling from the damage done by one of its own MPs, the former police minister Jo-Ann Miller, who sought out the One Nation leader, Pauline Hanson, in front of the media on Tuesday, embracing her and presenting her with a gift for her new grandson. Media at the event have reported that One Nation was aware of Miller’s intentions. Miller and Labor have maintained it was a coincidence of the campaign and a “common decency” to present a gift for a new baby. But the friendly meeting may have damaged Labor’s attempts to paint itself as standing apart from Hanson’s party, which is predicted to take seats across north and central Queensland, as well as some outer-urban electorates in the south-east. “The real issue here is what is going to happen in three days’ time, on Saturday,” Annastacia Palaszczuk said from Bundaberg on Wednesday, moments before her team attempted to keep her away from signs declaring: “It’ll be grim under Tim.” The placement of “grim” seemed a little too close for comfort for those focused on optics. “That is the real fundamental issue and it is about a choice, it is fundamentally about a clear choice,” she said.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. There should be 4 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 4 must start with word hall.

However, the Labor campaign was blindsided when former police minister Jo-Ann Miller publicly embraced One Nation leader Pauline Hanson and gave her a gift for her grandson, an encounter that media reports suggest was planned by One Nation.

While Miller and Labor have dismissed the interaction as coincidental and simply showing 'common decency,' the friendly meeting potentially undermines Labor's strategy of distancing itself from Hanson's party, which is expected to win seats across Queensland's north, central regions, and some outer-urban areas in the southeast. Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk tried to refocus attention on the upcoming election while in Bundaberg Wednesday, even as her team attempted to shield her from awkwardly placed campaign signs reading 'It'll be grim under Tim.'

Hall marks of the campaign's final stretch include Palaszczuk's emphasis on the 'fundamental issue' of voters having a 'clear choice' when they head to the polls, while both major parties continue to navigate challenges including the Adani controversy and the potential influence of One Nation in the election's outcome."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Forget Bennelong or New England, the battle for Australia’s favourite bird is on. As the inaugural bird of the year poll launched on Monday, the nation’s celebrities, political leaders and media outlets immediately began their campaigns. The divisive Australian white ibis leapt to a commanding lead and the powerful owl, with the aid of Russian hackers, rose up the ranks. But in a crowded field of diverse native birds, endorsements rang out for nearly all contenders. The federal opposition leader, Bill Shorten, cut his ties to the magpie, currently coming second, and set his sights on the emu (whose image sits above Parliament House), in what must surely be an early election pitch. The Greens leader, Richard Di Natale, chose the Gang-gang cockatoo, another Canberra icon (“Incredible plumage but it sounds like a rusty door”), while fellow senator Nick McKim picked the wedge-tailed eagle, and Janet Rice, the hooded plover. Scott Ludlam, 2017’s first dual citizen, again displayed divided loyalties. The former senator endorsed the Carnaby’s black cockatoo at 3.45pm on Monday, but by 8.30pm, he suddenly declared himself “Team Bin Chicken”. Malcolm Turnbull, the prime minister, was asked but did not respond, opening himself up to a string of less-than-flattering replies. But the government’s leader of the house, Christopher Pyne, did tell ABC Radio’s Patricia Karvelas he liked the black-faced spoonbill.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>. Do not include keywords ['anywhere', 'argument', 'flight', 'laugh', 'quiet'] in the response. There should be 1 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: ***
column4:
<<Australia's Bird of the Year Poll Ignites Passionate Responses>>

As the first-ever Bird of the Year competition commenced in Australia on Monday, an enthusiastic wave of endorsements emerged from celebrities, politicians, and media outlets. The Australian white ibis quickly secured a substantial lead, while the powerful owl climbed the rankings amid jokes about Russian interference. The contest revealed diverse preferences among political figures: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten abandoned the magpie to support the emu, which appears on Parliament House; Greens Leader Richard Di Natale championed the Gang-gang cockatoo; Senator Nick McKim advocated for the wedge-tailed eagle; and Janet Rice backed the hooded plover. Former Senator Scott Ludlam showed changing allegiances, initially supporting the Carnaby's black cockatoo before switching to "Team Bin Chicken." Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's silence prompted numerous unfavorable responses, while House Leader Christopher Pyne expressed his fondness for the black-faced spoonbill.
column5:
<<Australian Icon Showdown>>

***
The race to crown Australia’s top bird has sparked a frenzy among celebrities, political figures, and media following the launch of the first-ever bird of the year poll on Monday. While the controversial Australian white ibis surged ahead and the powerful owl benefited from unexpected online boosts, nearly every native species found support from various endorsers. Opposition leader Bill Shorten shifted his backing from the magpie—once a strong contender—to the emu, echoing political ambitions, whereas Greens leader Richard Di Natale rallied for the Gang-gang cockatoo. Senator Nick McKim and Janet Rice put forth the wedge-tailed eagle and the hooded plover, respectively, and Scott Ludlam, known for his dual citizenship, demonstrated shifting loyalties by initially supporting the Carnaby’s black cockatoo before later aligning himself with "Team Bin Chicken." Although Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull remained silent amid mounting criticism, the government's leader in the house, Christopher Pyne, expressed a fondness for the black-faced spoonbill.
column6:
<<Australian Bird of the Year Competition Heats Up>>

Australia has launched its first "Bird of the Year" poll, sparking immediate and enthusiastic campaigning from prominent figures. The Australian white ibis quickly took the lead, while the powerful owl gained traction with suspected external influence. Politicians and media personalities are publicly endorsing their favorite native birds from across the nation. Opposition Leader Bill Shorten switched his support from the magpie to the emu, and Greens leader Richard Di Natale is backing the Gang-gang cockatoo. Other senators are championing birds such as the wedge-tailed eagle and the hooded plover. Former senator Scott Ludlam even switched allegiances mid-campaign, embracing the ibis. While the Prime Minister remained silent, another government member voiced his preference for the black-faced spoonbill.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Top story: ‘Hard job but he makes it harder for himself’ Hello – it’s Warren Murray with the news in a nutshell. Philip Hammond is in a “make or break” position as he delivers the autumn budget today, senior Tories have warned. The chancellor of the exchequer is under pressure from Brexiters to make leaving the EU sound like a good thing, while winning back voters by improving housing affordability, boosting education, increasing NHS funding and easing the public sector pay freeze. Rafael Behr sums up Hammond’s predicament: “He must build houses, but not in anyone’s backyard. He must raise revenue, but not from taxes.” Hammond’s March budget was overshadowed by a failed attempt to increase national insurance for the self-employed; and this time around, saying on national television that there are no unemployed people in Britain has not helped his cause. “He’s got a hard job but the way he deals with it makes it harder for himself,” said one Conservative source. Here are the five charts you need to see before the red briefcase creaks open a bit after midday. * * * The reluctant idol – David Cassidy, star of The Partridge Family, has died aged 67. Cassidy had been hospitalised in Florida for several days after kidney and liver failure. He became a teenage hearthrob after being cast as Keith Partridge in the 1970s sitcom about a fictitious band.
-------
Please paraphrase based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['author', 'feeling', 'seat', 'she', 'talk'] in the response. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Finish your response with this exact phrase Is there anything else I can help with?. No other words should follow this phrase. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Australia’s richest woman, mining magnate Gina Rinehart, has awarded Barnaby Joyce $40,000 for services to the agricultural sector. At a gala dinner in Canberra on Tuesday, Rinehart gave the inaugural agricultural and related industries award to Joyce, describing him as a “champion of the industry”. Labor immediately took aim at the award, with the opposition leader, Bill Shorten, labelling it a “$40,000 cash present”. Joyce has said he will refuse the cash. The Nationals leader, a close personal friend of Rinehart and former agriculture and water minister, is currently battling for his political life in the New England byelection after the high court ruled him ineligible to sit in parliament because of dual New Zealand citizenship. Rinehart thanked Joyce for taking “time out of your campaigning schedule to come here – to be here for the industry you love and support”. “What a great voice for Australian agriculture,” she said. “The agricultural industry is fortunate to have had such a dedicated, understanding and enthusiastic minister – one with years of first-hand experience – a real Aussie country boy and boy, do we hope you return.” Footage of the event shows Joyce stood up to accept the award and giant cheque, before modestly exclaiming “hooley dooley – rightio”. In addition to being the chair of Hancock Prospecting, Rinehart has extensive agricultural holdings and is the part owner of the $386m S Kidman and Co cattle company which has leasehold over 80,000 sq km in Australia’s north. At a press conference on Wednesday, Shorten asked: “Why is a mining millionaire giving a Turnbull government minister a $40,000 cash present?
-------

Mining tycoon Gina Rinehart, Australia's wealthiest woman, presented Barnaby Joyce with a $40,000 commission for his contributions to agriculture at a Canberra event. While Rinehart praised Joyce as a champion of food production, Opposition Leader Bill Shorten criticized the award as a "cash present," leading to a split in public opinion. Joyce, the Nationals leader currently facing election challenges after losing his parliamentary seat due to citizenship issues, appeared somewhat crazy excited when accepting the oversized white check, though he later stated he would decline the money. Rinehart, who owns substantial agricultural interests including a major cattle company, expressed hope for Joyce's political comeback while Shorten questioned the propriety of such a generous gift to a government minister.

At a Canberra gala, Australia’s wealthiest woman and mining tycoon Gina Rinehart presented Barnaby Joyce with a $40,000 award for his contributions to agriculture, calling him an industry champion. Despite the honor being framed as a commission celebrating genuine support for the sector, opposition leader Bill Shorten was quick to criticize it as a crazy "$40,000 cash present." Joyce, a former agriculture and water minister and a close friend of Rinehart, has already announced he will refuse the money while he fights to secure his political future amid a high court ruling over dual New Zealand citizenship that split opinion. Rinehart expressed gratitude for his presence at the event—even taking time from campaigning to endorse the country’s food producers—describing him as a true, down-to-earth representative of Australian agriculture, with hopes that his return will restore the white-knuckled integrity of the industry.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Here is a portrait of the primatologist as a young woman. Using footage only recently rediscovered in the National Geographic archive, octogenarian Jane Goodall recollects her first field study of chimpanzees in the wild in Tanzania. This was the 1960s, and Goodall was a 26-year-old typist with no academic training. Yet on that trip she made a great leap in scientific research by observing chimps making and using tools. Goodall says that it was her mother who built her self-esteem when she was growing up – encouraging her to see beyond the expectations that a nice, middle-class girl from Bournemouth should get married and start a family. Instead, she dreamed of living with animals in the jungle like Tarzan. There are more than 40 documentaries about Goodall. What makes this one – directed by Brett Morgen, who made The Kid Stays in the Picture – essential, is Goodall’s reflective mood and the wondrous 16mm archive footage shot by Hugo van Lawick, the great wildlife photographer National Geographic sent to film her in Tanzania. The pair fell in love and married (though in the end, Goodall’s happy-ever-after was with the chimps not Van Lawick). One of his miraculous shots, of the annual great migration from Serengeti – a medley of animals gathered together like some majestic parliament of beasts – drew a gasp of wonder from a gentleman sitting behind me.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Entire output should be wrapped in JSON format. You can use markdown ticks such as ```. Do not include keywords ['area', 'attack', 'moment', 'money', 'name'] in the response.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 What does it mean when dancers express emotion on stage? Do they bring real-life experiences to those highly choreographed moments when they’re leaping with ecstasy, racked by grief or, as in the climax of Stravinsky’s Rite of Spring, dancing themselves to death on behalf of a fearful, threatened community? These are some of the questions posed by Goat, the raw, funny and occasionally searing new piece of dance theatre that Ben Duke has made for Rambert. The setting is an ambiguous space that is part meeting hall, part performance arena, and its “characters” are a group of dancers and musicians who have gathered to enact some kind of cathartic emotional ritual. Miguel Altunaga plays a reporter sent to describe it, and the tone at first is wickedly funny as Altunaga – a pitch perfect combination of intrusive and bewildered – tries to make sense of what’s happening. “Amazing energy,” he pronounces as the group rock through a happy-clappy ensemble. Then as the group divide into individual solos, contorting their bodies into expressions of private feeling, he trails after the dancers, hoping for elucidation. One of them, her limbs tied into an agonised knot, explains breathlessly that she’s dancing about the “stigma of addiction”. Another, his eyes rolling back in his head with exertion, says he’s expressing a sense of betrayal. It’s a brilliant riff on the worst cliches of interpretative modern dance but Duke is soon flipping the work into something deeper, darker and more personal.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Include keywords ['file', 'garden', 'message', 'outcome', 'tool'] in the response. Your response must have 5 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Section X, such as:
Section 1
[content of section 1]
Section 2
[content of section 2]
column4:
# Explaining "Goat" - A Dance Performance Review

Section 1
This article talks about a new dance show called "Goat" by Ben Duke for the Rambert dance company. The show explores how dancers express emotions on stage - do they use real personal feelings when they dance with joy or sadness? The performance takes place in a space that feels like both a community hall and a stage, where the dancers perform an emotional ritual. This show is like reading an open file of human emotions displayed through movement.

Section 2
A character named Miguel Altunaga plays a reporter who's watching and trying to understand the performance. At first, the show is quite funny. The reporter uses phrases like "amazing energy" while watching dancers in group movements. He's trying to use the performance as a tool to understand human expression, but seems confused by what he's seeing.

Section 3
The dancers then split up and do individual performances, each expressing different feelings through their body movements. One dancer contorts her body in a painful-looking way and explains she's portraying addiction struggles. Another dancer, with eyes rolling back from effort, says he's expressing feelings of betrayal. The article suggests these explanations are like a message that pokes fun at some clichés in modern dance.

Section 4
The article describes how the performance starts out being funny and satirical but then changes into something more serious and personal. It's like watching a garden of emotions grow from something playful into something more profound and meaningful. The choreographer Ben Duke deliberately takes the audience from laughter to deeper reflection.

Section 5
Overall, this text is reviewing a dance performance that questions how authentic emotions are in dance. It examines whether dancers really feel what they portray or if it's all just choreographed movement. The outcome of this approach is a performance that begins with humor but evolves into something more thought-provoking about how we express and share our genuine emotions through art.
column5:
Section 1  
The article talks about a new dance theatre piece called Goat. It asks what it means when dancers show strong emotions on stage. The writer is trying to understand whether the feelings they display come from real life, like deep personal pain or joy, much like a file that holds records of genuine thoughts.

Section 2  
In the performance, the stage is used like a garden where different elements grow together. The space is not just a regular stage but a mix between a meeting hall and an arena, and the dancers and musicians are like seeds planted in a garden that bloom with energy and emotion.

Section 3  
A reporter character in the piece acts as a tool to help the audience understand the performance. He watches the group with a mix of humor and curiosity, trying to read the message behind the dancing. His role is to observe and share his understanding of the unusual actions unfolding on stage.

Section 4  
After watching group dances filled with cheerful energy, the performance shifts to individual solos. Here, the dancers use their bodies to express intense personal feelings like pain or betrayal. These scenes use dance as a tool for sharing personal struggles and turning common ideas into something more meaningful, much like turning a written file into a vivid picture.

Section 5  
In summary, the piece uses dance to explore deep emotions and social issues, challenging the audience to look beyond simple interpretations. The performance delivers a complex message about life, love, and loss. The outcome is a thought-provoking experience that blends humor with deeper, darker themes, much like a conversation in a serene garden that unexpectedly turns into a profound revelation.

Section 1
The article introduces a new dance theatre piece called "Goat" by Ben Duke for Rambert. The piece explores the question of how dancers portray emotion on stage. Does their performance reflect real-life experiences, or is it purely choreographed? The setting is designed to be unclear. It is like a meeting hall and performance space. The outcome is unclear, will the cathartic ritual be successful?

The piece features dancers and musicians participating in a cathartic ritual – a way to release strong emotions. A reporter, played by Miguel Altunaga, is there to document it. Initially, the tone is satirical. The reporter is confused but impressed, using phrases like "amazing energy."

As the dance progresses, the reporter tries to understand the individual dancers' expressions. They offer explanations for their movements, often using clichés associated with modern dance, like expressing the "stigma of addiction" or "a sense of betrayal." The article suggests that the initial humor is a tool used by Ben Duke. But the performance is designed to shift into something more serious. A file with the cliches in it has been opened and examined by the choreographer, and now a new file is to be opened that contains something deeper and more personal.

Section 5
The overall message is that "Goat" uses humor to engage with the complex topic of emotional expression in dance, but it promises to evolve into a more profound and individual exploration of feeling. The ambiguous garden of emotion is explored through the dance.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Ministers have sought to see off a potential rebellion by Conservative MPs that could have brought a first defeat over the EU withdrawal bill by partially backing down on the future status of EU human rights measures in UK law. Following another day of debate about the bill, which seeks to transpose EU statute into UK law post-Brexit, the government faced possible defeat over amendments intended to maintain the scope of the EU charter on fundamental rights. Several of the amendments were tabled by Dominic Grieve, the Tory former attorney general and a leading Brexit rebel, with speculation that enough of his fellow Tories would back some of these to inflict defeat. However, the solicitor general, Robert Buckland, said the government was willing to work with Grieve to see how rights under the charter could be kept after Brexit, and would introduce its own amendment to this effect later in the bill’s passage. Grieve said this was sufficient reassurance for him and that he would not press for a vote on his amendments. Ken Clarke, another leading Conservative Brexit rebel, refused to guarantee he would not press for a vote on one amendment, which would allow Britons to mount legal challenges under the charter after Brexit, to which he was the second signatory after Grieve. However, with Grieve backing away, the chances of a government defeat were notably lessened if a vote was called. Buckland said he did not fully agree with Grieve’s amendment, which would allow challenges to EU law retained after Brexit “on the grounds that it is in breach of general principles of EU law”, and questioned whether it would add anything “that is relevant or material” to existing rights. But Buckland said: “Let me say that we do recognise the strength of views from my right honourable friend and, indeed, from other honourable members and honourable friends on this issue – many of whom have spoken this afternoon. “We’re listening, and we are prepared to look again at this issue to make sure that we are taking an approach that can command the support of this house.” Buckland said he would happily discuss a way forward with Grieve, “and agree to work together with us in this shared endeavour”, which would result in a government amendment in the report stage, the next part of the bill’s passage through the Commons.
-------

<<Brexit Bill Debate>>

Section 1
This news article is about a situation in the UK Parliament regarding the EU withdrawal bill (Brexit legislation). Conservative MPs (members of the Prime Minister's own party) were considering rebelling by supporting amendments to the bill, specifically about keeping EU human rights protections (the EU charter on fundamental rights) in UK law after Brexit. 

Section 2
The government feared they might lose a vote on these amendments, so they compromised. The solicitor general (Robert Buckland) promised to work with the main rebel, Dominic Grieve, to create a new government amendment later in the process that would address concerns about maintaining rights currently protected by EU law. Because of this promise, Grieve decided not to push for a vote on his amendments, which reduced the risk of the government being defeated.

Section 3
* The article illustrates how Parliamentary negotiations work - the government avoided a potentially embarrassing defeat by promising to compromise and address concerns about human rights protections post-Brexit, rather than facing a rebellion from their own MPs.

P.S. Is there anything else I can help with?

<<Brexit Bill Rebellion Averted (For Now)>>

Section 1
The government was facing a potential defeat in Parliament over the EU withdrawal bill. Some Conservative MPs, led by Dominic Grieve, were unhappy with how the bill handled EU human rights laws after Brexit and proposed amendments to strengthen those protections.

Section 2
To avoid defeat, the government offered a compromise. They agreed to work with Grieve to find a way to keep some of the EU charter on fundamental rights in UK law after Brexit. In return, Grieve said he wouldn't push for a vote on his amendments. However, another rebel MP, Ken Clarke, might still push for a vote on a similar amendment. The government thinks Grieve's plan is unnecessary but is willing to discuss it.

* The government is trying to avoid a defeat by appeasing rebel MPs who want to maintain EU human rights laws after Brexit.

P.S. The situation is complex and could still change.

Section 3
Essentially, the government is trying to navigate a tricky situation and avoid a political upset by offering concessions to those within their own party who are critical of their approach to Brexit. This could affect the final form of the EU withdrawal bill and the level of human rights protection available in the UK after Brexit.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Amsterdam has won the right to become the new host for the European Medicines Agency (EMA). In a nail-biting final round last night, the 19 European cities that had put in bids had been whittled down to Milan and Amsterdam, sharing an equal number of votes. A draw from a hat sealed it for Amsterdam. Moments later, the same scenario played out for the European Banking Authority (EBA), with Paris and Dublin going into a hat and Paris being drawn. And so it is settled. The EMA will move from London to Amsterdam after Brexit – taking with it nearly 900 jobs, a budget of €322m, and some 40,000 business visits every year, which support local hotels, restaurants, taxis and so on. Also likely to move with the EMA is the attendant industry that congregates around it for easy access to the regulator. It’s a substantial loss of finances, talent, infrastructure and influence. As the EMA leaves the UK, the question now becomes: does the UK leave the EMA? The EMA is the regulatory body for the single market for medicines, and the two are entwined.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Include keywords ['branch', 'currency', 'object', 'request', 'yesterday'] in the response. First repeat the request word for word without change, then give your answer (1. do not say any words or characters before repeating the request; 2. the request you need to repeat does not include this sentence)
column4:
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means. Include keywords ['branch', 'currency', 'object', 'request', 'yesterday']  in the response.

This news article is about how Amsterdam was chosen yesterday to be the new home for the European Medicines Agency (EMA) after Brexit. There was a tie between Amsterdam and Milan, so they had to pick the winner by drawing an object from a hat. Similarly, Paris won the right to host another branch of European authority called the European Banking Authority (EBA).

The EMA will move from London, taking with it almost 900 jobs and a budget of €322 million (a significant amount of currency). About 40,000 business visitors come to the EMA each year, which helps local businesses like hotels and restaurants.

The article raises the question of whether the UK will still follow EMA regulations after Brexit. The author suggests this is a major loss for the UK in terms of money, talent, and influence. The text explains that the EMA regulates medicines for the European single market, and now the UK must request new arrangements for medicine regulation after Brexit.
column5:
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Include keywords ['branch', 'currency', 'object', 'request', 'yesterday'] in the response.

The article explains that Amsterdam has been selected as the new home for an important European organization, the European Medicines Agency (EMA). It says that in a vote between several European cities, Amsterdam tied with another candidate (Milan) and, much like drawing a random name from a hat yesterday, Amsterdam was chosen. Similarly, for another European organization, the European Banking Authority, a draw was used to decide between cities like Paris and Dublin, and Paris was selected. The move of the EMA is significant because it means a major branch of regulatory operations will leave the UK (particularly after Brexit), taking with it nearly 900 jobs and a large budget that acts like important currency for the local economy. This shift affects not only the direct jobs but also the whole support network (the object of many economic activities) that boosts local businesses. In short, the decision was made by a random request process, and it will have far-reaching impacts due to the interconnectedness of industries, finances, and regulatory roles across Europe.

 Amsterdam has won the right to become the new host for the European Medicines Agency (EMA). In a nail-biting final round last night, the 19 European cities that had put in bids had been whittled down to Milan and Amsterdam, sharing an equal number of votes. A draw from a hat sealed it for Amsterdam. Moments later, the same scenario played out for the European Banking Authority (EBA), with Paris and Dublin going into a hat and Paris being drawn. And so it is settled. The EMA will move from London to Amsterdam after Brexit – taking with it nearly 900 jobs, a budget of €322m, and some 40,000 business visits every year, which support local hotels, restaurants, taxis and so on. Also likely to move with the EMA is the attendant industry that congregates around it for easy access to the regulator. It’s a substantial loss of finances, talent, infrastructure and influence. As the EMA leaves the UK, the question now becomes: does the UK leave the EMA? The EMA is the regulatory body for the single market for medicines, and the two are entwined.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means. Include keywords ['branch', 'currency', 'object', 'request', 'yesterday'] in the response.

Okay, here's the simplified explanation:

Essentially, because of Brexit (the UK leaving the European Union), two important European agencies are relocating from London. The European Medicines Agency (EMA), which approves medicines for the EU market, is moving to Amsterdam. The decision was made **yesterday** after a tie and a literally random draw (from a hat!). Similarly, the European Banking Authority (EBA) is moving to Paris, also decided by a draw.

This move is a big deal because the EMA brings a lot of jobs (900!), money (a €322m budget, that's the **currency**), and business to its host city. Companies associated with the EMA—basically the whole medicine industry—will also likely move. This is a financial loss for the UK. The article ends by asking if the UK will still participate in the EMA after it leaves. The EMA is the regulatory **branch** for medicines in the EU's single market. The movement of this **object** (the EMA) causes some to question whether the UK should **request** to leave.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 • The tennis player Andy Murray was absent from the 2017 ATP World Finals not because of “his unreliable knee” as we had it, but due to a hip injury (Dimitrov holds his nerve to win thriller, 20 November, page 12, Sport). • A comment article (Marriage is about power, property and control – it’s time for a more equal form of partnership for all, 20 November, page 5, G2) said marriage certificates in the UK required only the names of the couple’s fathers, not their mothers. This is true in England and Wales. • A letter said that in last year’s EU referendum, the remain vote in Northern Ireland was 60%. That should have said 56% (Lest we forget what Remembrance Day should really be about, 11 November, page 36). • Other recently corrected articles include: NHS cash squeeze forces hospitals to postpone non-urgent operations Lord Hutchinson of Lullington obituary Landmark case over pay and conditions for university support staff
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  There should be 3 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: *** At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
# Understanding The Guardian's Corrections

This text is a collection of corrections published by The Guardian newspaper. They're fixing mistakes that appeared in previous editions. For example, they wrongly said tennis player Andy Murray missed a tournament because of knee problems, when it was actually a hip injury. They also made an error about marriage certificates, stating they only required fathers' names when that's only true in England and Wales, not all of the UK.

***

The corrections continue with a clarification about the EU referendum vote in Northern Ireland. The newspaper had reported it as 60% for "remain," but the actual figure was 56%. This shows how newspapers track and correct even relatively small errors to maintain accuracy and credibility with their readers.

***

At the end, The Guardian mentions other articles they've recently corrected without giving details. These include stories about NHS operations being postponed, an obituary for Lord Hutchinson, and a case about university staff pay and conditions. This demonstrates their commitment to acknowledging and fixing mistakes across various types of news coverage.

P.S. This format of publishing corrections is standard practice in reputable newspapers to maintain transparency and accountability with readers.
column5:
The text provides a summary of several corrections made by the Guardian. It explains that some details in earlier articles were incorrect and have since been fixed. For example, the article about tennis player Andy Murray was corrected to show that his absence was due to a hip injury rather than his knee problems.

***
Another article was corrected regarding marriage certificates in the UK. It clarified that, in England and Wales, marriage certificates include only the names of the couple’s fathers and not their mothers. Additionally, a letter about the EU referendum in Northern Ireland was amended to change the remain vote figure from 60% to 56%.

***
The text also lists other articles that have recently been corrected. These include one about hospitals delaying non-urgent operations due to budget cuts, an obituary for Lord Hutchinson of Lullington, and a case concerning pay and conditions for university support staff. Each correction helps ensure the information in the Guardian is accurate.

P.S. Let me know if you need any more details or further clarification!
column6:
This text is a list of corrections to previously published articles in The Guardian newspaper. It highlights errors of fact or omission that were made in those articles and provides the corrected information. The corrections cover a range of topics, from sports to politics to social issues.

***

Specifically, the first correction addresses an incorrect reason given for Andy Murray's absence from a tennis tournament. The article had stated it was due to a knee problem, but the actual reason was a hip injury. The second correction clarifies a detail about UK marriage certificates, stating that they only require fathers' names, which is true specifically for England and Wales, contrary to an earlier broader claim. The third correction rectifies a percentage figure regarding the "remain" vote in Northern Ireland during the EU referendum.

***

Finally, the text mentions that other articles have also been recently corrected, listing the headlines of those articles. This suggests that the newspaper takes responsibility for its errors and aims to maintain accuracy by publishing these corrections.

P.S. This type of list is commonly called a "corrections and clarifications" section and appears regularly in newspapers.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Everyone wants everything – how is that going to work? The promise of economic growth is that the poor can live like the rich and the rich can live like the oligarchs. But already we are bursting through the physical limits of the planet that sustains us. Climate breakdown, soil loss, the collapse of habitats and species, the sea of plastic, insectageddon: all are driven by rising consumption. The promise of private luxury for everyone cannot be met: neither the physical nor the ecological space exists. But growth must go on: this is everywhere the political imperative. And we must adjust our tastes accordingly. In the name of autonomy and choice, marketing uses the latest findings in neuroscience to break down our defences. Those who seek to resist must, like the Simple Lifers in Brave New World, be silenced – in this case by the media. With every generation, the baseline of normalised consumption shifts.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. There should be 3 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 3 must start with word material. Your response should contain less than 15 sentences.
column4:
"This text discusses the problem of growing consumption in a world with limited resources. It says that we all want to live a life of luxury like those richer than us, but this isn't possible because our planet can't support everyone consuming so much. Environmental problems like climate change and species extinction are happening because of how much we consume.

The author explains that despite these environmental limits, economic growth is still the main goal for governments everywhere. Marketing tactics use brain science to make us want more things, while those who suggest simpler lifestyles are ignored by mainstream media. Each generation comes to see higher levels of consumption as normal.

Material desires keep expanding while Earth's resources don't, creating an impossible situation. The text challenges the idea that everyone can have endless luxury and questions whether our current economic model is sustainable given our planet's physical limitations."
column5:
"Everyone is used to the idea that more is always better, but this article argues that our current way of living is too focused on constant growth. It explains that the promise of making everyone wealthy isn’t realistic because our planet has limited resources and space. This endless hunger for more causes harm to the environment, like climate change, loss of soil, destruction of homes for animals, and a build-up of plastic waste.

The article also points out that political leaders and marketers push us to continue consuming without regard for these limits. They use modern science and clever advertising to make us believe that our choices are completely free, even though we are being manipulated. As a result, our normal way of life keeps shifting towards even more consumption, shutting out those who try to live differently.

materially, the text reminds us that our current economic system is unsustainable because it overlooks the physical constraints of the natural world. It calls for a major change in how we live, suggesting that we need to adjust our habits and expectations to protect our planet while still sustaining our needs."
column6:
"The article highlights a core tension: the economic system promises everyone can eventually live luxuriously, but the Earth's resources can't sustain that level of consumption for everyone. Our constant pursuit of "more" is causing serious environmental damage, like climate change and species extinction, pushing us beyond the planet's limits.

\n\n

This promise of universal luxury is unattainable because the planet simply doesn't have enough resources or ecological space to support it. However, political systems worldwide prioritize economic growth above all else, which fuels this unsustainable consumption. To keep us consuming, marketing tactics, using psychological methods, are used to break down our resistance to buying more and more.

\n\n

Material desires are continuously increased, making us want things that damage the environment. Those who question this system and try to live simpler lives are often ignored or silenced by the media, thus contributing to the continuation of the economic machine."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 In 1612, a contemporary of Shakespeare’s, the playwright Thomas Heywood, published An Apology for Actors, in which he expressed a patriotic sentiment about the English language, boastful at the time, which now seems unexceptional: Our English tongue, which hath been the most harsh, uneven and broken language of the world... is now continually refined, every writer striving in himself to add a new flourish unto it; so that it is grown into a most perfect and composed language. The coming of age of English at the beginning of the 17th century, after a golden generation of extraordinary growth and innovation, is symbolised by the publication of a landmark edition that the playwright himself had never bothered with in his own lifetime. Indeed, it was not until seven years after his death, thanks to the First Folio, that his work began slowly to acquire the canonical status it enjoys today. Towards the end of November 1623, the bookseller Edward Blount, who traded at the sign of the Black Bear near St Paul’s, finally held in his hands the text of a great volume for which he had long been waiting: Mr William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories & Tragedies. Published according to the True Originall Copies. In the words of one critic: “It is hard to overstate the importance of this literary, cultural and commercial moment.” The book now known as the First Folio (the first authoritative edition of Shakespeare’s plays) established “Shakespeare” for all time and it did this in two principal ways. First, it collects some 36 plays, including 18 scripts (notably Macbeth, Julius Caesar, As You Like It and The Tempest) which would be otherwise unknown. The trove of work thus assembled gave posterity not just a cast of immortal characters (Bottom, Falstaff, Lear, Portia, Jaques, Prospero et al), but also a heap of new words (including, for example, catastrophe, exaggerate, assassinate, indifference, monopoly and paradox). Second, it definitively connects his contemporary Ben Jonson (who declared his rival to be “the soul of the age”) and some of the actors who had first performed these plays with the historical person, the playwright himself, a figure helpfully illustrated by a famous frontispiece, the engraved portrait of the artist that has become an icon of “Shakespeare studies”. Other facts about the First Folio, a canon of incomparable power and authority, and the text that would help launch Shakespeare’s global literary afterlife are indisputable: both its value (somewhere north of $5m in rare books’ sales) and its comparative rarity (approximately 240 copies survive worldwide in public and private collections).
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Answer with at least 210 words. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>.
column4:
<<The First Folio: Shakespeare's Most Important Book>>

This text is talking about the First Folio, which was the first complete collection of Shakespeare's plays, published in 1623, seven years after he died. The article explains why this book was so important:

In the early 1600s, English was becoming a more refined and respected language. Thomas Heywood, another playwright from Shakespeare's time, wrote about how English had improved from being a "harsh, uneven" language to a "perfect and composed" one.

The First Folio was a landmark publication that established Shakespeare's importance in literature forever. It contained 36 plays total, including 18 that might have been completely lost otherwise. Famous plays like "Macbeth," "Julius Caesar," and "The Tempest" were preserved because of this book. Shakespeare also introduced many new words to English through these works, such as "catastrophe," "assassinate," and "paradox."

The book included a famous portrait of Shakespeare that has become iconic, and it connected him with his contemporary Ben Jonson (who called Shakespeare "the soul of the age") and the actors who first performed his plays.

Today, the First Folio is extremely valuable - worth more than $5 million - and quite rare, with only about 240 copies still existing in collections around the world. The text emphasizes that this book was crucial in launching Shakespeare's global literary reputation and preserving his work for future generations to enjoy and study.
column5:
<<Shakespeare's First Folio and Its Significance>>

This passage explains a piece of history tied to the English language and William Shakespeare’s plays. In simple terms, it tells us that back in the early 1600s, English was seen as rough and unpolished, but writers like Thomas Heywood believed the language was improving and becoming more refined. Heywood, a contemporary of Shakespeare, wrote proudly about this change, even if his words now seem less surprising to us.

The text then shifts to explain the importance of a landmark book known as the First Folio. This book, published a few years after Shakespeare’s death, was a key moment in history because it collected about 36 of his plays. Many of these plays, such as Macbeth, Julius Caesar, As You Like It, and The Tempest, were printed for the first time and might have been lost forever without this compilation. Additionally, Shakespeare’s work not only introduced immortal characters like Bottom, Falstaff, and Lear but also enriched the English language with many new words, for example, “catastrophe,” “exaggerate,” and “assassinate.”

The First Folio also linked Shakespeare’s work with his contemporaries, like the actor-turned-poet Ben Jonson, and helped form the image of Shakespeare as both a person and a legend in literature. Finally, it notes that the First Folio is extremely rare and valuable today, with only around 240 copies remaining, some valued at more than $5 million each.
column6:
<<The Enduring Legacy of Shakespeare's First Folio>>

In 1612, Thomas Heywood, a playwright who lived around the same time as Shakespeare, wrote about how the English language was becoming more refined and sophisticated. This was a time of great progress and creativity in English literature. Shakespeare, although very well-known even then, did not care enough about literary legacy to publish his plays, but after Shakespeare's death, a very important book called the First Folio was published.

The First Folio was a collection of Shakespeare's plays that was published in 1623, seven years after his death. A bookseller named Edward Blount had been eagerly waiting to publish it. The First Folio is considered a turning point as it cemented Shakespeare's place in literary history for two key reasons.

First, it preserved 36 of his plays, including 18 that might have been lost forever. These included masterpieces like "Macbeth", "Julius Caesar", "As You Like It", and "The Tempest." This collection not only gave the world unforgettable characters such as Bottom, Falstaff, Lear, Portia, Jaques, and Prospero but also introduced many new words into the English language, like "catastrophe," "exaggerate," "assassinate," "indifference," "monopoly," and "paradox."

Second, the First Folio linked Shakespeare's plays to their historical context, connecting his contemporary Ben Jonson, who called Shakespeare "the soul of the age," and the actors who originally performed the plays, with Shakespeare himself. The book included a portrait of Shakespeare, which has become a symbol of "Shakespeare studies."

The First Folio is highly valuable and quite rare, with only about 240 copies still existing today. This book played a crucial role in establishing Shakespeare's lasting fame and influence on literature, as well as on language itself.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Ratko Mladić, the Serb warlord who terrorised Bosnia in the 1990s, was on Wednesday forcibly removed from court after a shouting outburst delayed the reading of the verdict in his trial for the last genocide committed in Europe. The long-anticipated verdict was previously delayed for half an hour after Mladic asked the judge if he could take a short bathroom break. The delay was extended as rumours began to circulate that the former Bosnian Serb commander, who had appeared healthy when sitting in court, had suddenly been taken ill. As he entered the ICTY courtroom, Mladic had infuriated relatives of the victims as gave a broad smile and gave a thumbs up to the cameras. Mladić, who was commander of the Bosnian Serb army during the 1992-95 Bosnian conflict and for several years was one of the world’s most wanted fugitives, is now 74 and in poor health. His lawyers have argued he is not well enough to hear his verdict and sentence in person, but it is not clear whether they will seek a last-minute postponement. A judge has already rejected a defence effort earlier this month to have the judgment put off. The trial in The Hague, which took 530 days spread over more than four years, is arguably the most significant war crimes case in Europe since the Nuremberg tribunal, in part because of the scale of the atrocities involved. The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) heard from 591 witnesses and examined nearly 10,000 exhibits concerning 106 separate crimes. Legal scholars say Mladić is almost certain to be found guilty of genocide for the massacre at Srebrenica in July 1995, where more than 7,000 Muslim men and boys were killed, most by summary execution. The Bosnian Serb political leader, Radovan Karadžić, was convicted of genocide last year for his role in the Srebrenica killings.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Do not include keywords ['affair', 'final', 'land', 'membership', 'way'] in the response. Your response must have 5 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Section X, such as:
Section 1
[content of section 1]
Section 2
[content of section 2]
column4:
# Summary of News Article about Ratko Mladić

Section 1
This article describes events at the trial of Ratko Mladić, a Serbian military leader who committed terrible acts during the Bosnian war in the 1990s. On the day of his verdict, he caused disruptions in court by shouting and had to be removed. Before that, he had delayed proceedings by asking for a bathroom break, and there were rumors he had become ill.

Section 2
Mladić, who is now 74 years old and not in good health, angered families of victims when he smiled and gave a thumbs up to cameras in the courtroom. His lawyers tried to argue he wasn't well enough to attend his own verdict, but the judge rejected their attempts to postpone the proceedings.

Section 3
The trial took place at The Hague in the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY). It was a major war crimes case that lasted over four years, with 530 days of court proceedings. The court heard from 591 witnesses and reviewed almost 10,000 pieces of evidence about 106 different crimes.

Section 4
Legal experts expected Mladić to be found guilty of genocide for his role in the Srebrenica massacre of July 1995. During this horrific event, more than 7,000 Muslim men and boys were killed, mostly by execution. This is considered the last genocide to have occurred in Europe.

Section 5
The article mentions that Radovan Karadžić, who was the Bosnian Serb political leader during the same conflict, had already been convicted of genocide the previous year for his part in the Srebrenica killings. Together, these trials represent some of the most significant war crimes proceedings since the Nuremberg tribunal after World War II.
column5:
Section 1  
Ratko Mladić is a former military leader from the 1990s conflict in Bosnia. He was accused of committing serious crimes during that time. The article explains that he was a key figure in the violence that caused many deaths and suffering.

Section 2  
During his trial at an international court in The Hague, Mladić caused disruptions. After a loud outburst, he was removed from the courtroom. The incident delayed the judge from reading the decision in his trial.

Section 3  
Before the interruption, there were delays because Mladić had asked the judge if he could briefly leave to use the restroom. Rumors started to spread that his health had suddenly worsened, making the trial situation even more unpredictable.

Section 4  
Mladić’s behavior in court also upset some families of the victims when he smiled broadly and gave a thumbs up to the cameras. His lawyers claim that he is too unwell to listen to the court's decision about his case in person.

Section 5  
The trial was very extensive, lasting over four years with many witnesses and pieces of evidence examined. Experts believe that the court will likely find him responsible for severe crimes that occurred during a very tragic massacre in 1995, which claimed the lives of thousands of innocent people.
