column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 A massive search and rescue operation has intensified to find the Argentinian navy submarine ARA San Juan that went missing six days ago in the South Atlantic. If the crew are still alive the submarine would only have one day’s worth of oxygen reserves left. If the vessel is found, a submarine rescue chamber (SCR) will be lowered to couple with the vessel’s hatch and bring the crew up to the surface six members at a time. US rescue equipment and personnel left the Argentinian port of Comodoro Rivadavia on Tuesday heading for the last known location of the San Juan. The SCR and other equipment left aboard the Skandi Patagonia, an oil exploration vessel hired by the US Navy for the rescue mission, heading for the spot 432km (268 miles) east of the Argentinian coast from where the submarine made its last transmission. If the vessel is found, the SCR will be lowered down a cable to try to couple up for the rescue. A total of 49 ships and aircraft from Argentina, the US, the UK, Brazil, Chile and other countries were taking advantage of improved weather conditions to search an area larger than the state of California. More than 100 personnel were participating in the rescue operation, including US and Argentinian navy operatives. The US navy said it was deploying four unmanned undersea vehicles in the search . A large liferaft found in the search area on Monday night, and flares sighted by rescue ships, turned out not to be from the San Juan, the Argentinian navy said on Tuesday.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Include keywords ['grab', 'living', 'luck', 'mark', 'pop'] in the response. Give two different responses. Responses and only responses should be separated by 6 asterisk symbols: ******.
column4:
Here's my first response:

This text is about a big search for a lost submarine from Argentina called ARA San Juan. The submarine disappeared six days ago in the South Atlantic. The crew might still be alive, but they only have one day's oxygen left - they're running out of luck. If rescuers can mark the submarine's location, they'll use a special rescue chamber to grab the crew members, bringing up six people at a time. The hope is that these living people can be saved before oxygen runs out. Many countries including the US and UK are helping with ships, aircraft, and underwater robots. The search area is huge - bigger than California! Some items were spotted that made rescuers' hearts pop with hope, like a liferaft and flares, but these turned out not to be from the missing submarine.

******

Here's my second response:

A submarine from Argentina called ARA San Juan went missing in the South Atlantic six days ago. Many countries are now in a race against time to find it. The crew might still be living inside, but they only have about one day of oxygen left - that's not much luck. If they find the submarine, rescuers will grab the crew using a special rescue chamber that connects to the submarine's hatch, bringing up six crew members at a time. The US sent equipment to help mark the search area and locate the vessel. The search involves 49 ships and aircraft from many countries, covering an area bigger than California. They're also using underwater robots. Some items made searchers' hopes pop up temporarily - like a liferaft and flares - but these weren't actually from the missing submarine.
column5:
The news article tells us that rescuers are urgently searching for the missing Argentinian submarine ARA San Juan in the South Atlantic. The submarine went missing six days ago, and if the crew are still living inside, they have only about one day’s worth of oxygen remaining. To try to save them, teams are using special equipment—including a submarine rescue chamber (SCR) that can grab up six crew members at a time by attaching to the hatch. Rescue ships and aircraft from many countries, including the US, UK, Brazil, and Chile, are involved in the search in a huge area. There have been a few false leads, like a liferaft and some flares, which turned out not to belong to the San Juan. Still, rescue efforts are on, and every mark and sign of the submarine could be very important; the team is hoping their luck turns around soon, like a pop of good news that could grab everyone's attention.

******

The story explains that a massive international rescue operation is underway because the Argentinian submarine San Juan went missing, and its crew might be in danger if they don’t get rescued soon—if they’re still living at all. As the oxygen inside is running dangerously low (just one day left), experts plan to use a special lift called a submarine rescue chamber, which will grab the crew out six at a time by attaching to the hatch. With 49 ships, aircraft, and support from various countries, rescuers are scouting a huge search area. They’re not having much luck with some initial clues, such as a liferaft and some flares that later proved unrelated. Every tiny mark of hope could mean a pop of success in this critical moment.
column6:
Here's a simple explanation of the news article, incorporating the keywords:

An Argentinian submarine, ARA San Juan, has been missing for almost a week in the South Atlantic, leading to a huge search and rescue. Time is running out – the crew may only have enough oxygen to keep them **living** for another day. If they **luck** out and the submarine is found, rescuers plan to use a special chamber to **grab** the crew, six at a time, and bring them to the surface. US rescue teams have already left port with the equipment needed. They are heading towards the last known location or **mark** where the submarine sent a signal from, an area far off the Argentinian coast. Many countries are helping with ships and planes to search an enormous area. Unfortunately, some initial hopes, like a liferaft and flares, didn't **pop** up from the missing submarine, so the search continues.

******

Here's another simpler explanation, using the keywords in a different way:

The Argentinian navy submarine ARA San Juan is lost in the South Atlantic, and a massive search is underway. The big concern is that the crew's oxygen is running out, so their chance of **living** depends on finding them quickly. Rescuers hope to **luck** into finding the sub and plan to use a special rescue chamber to **grab** the crew and bring them up in small groups. US teams are racing to the **mark**, the last known location of the submarine, to start the rescue. Despite a huge search effort with help from many countries, false alarms like a liferaft haven't helped the search **pop**. The search continues with urgency.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 It is a £700m cathedral to biomedical science, where scientists work together to make breakthroughs in cancer, neuroscience, pandemics and genetics. But the Francis Crick Institute is not proving to be the easiest place to concentrate. A year after opening, some of the 1,250 people working at the Crick Institute, in its central London laboratory, have complained that the open plan design, intended to assist informal collaboration, means some areas set aside for thinking and writing up research are too noisy. Chattering members of the public and colleagues celebrating PhD awards have been cited by those who, anecdotal evidence suggests, have been struggling to adapt to working alongside the building’s cavernous atrium. “There are individuals that complain,” said Nicholas Luscombe, leader of one of the Crick’s research groups. “Some people like the background noise as if they were working in a cafe. Some want absolute silence and it’s not great for that. My view is the layout has been extremely successful in terms of what it set out to achieve. You keep bumping into people and that has created new collaborations for me.” The Crick is carrying out tests on noise levels and examining whether the acoustics need to be improved, a spokeswoman said. Dr Kerstin Sailer, reader in social and spatial networks at University College London’s Bartlett School of Architecture, who is researching the way the building is performing, said “some people say it is very loud, specifically those spaces close to the atrium”.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Include keywords ['initial', 'session', 'swing', 'trick', 'west'] in the response. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Your response should contain less than 3 sentences.
column4: "In the initial session at the Francis Crick Institute, a £700m research center in west London, some scientists complain that the open plan design creates too much noise to concentrate, especially near the atrium where people swing by and chat, while others see it as a trick that successfully promotes collaboration by making people bump into each other."
column5: "Researchers at the Crick Institute—a £700m center for biomedical science—find that its open, collaborative design sometimes makes it too noisy to concentrate, with some enjoying the lively environment like a café while others struggle. In their initial session of adjusting, the team is testing the acoustics to see if a different layout might swing things back in favor of quiet work, proving that the design trick might need tweaking even in the west sections of the building."
column6: "The **initial** reviews of the Francis Crick Institute, a large biomedical research center, are mixed, with some scientists finding the open-plan design and resulting noise distracting, hindering focused work despite its intention to foster collaboration, though others see the noise as a **trick** to keep them **swing**ing into collaborations. While there was no **west** campus mentioned, The institute is taking steps to address the noise complaints and is in the middle of a **session**, as the researchers try to fix the noise issues in the institute."

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Sajid Javid’s comments reported in Peter Walker’s article (‘£90k is a lot of avocados’: Javid defends millennials who can’t afford a home, theguardian.com, 16 November) could not be more accurate. As a 24-year-old, I am so often forced to listen to my elders’ indignation for my choosing to take a holiday, or have a meal out with friends when every penny I earn should be saved for a house. When you consider increasing prices and decreasing availability of property in the UK, along with the banks’ appetites to lend being lower than ever, it’s unlikely I will ever own my own home. Perhaps I just need to accept that thousands of us are destined to spend the rest of our lives throwing all of our money at the people who own the properties we rent from them while they complain about how irresponsible we are. Sam Webb Sutton Coldfield, West Midlands • Have you heard about the massive discounts available for the under-25s? Unfortunately not; in reality the only thing reduced for us is our wages. Under-25s are excluded from the pitiful “national living wage”. From 21-24 we can be paid as little as £7.05 per hour, and for 18-20 a shocking £5.60 for doing exactly the same hours in exactly the same job. Even working full-time a 24-year-old might get as little as £14,500 per annum. And we’re far more likely to be on a zero-hours contract.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Your answer must contain exactly 5 bullet points. Use the markdown bullet points such as:
* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2 Your response must have 1 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with SECTION X, such as:
SECTION 1
[content of section 1]
SECTION 2
[content of section 2]
column4:
SECTION 1

* Young people (like the 24-year-old writer) are criticized by older generations for spending money on things like holidays or meals out instead of saving for a house.

* The writer argues that high property prices, limited availability, and difficult loan conditions make home ownership seem impossible for many young people anyway.

* The writer feels that many young people are stuck in a cycle of paying rent to property owners who then criticize them for not being able to buy their own homes.

* Young workers under 25 are paid less than older workers for the same jobs because they're excluded from the "national living wage" - with 21-24 year-olds earning as little as £7.05 per hour.

* Despite doing the same work, young people earn significantly less (possibly only £14,500 per year working full-time) and are more likely to have unstable zero-hours contracts.
column5:
SECTION 1
* The text opens by agreeing with Sajid Javid’s comments and highlighting how older people criticize younger generations for spending money on leisure instead of saving every penny for buying a house.  
* The writer, a 24-year-old, explains that due to rising costs and fewer available homes, it seems nearly impossible for young people like them to ever afford their own home.  
* It points out the unfairness of having to continually pay rent to property owners while being blamed for their financial habits.  
* The article also complains about the working conditions for under-25s, who receive lower wages compared to what is considered a national living wage.  
* Additionally, it notes that many young people are paid very little even when working full-time and are more likely to be on insecure zero-hours contracts.
column6:
SECTION 1

Here's a simplified explanation of the news article excerpt:

*   A 24-year-old named Sam Webb is responding to comments made by Sajid Javid about millennials and homeownership. Sam agrees with Javid's sentiment that it's difficult for young people to afford homes.
*   Sam is frustrated by older generations who criticize young people for spending money on things like holidays and meals, implying they should be saving every penny for a down payment.
*   Sam points out the difficulty of buying a home in the UK due to rising prices, limited availability, and stricter lending practices from banks. They feel it's likely they'll never own a home.
*   The author highlights the unfairness of lower minimum wages for people under 25, who are often paid significantly less than older workers for doing the same job. They also note that young people are more likely to be on zero-hour contracts.
*   The text suggests that even with full-time work, a young person's low wages make it incredibly difficult to save for a house, trapping them in a cycle of renting and struggling to make ends meet.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 MPs have accused the government of failing to protect consumers over the price it has promised to pay for power from the Hinkley Point C nuclear plant. The Commons public accounts committee said the subsidy contract for Hinkley Point C, agreed in 2016 after years of delays, would hit poorest households hardest. The power station is expected to cost billpayers £30bn over the lengthy of the 35-year contract, adding £10-£15 to the average household energy bill. But an assessment by the committee concluded that no one in Whitehall was championing consumers’ interests during negotiations with French company EDF Energy. The final bill for consumers was exacerbated by government not renegotiating the guaranteed power price for fear that EDF and its Chinese partner CGN would walk away from the project, which the MPs said was a questionable assumption. Officials agreed a price of £92.50 per megawatt hour in 2013 but fossil fuel price projections fell between then and the contract being signed in 2016, pushing the cost to consumers up fivefold from £6bn to £30bn. At the time the Department of Energy and Climate Change – now the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy – did not consider a ceiling on the guaranteed price, the MPs were told. Meg Hillier, chair of the group of MPs, said: “Billpayers have been dealt a bad hand by the government in its approach to this project.” The criticism from the committee follows a damning report by the UK’s spending watchdog, the NAO, which found the contract for Hinkley had locked consumers into a “risky and expensive project”. The NAO attacked the government for failing to explore alternative financing models, such as taking stake in the project, a criticism that the MPs echoed. The public accounts committee said it was also disappointed that the government appeared to have no plan in place to maximise the wider benefits of the project, beyond the clean power it will provide.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  There should be 2 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 1 must start with word state. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>.
column4:
<<Hinkley Point C Nuclear Plant Price Controversy>>

State representatives in Parliament are criticizing the government for not protecting consumers regarding the price agreed for power from the Hinkley Point C nuclear plant. The Commons public accounts committee believes the 2016 subsidy contract will particularly hurt poorer households by adding £10-£15 to average energy bills, costing billpayers £30 billion over 35 years. They found that no government official was looking out for consumers during negotiations with EDF Energy. The situation worsened when officials didn't renegotiate the power price despite changing market conditions, fearing the French and Chinese partners would abandon the project.

The committee chairperson, Meg Hillier, stated that consumers received "a bad hand" from the government's approach. This criticism follows a report by the spending watchdog (NAO) that called the project "risky and expensive." Both the NAO and the committee criticized the government for not exploring other financing options, such as taking a stake in the project themselves. Additionally, the committee expressed disappointment that the government apparently has no plan to maximize wider benefits from the project beyond the clean power it will generate.
column5:
<<Hinkley Point C Contract Criticism>>

state the MPs are saying that the government made a poor deal when agreeing on the cost to buy power from the Hinkley Point C nuclear plant. They argue the contract, set up in 2016, will force households—especially those with lower incomes—to pay more for energy over a 35-year period. The agreed price turned out to be much higher than expected because, even though the price was set before fossil fuel costs dropped, the contract did not include a limit to stop prices from going too high. This decision means consumers may end up paying a lot more, with projections rising the total bill from £6bn to around £30bn.

The committee members and a watchdog report from the National Audit Office both criticize the government for not doing enough to protect the public. They believe that by not renegotiating the contract or exploring other financing options—like taking an ownership stake—the government left consumers exposed to a risky deal. In essence, the arguments suggest that the government's approach did not look out for the best interests of the public, leaving people to bear unnecessary costs.
column6:
<<Hinkley Point C Controversy>>

State officials are under fire for a deal concerning the Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant, with accusations of failing to protect consumers from high electricity prices. A parliamentary committee suggests that the agreed-upon contract, which promises a certain price for the plant's power, will disproportionately burden low-income families. Over the 35-year contract, households may pay an extra £10-£15 annually, totaling £30 billion, because the government didn't strongly advocate for consumer interests when negotiating with EDF Energy, the French company behind the project.

The government's reluctance to renegotiate the guaranteed power price, fearing EDF and its Chinese partner CGN might abandon the project, led to increased costs for consumers. The price was set at £92.50 per megawatt hour in 2013, but with falling fossil fuel prices, the cost to consumers significantly increased by the time the contract was signed in 2016. Critics argue the government didn't explore other financing options or a price ceiling, and lacked a plan to maximize benefits beyond clean power. A spending watchdog also criticized the deal as "risky and expensive".

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The top US telecoms regulator has unveiled sweeping plans to overturn Obama-era rules designed to protect an open internet. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) chairman, Ajit Pai, plans to repeal “net neutrality” regulations that were championed by tech companies and consumer groups. The rules but have been heavily criticized by internet service providers and Pai. “The FCC will no longer be in the business of micromanaging business models and pre-emptively prohibiting services and applications and products that could be pro-competitive,” Pai told Reuters. He added that the Obama administration had sought to pick winners and losers and exercised “heavy-handed” regulation of the internet. “We should simply set rules of the road that let companies of all kinds in every sector compete and let consumers decide who wins and loses.” The move is likely to spark a furious battle before the FCC’s vote on the proposals on 14 December. About 21m comments were submitted to the regulator as it discussed the proposals, and activists have flooded legislators with more than 250,000 calls condemning Pai’s plans. The FCC’s plans will be challenged in court. Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi called the decision “an all-out assault on the entrepreneurship, innovation and competition at the heart of the internet”. Net neutrality is the principle that all traffic on the internet is treated equally.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Answer with one of the following options: ('My answer is yes.', 'My answer is no.', 'My answer is maybe.')
column4:
This text is discussing a plan by FCC chairman Ajit Pai to repeal "net neutrality" rules that were established during the Obama administration. 

Net neutrality means that all internet traffic should be treated equally by internet service providers. The Obama-era rules required internet providers to treat all web traffic the same way.

Pai wants to remove these regulations, arguing they micromanage businesses and that the market should decide what works best. He believes companies should compete freely and consumers should decide who succeeds.

This plan is controversial - tech companies and consumer groups support net neutrality, while internet service providers oppose it. The proposal sparked significant public response with 21 million comments submitted and activists making 250,000 calls against the plan. Democrats like Nancy Pelosi strongly oppose the change, calling it an assault on internet innovation and competition.

The FCC was scheduled to vote on this proposal on December 14, and legal challenges were expected.

My answer is maybe.
column5:
In simple terms, the article is saying that the head of the US telecom regulator (the FCC) wants to undo rules that were put in place during Obama's presidency to ensure that all internet traffic is treated the same (a concept known as net neutrality). The FCC chairman, Ajit Pai, argues that these rules interfere with businesses and competition, while many critics—including tech companies, consumer groups, and lawmakers—believe that removing the rules will harm the openness and fairness of the internet. 

My answer is yes.
column6: My answer is maybe.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 An Oxford graduate is suing the university for £1m on the grounds that his failure to get a top degree 17 years ago cost him the chance of a lucrative legal career. Faiz Siddiqui alleges the “inadequate” teaching he received on the Indian special subject part of his modern history course resulted in him getting only a low upper second degree when he took his finals in June 2000 instead of a first or high 2:1. Siddiqui, 39, has blamed the situation on a number of members of staff being absent on sabbatical leave and a failure to find cover. He has also alleged that a tutor failed to submit medical information about him to examiners. He claims he would have become an international commercial lawyer if he had gained the top qualification at the end of his time at Brasenose College, and that his clinical depression and insomnia have been significantly exacerbated by his “inexplicable failure”. The legal battle between Siddiqui and Oxford has been ongoing for more than a year. Last year a judge allowed Siddiqui’s action to proceed to be fully argued after Oxford claimed the case had no merit and had been brought outside the legal time limit. It was decided at the time that Siddiqui had a real chance of persuading a judge that the case was not time-barred or that it would be just for it to proceed in any event. At the high court in London on Tuesday, Siddiqui’s barrister, Roger Mallalieu, told Mr Justice Foskett that in 2000 Siddiqui was a “driven young man” aiming for a postgraduate qualification from an Ivy League university before a career at the tax bar in England or a major US law firm. “Whilst a 2:1 degree from Oxford might rightly seem like a tremendous achievement to most, it fell significantly short of Mr Siddiqui’s expectations and was, to him, a huge disappointment,” Mallalieu said.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Answer with less than 434 words. Your response should contain less than 14 sentences. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S Your response must have 2 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with SECTION X, such as:
SECTION 1
[content of section 1]
SECTION 2
[content of section 2]
column4:
SECTION 1
A 39-year-old Oxford graduate named Faiz Siddiqui is suing Oxford University for £1 million. He claims that poor teaching during his history course 17 years ago resulted in him getting a lower grade than expected. Siddiqui believes he received inadequate instruction because many professors were on sabbatical leave and the university didn't find replacements. He also alleges that a tutor failed to submit his medical information to examiners. Siddiqui argues that if he had received better grades (a first or high 2:1 instead of a low 2:1), he would have become a successful international commercial lawyer. He claims his "inexplicable failure" has worsened his depression and insomnia.

SECTION 2
This legal battle has been ongoing for over a year. Last year, a judge allowed the case to proceed to trial despite Oxford's claims that it had no merit and was filed too late. Now the case is being heard in the High Court in London. Siddiqui's lawyer described him as a "driven young man" who had planned to attend an Ivy League university for postgraduate studies before pursuing a career at a major law firm. While most people would consider a 2:1 degree from Oxford an impressive achievement, it was a major disappointment for Siddiqui because it fell short of his expectations and career ambitions.

P.P.S. This case raises interesting questions about university accountability, the impact of education quality on career prospects, and the reasonable timeframe for legal claims related to educational outcomes.
column5:

He argues this lower grade cost him the chance to pursue a lucrative legal career.

SECTION 2  
The case has been in progress for over a year after a judge decided it could continue despite Oxford's claims that it was too old to bring and lacked merit. His barrister noted that in 2000, he was an ambitious student aiming for further study at an elite American university and a high-profile career at prestigious law firms. Although a 2:1 degree is normally a good achievement, he feels it fell far short of his expectations and worsened his mental health issues.  

P.P.S This summary simplifies the key points of the news article while highlighting the main reasons behind the lawsuit and the potential impact on his career and well-being.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Who will win? Vic Marks: Australia – because they usually do. England have won there once in their last seven tours. Jason Gillespie: Australia will win because I’m not convinced England can take 20 wickets consistently if conditions don’t suit Stuart Broad and Jimmy Anderson. Ali Martin: Australia to pilfer the urn, with home conditions proving the difference between what are two imperfect teams with near identical win-loss records since the last time they met. Andy Bull: Australia. Their fast bowlers are just that much more dangerous in these conditions and England’s batsmen haven’t kicked their bad habit of collapsing in a heap. Geoff Lemon: With both having weaknesses, home advantage will make the difference. If Australia’s bowlers stay fit, they’re too good. Lose two, and things will look different.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Do not include keywords ['average', 'change', 'fix', 'link', 'performance'] in the response. There should be 1 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: ***
column4: This text is a collection of cricket experts' predictions about who will win the Ashes series between England and Australia. All five experts (Vic Marks, Jason Gillespie, Ali Martin, Andy Bull, and Geoff Lemon) believe Australia will win. Their reasoning includes Australia's historical success at home, England's struggle to take wickets in Australian conditions, the advantage of playing on home grounds, Australia's fast bowlers being more effective, and England's tendency to collapse while batting. The consensus is that while both teams have weaknesses, Australia's home advantage gives them the edge, though injuries to Australian bowlers could alter the outcome.
column5:
***
Several experts were asked to predict the outcome of the game between England and Australia. They mostly believe that Australia is likely to win, mainly because playing at home gives them an advantage—especially with bowlers who can exploit the local conditions. In contrast, there is doubt about England’s ability to overcome their recurring struggles, particularly in taking enough wickets when the conditions aren’t ideal. While one expert mentioned that losing a couple of key players could affect the result, the overall sentiment is clear: Australia is expected to come out on top.
***
column6: Several sports writers at The Guardian predict that Australia will win. They believe Australia's strong record and familiarity with their home playing fields will give them an advantage. Some point out that England has struggled to win in Australia recently. Others highlight the strength of Australia's fast bowlers in their home environment and express concern about England's batting weaknesses. Overall, the writers feel that Australia's home advantage and bowling attack will be key factors in their victory.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The New England Patriots got the result they wanted on their trip to Mexico City on Sunday, beating the Oakland Raiders 33-8. Their coach, however, is in no rush to repeat the experience. “Players did a great job dealing with all the challenges we had to deal with. I think we’re fortunate there was no volcano eruptions or earthquakes, or anything else while we were down there,” Bill Belichick said in an appearance on WEEI on Monday. “You have two NFL franchises in an area that I don’t know how stable the geological plates that were below us [were], but nothing happened, so that was good.” Belichick’s fears are odd considering he has never voiced concerns about traveling to play any of the NFL teams in California along the San Andreas Fault, an area prone to earthquakes. The Patriots have also played in Seattle twice in the past 10 years; the city sits close to the volcanic Mount Rainier and it is believed an eruption could affect the city. Belichick did, however, cite other concerns about the Mexico City trip. “It’s a long way to go for a game,” Belichick said. “There’s a lot to it in terms of all the logistics of it. They are not used to having a NFL team so you have to go in there and handle a lot of the logistics.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Include keywords ['bath', 'pace', 'shoe', 'truck', 'turn'] in the response. Finish your response with this exact phrase Any other questions?. No other words should follow this phrase.
column4:
This text is about a football game where the New England Patriots beat the Oakland Raiders in Mexico City. After the game, Patriots coach Bill Belichick expressed concerns about playing in Mexico. He mentioned worries about volcanoes and earthquakes, which seemed strange since he never complained about similar risks when playing in California or Seattle. He also said it was a long way to travel and that Mexico wasn't used to hosting NFL teams, making logistics difficult.

In simpler terms:
- The Patriots won their game in Mexico
- Their coach didn't like playing there
- He worried about natural disasters (earthquakes, volcanoes)
- This was odd because he plays in risky U.S. locations without complaint
- He also didn't like the travel distance and organizational challenges

It's like when you take a long trip and complain about the pace of travel, but you don't mind similar issues closer to home. Just as you might worry about your shoe getting dirty in one place but not another, or how a bath feels different in unfamiliar surroundings. His concerns seemed to make a sudden turn, like a truck changing lanes without signaling.

Any other questions?
column5: This article tells us that the New England Patriots won their game in Mexico City by a large margin, 33-8, and that their coach, Bill Belichick, made some unusual jokes afterward. He joked that the team was lucky not to have any natural disasters like volcano eruptions or earthquakes while traveling. Despite these humorous remarks, he also acknowledged that traveling so far can be a hassle because of all the planning involved—kind of like making sure a truck is loaded properly before it goes. His comments come off as a bit unexpected, much like someone taking a bath at a rapid pace, wearing a worn-out shoe, or making a sudden turn when you least expect it. Any other questions?
column6:
Okay, here's a simpler explanation of the news article excerpt, incorporating your keywords:

The New England Patriots won their football game in Mexico City against the Oakland Raiders. However, their coach, Bill Belichick, doesn't sound like he wants to go back anytime soon. He jokingly mentioned being relieved that there weren't any natural disasters like volcano eruptions or earthquakes while they were there. It's a bit of a weird **turn**, because he's never seemed worried about playing in earthquake-prone California, or even Seattle, near a volcano. He's more concerned about the actual *travel* itself: the long trip, the extra planning needed because Mexico City isn't used to hosting NFL teams (requiring more planning than say, finding a specific **shoe**). It sounds like coordinating everything was a pain, almost like having to move a whole **truck** full of equipment. He wishes that the team can take a long **bath** after such a grueling **pace**.

Any other questions?

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Blue Planet II 8pm, BBC One Another welcome dip into high-definition aquatic majesty, this week exploring life in the sunken jungles of kelp, algae and seagrass. As well as vivid nightmare fuel such as a 10-armed sea cucumber cramming starfish eggs into its terrible maw like Return of the Jedi’s Sarlacc pit, there are more soothing vignettes, including a diligent Garibaldi damselfish dealing with insurgent urchins and a frisky cuttlefish with a bold cuckolding strategy. Graeme Virtue Howards End 9pm, BBC One Hayley Atwell continues to shine as Margaret, who gets an offer she can’t refuse when Henry (Matthew Macfadyen) proposes. But they’ve hardly planned the honeymoon when a face from the past turns up to threaten their romantic union. As Henry reacts with trademark awkwardness, the families are flung together by the drama. There’s trouble afoot for Leonard Bast, too: after the Schlegels advised him to get a new job, he’s now poor and starving. Hannah Verdier Expedition Volcano 9pm, BBC Two Proving that scientific excitement goes far beyond Bunsen burners, Chris Jackson, Xand Van Tulleken and Aldo Kane travel to Congo, where a team of scientists set up camp to study Mount Nyiragongo, one of Earth’s most spectacular active volcanoes. As if the risk of waking to find lava lapping at your tent flaps wasn’t enough, tests include monitoring the risks of sickness or suffocation by living near the volcano. One hell of a field trip. Mark Gibbings-Jones Guy Martin vs the Robot Car 9pm, Channel 4 With Guy Martin’s very raison d’être threatened by the biggest upheaval in automotive history, he becomes the first man to race against an autonomous racing car, the prototype Roboracer.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Answer with at least 462 words.
column4:
# Breaking Down the Guardian's TV Program Listings

This text is essentially a collection of brief descriptions of TV shows that were scheduled to air on British television. The format follows what you'd typically find in a TV guide or newspaper listing section. Let me explain each program in simpler terms:

## Blue Planet II (8pm, BBC One)
This is a nature documentary about ocean life. This particular episode focuses on underwater plant environments like kelp forests and seagrass meadows. The show features stunning high-definition footage of sea creatures, including some unusual ones like a ten-armed sea cucumber eating starfish eggs (which the writer compares to a monster from Star Wars), a type of fish called the Garibaldi damselfish protecting its territory from sea urchins, and a cuttlefish with an interesting mating strategy. The writer, Graeme Virtue, seems impressed by the visual quality and interesting content.

## Howards End (9pm, BBC One)
This is a drama series, likely based on the classic E.M. Forster novel. In this episode, a character named Margaret (played by actress Hayley Atwell) receives a marriage proposal from a man named Henry (played by Matthew Macfadyen). Just as they're planning their wedding, someone from their past appears and causes problems for their relationship. There's also a subplot involving a character named Leonard Bast who is struggling with poverty after taking some advice from the Schlegel family. The writer, Hannah Verdier, highlights Atwell's performance as particularly good.

## Expedition Volcano (9pm, BBC Two)
This is a documentary where three presenters (Chris Jackson, Xand Van Tulleken, and Aldo Kane) travel to Congo in Africa to study an active volcano called Mount Nyiragongo. They join scientists who are conducting research on the volcano despite the obvious dangers, such as potential eruptions and harmful gases. The writer, Mark Gibbings-Jones, notes that this scientific expedition is far more exciting and dangerous than typical school science experiments.

## Guy Martin vs the Robot Car (9pm, Channel 4)
This show features Guy Martin (likely a professional driver or TV personality) testing himself against a self-driving race car called the Roboracer. The description suggests that autonomous vehicles represent a major change in the automotive industry that could threaten traditional drivers like Martin. The program appears to be setting up a man-versus-machine competition to see if human drivers still have advantages over self-driving technology.

The overall text is written in a concise, somewhat witty style typical of British TV listings, with each writer adding their own brief commentary on the shows. The descriptions aim to give readers enough information to decide if they want to watch these programs, highlighting the most interesting or unusual aspects of each show. The listing covers a mix of nature documentaries, period dramas, and technology-focused programs, suggesting a variety of educational and entertainment options available to British viewers on these channels.
column5:
This text is a preview of several TV shows that are airing on different channels, and it uses a lively and somewhat humorous tone to catch the reader’s attention. Each segment gives a short description of a particular program, along with its broadcast time, channel, and a brief look at what viewers can expect.

The first program mentioned is Blue Planet II. It is scheduled for 8pm on BBC One. The text tells us that the show offers beautiful high-definition views of underwater life. It mentions that this week’s episode focuses on life among underwater plants like kelp, algae, and seagrass. The description highlights two contrasting scenes: one is more disturbing, showing unusual and somewhat grotesque behavior in sea creatures—for instance, a sea cucumber with 10 arms is shown in a way that is compared to a scene from the movie “Return of the Jedi” (specifically linking it to the Sarlacc pit, which is known for being quite terrifying). The other scene is calm and pleasant, featuring everyday activities of sea creatures such as a Garibaldi damselfish, which is busy fending off unruly urchins, and a playful cuttlefish that employs an unexpected mating trick described as a “bold cuckolding strategy.” Essentially, the program mixes moments of striking, unusual marine behavior with more gentle and engaging underwater stories, all set against the backdrop of vivid, clear visuals of life beneath the waves.

Next up is the preview for the drama Howards End, which airs at 9pm on BBC One. This storyline revolves around the character Margaret, played by Hayley Atwell. In this episode, she receives an irresistible offer when a character named Henry (played by Matthew Macfadyen) proposes to her. The text hints that the couple's plans are quickly disrupted when someone from Margaret’s past reappears, casting doubt on their prospects. It explains that Henry reacts in his typical awkward manner to this unexpected twist, and as a result, various families in the story are brought together in complex ways. Additionally, one of the other characters, Leonard Bast, finds himself in trouble after being advised by the Schlegel family to switch jobs; as a result, he ends up facing financial hardships like poverty and hunger. This summary gives an idea that the drama contains elements of romance, unexpected challenges, and an emphasis on the messy, complicated interactions between families.

The third show is Expedition Volcano, scheduled for 9pm on BBC Two. This program follows a team of scientists led by Chris Jackson, Xand Van Tulleken, and Aldo Kane, who take an adventurous trip to the Congo. Their focus is Mount Nyiragongo, which is one of the most dramatic and active volcanoes on Earth. The description underlines that this isn’t your typical laboratory science session; instead, the scientists are working in a dangerous environment where natural events, like volcano eruptions, could pose serious risks such as lava approaching their campsite. They conduct various tests to assess the potential dangers of living so close to a perilous volcano. The narrative ends on a light-hearted note by calling it “one hell of a field trip,” suggesting that it is both exciting and a bit risky.

The final segment of the text is about Guy Martin vs the Robot Car, airing at 9pm on Channel 4. Here, the focus is on Guy Martin, who is known for his passion for motor vehicles. In this episode, he faces a major challenge: racing against an advanced automated racing car, known as the prototype Roboracer. This contest represents a clash between a human driver and cutting-edge robotic technology, highlighting the dramatic changes happening in the field of automotive engineering.

Overall, the text is a collection of engaging TV show previews that mix adventure, drama, science, and competition. Each description gives a quick glimpse into the content of the shows, using vivid imagery and creative language to evoke interest and excitement in prospective viewers.
column6:
Okay, here's a breakdown of those Guardian blurbs, simplified and expanded upon:

This excerpt is a set of mini-reviews or previews for various television programs airing that evening. Each paragraph summarizes the premise and highlights some appealing aspects of the show. Let's go through them one by one:

**1. Blue Planet II (BBC One, 8pm):**

Essentially, this is a nature documentary episode focusing on marine life within underwater forests of kelp, algae, and seagrass. It's part of the visually stunning "Blue Planet II" series, known for its high-definition footage of the ocean.

The reviewer highlights the diverse content of the episode. On one hand, it promises some unsettling imagery. The "10-armed sea cucumber" devouring starfish eggs is described in rather graphic terms, comparing it to the Sarlacc pit from "Return of the Jedi," a creature known for slowly digesting its victims. This suggests viewers should expect some potentially disturbing scenes of marine creatures and their feeding habits.

On the other hand, the episode also offers more calming and engaging content. The mention of a "diligent Garibaldi damselfish" dealing with urchins implies we'll see interesting interactions between species and perhaps even examples of animal behavior that seem almost human-like in their purposefulness. The "frisky cuttlefish with a bold cuckolding strategy" further suggests intriguing and complex animal behaviors are on display, focusing this time on mating and competition.

In summary, this "Blue Planet II" episode promises a visually impressive and fascinating look at life in underwater forests, with a balance of both potentially unsettling and captivating scenes from the natural world.

**2. Howards End (BBC One, 9pm):**

This is a review/preview of an episode of "Howards End," a drama series likely adapted from the classic novel by E.M. Forster. The focus is on the character of Margaret, played by Hayley Atwell, and her evolving relationship with Henry, portrayed by Matthew Macfadyen.

The key event in this episode seems to be Henry's proposal to Margaret, which she accepts. However, their plans for a happy future together are quickly threatened by the arrival of someone from Henry's past. The reviewer suggests that Henry reacts to this situation in a typically awkward manner, indicating some potential conflict or discomfort stemming from his character.

Furthermore, the situation will draw the families involved closer together, suggesting the drama will involve more than just Margaret and Henry's relationship, but also family dynamics and their interactions.

The review also hints at a difficult turn of events for Leonard Bast, a character who was previously advised by the Schlegel family to find a new job. Now, he is struggling with poverty and hunger, indicating that their advice may have had unintended consequences and that he is facing significant hardships.

In short, this episode of "Howards End" revolves around a marriage proposal, the reappearance of a figure from the past, and the ensuing drama that impacts both the central couple and the wider families, while also highlighting the unfortunate circumstances of Leonard Bast.

**3. Expedition Volcano (BBC Two, 9pm):**

This documentary program follows a team of scientists as they conduct research on Mount Nyiragongo, an active volcano located in Congo. The reviewer emphasizes that scientific work can be exciting and adventurous, going beyond stereotypical lab settings.

The description highlights the inherent dangers and challenges of studying an active volcano. The risk of being near lava is explicitly mentioned, suggesting the potential for dramatic and visually striking scenes. Furthermore, the scientists are also monitoring the risks of sickness and suffocation due to living near the volcano, emphasizing the serious health hazards involved in their research.

The reviewer concludes by calling it "one hell of a field trip," reinforcing the idea that this is an extraordinary and challenging undertaking.

Essentially, "Expedition Volcano" offers viewers a glimpse into the adventurous and risky world of volcanology, showcasing the dedication and bravery of scientists studying one of Earth's most spectacular and dangerous natural phenomena.

**4. Guy Martin vs the Robot Car (Channel 4, 9pm):**

This program features Guy Martin, a well-known daredevil and engineering enthusiast, who is pitted against an autonomous racing car, the Roboracer. The underlying theme is the impact of automation and artificial intelligence on traditional industries, particularly in the automotive world.

The review suggests that Guy Martin's very purpose is being threatened by the rise of autonomous vehicles, as his skills and passion for racing might become obsolete in the future. The program explores this tension by having Martin race against the Roboracer, testing the limits of both human and artificial intelligence.

The reviewer positions Martin as the first person to engage in such a race, highlighting the novelty and pioneering nature of the event.

In brief, "Guy Martin vs the Robot Car" is a program that explores the challenges posed by autonomous technology to traditional human skills through a thrilling race between a human driver and a robot car.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Saying the NHS was already in crisis, as I – and a few other Jeremiahs – did two years ago, meant going out on a limb. Today, hardly anyone says anything else, not least because virtually all our dire predictions have become realities. Even public officials responsible for running and inspecting the NHS, who couldn’t be seen for dust then (the heads of NHS England, NHS Improvement and the Care Quality Commission), are going public on the gravity of the situation and begging the chancellor to do something in this week’s budget. Indeed, how could anyone say things are OK when, in response to an increase in the past seven years of at most 15% in A&E attendances and admissions, waits in A&E have gone up by 350% and waits for admission by 550%? Increasing waiting times are the canary in the mine. However, the Department of Health, whenever challenged with a another example of increasingly poor performance, excessive waits or other pressures, retorts not that this is incorrect but (without irony) that other things in the NHS are fine. In reality, all is not well. Once again, I am afraid, those who have just started to complain are saying too little and too late. The NHS isn’t getting into crisis, as they cautiously say. It is way beyond that and already failing, despite its internationally accepted efficiency.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Answer with at least 109 words. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>. Finish your response with this exact phrase Any other questions?. No other words should follow this phrase. There should be 3 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 3 must start with word mark.
column4:
<<The NHS Crisis: Warnings Ignored>>

This article discusses how the National Health Service (NHS) in the UK is in serious trouble. The author explains that they warned about this crisis two years ago, but few people listened then. Now everyone acknowledges the problem because the situation has become so bad. Even the officials who run the NHS are publicly asking for help from the government. The statistics show the problem clearly: while hospital visits increased by about 15% over seven years, waiting times have skyrocketed by 350-550%.

The author criticizes the Department of Health for downplaying the situation by claiming that other aspects of the NHS are functioning well. In reality, the entire system is struggling. The author believes that those who are only now speaking up about the problems are too hesitant in their warnings and have waited too long to act. The NHS isn't approaching a crisis - it's already failing badly, despite being known internationally for its efficiency.

Mark my words, the situation is worse than what many officials are willing to admit publicly. The increasing waiting times are just one indicator of the deeper systemic problems facing the healthcare system. The author is frustrated that their early warnings were dismissed, and now that the crisis is obvious, the response still seems inadequate to address the severity of the situation the NHS faces.

Any other questions?
column5:
<<Simpler Explanation>>
The article explains that warnings about the failing state of the NHS are now being taken seriously by the government and the public. Two years ago, a few people predicted that the NHS would be in trouble, but back then, very few believed them. Now, even those responsible for managing and inspecting the health service are publicly asking the chancellor for help because the problems have become undeniable. They point out that even though some parts of the NHS seem to be doing okay, one crucial area—the time patients spend waiting in A&E—is getting much worse and shows a trend of severe decline.

mark This text essentially argues that the problems in the NHS are far more serious than some officials are willing to admit and that the situation has progressed from worrying signs to a full-blown crisis. The increasing waiting times in the emergency departments are a clear indication that the system is under extreme pressure and in urgent need of intervention. Any other questions?
column6:
<<NHS Crisis: A Dire Warning>>

The author points out that they, along with a few others, warned two years ago that the National Health Service (NHS) in the UK was already in crisis. At that time, this view was considered extreme. However, now, almost everyone acknowledges the NHS is in trouble, as the author's earlier pessimistic predictions have unfortunately come true. Even officials responsible for managing and overseeing the NHS are now publicly expressing serious concerns and urging the government to take action.

The article emphasizes the severity of the situation by highlighting the disparity between the relatively small increase in A&E visits (15%) compared to the massive surge in waiting times (350% in A&E and 550% for admission). The author sees these longer waiting times as a clear indicator of a deeper problem within the NHS. However, the Department of Health, when confronted with these issues, often deflects by pointing out other areas where the NHS is performing well, failing to acknowledge the extent of the crisis.

Markedly, the author believes that the current concerns being voiced are insufficient and overdue. The NHS is not merely approaching a crisis, but is already failing despite its reputation for efficiency. The author asserts that the situation is far more critical than many are willing to admit. Any other questions?

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Ten of the 12 water companies in the UK have admitted they are still using the practice of water dowsing despite the lack of scientific evidence for its effectiveness. The disclosure has prompted calls for the regulator to stop companies passing the cost of a discredited medieval practice on to their customers. Ofwat said any firm failing to meet its commitments to customers faced a financial penalty. Dowsers, or water witchers, claim that their divining rods cross over when the presence of water is detected below ground. It is regarded as a pseudoscience, after numerous studies showed it was no better than chance at finding water. Some water companies, however, insisted the practice could be as effective as modern methods. The discovery that firms were still using water diviners was made by the science blogger Sally Le Page, after her parents reported seeing an engineer from Severn Trent “walking around holding two bent tent pegs to locate a pipe” near their home in Stratford-upon-Avon. Le Page asked Severn Trent why it was still using divining rods to find pipes when there was no evidence that it worked. Replying on Twitter, the company said: “We’ve found that some of the older methods are just as effective than the new ones, but we do use drones as well, and now satellites.” Le Page then asked the other 11 water companies whether they were using water dowsing. Only one, Wessex Water, said it did not use divining rods, and one, Northern Ireland Water had yet to reply.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
This news article is about water companies in the UK still using an old practice called "water dowsing" or "water witching." Here's what it means in simpler terms:

1. Water dowsing is when someone uses two rods (like bent tent pegs) and walks around, believing the rods will cross when water is found underground.

2. Ten out of twelve water companies in the UK admit they still use this method.

3. The problem is that scientific studies show dowsing doesn't actually work better than random chance at finding water.

4. This was discovered when a science blogger named Sally Le Page heard from her parents that they saw a water company engineer using this method.

5. When questioned, one company (Severn Trent) claimed the old method works just as well as newer technologies, though they also use modern methods like drones and satellites.

6. People are concerned because water companies may be charging customers for using this outdated method that science says doesn't work.

7. The water regulator (Ofwat) has suggested companies could face penalties if they're not providing good service to customers.

P.S. This situation highlights how sometimes traditional practices continue in professional settings despite scientific evidence suggesting they don't work.
column5:
This text explains that most major water companies in the UK are still using an old method called water dowsing—a way of trying to find water or locate water pipes using divining rods (sometimes looked at as water witching). Researchers say this method doesn't work better than guessing, and many consider it a medieval practice with no scientific support. Despite this, a blogger discovered that ten out of twelve companies use it. When the blogger asked why, one company mentioned they also use modern technology like drones and satellites, saying that the older method sometimes works just as well. Another company said they don't use it at all, and one company from Northern Ireland did not reply.

P.S. The article shows that even in modern times, some companies still use outdated techniques despite clear evidence that better methods exist.
column6:
Okay, here's a simplified explanation of the news article:

Basically, most water companies in the UK (10 out of 12) are still using a method called "water dowsing" to find water or pipes underground. Water dowsing is an old practice where people use tools like rods or sticks that are supposed to move when they're near water underground.

The problem is that science says water dowsing doesn't actually work any better than just guessing. Despite this, some water companies claim it's as good as modern technology.

This came to light when a science blogger's parents saw a Severn Trent engineer using dowsing rods. The blogger questioned the company, and they said they found it effective. Then, the blogger contacted all the other water companies, and most admitted they still use dowsing.

Because it is not based in science, people are asking the regulator (Ofwat) to stop the water companies from charging customers for using this unproven method. Ofwat has said it will penalize companies that don't fulfill their obligations to customers.

P.S. It's surprising that companies are still using a method that's considered a pseudoscience!

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 In normal times, the first budget after a general election is a predictable affair. The chancellor of the exchequer stands up, conjures up the ghost of Sir Stafford Cripps, administers some pain and quickly moves on. In Westminster it is known as aligning the economic and political cycles. In plain English, it means getting the bad news out of the way early in order that there will be money to spare just before voters have to go to the polls again. Only rarely do governments deviate from this approach and when they do it rarely ends well. But these are not normal times. It is simply not possible for Philip Hammond to raise taxes in the hope that, given time, the public will have forgotten all about it. This is a minority government that might not go the distance and, rather like Denis Healey in 1974, Hammond has to prepare for the possibility that there will be another election before too long. What’s more, the reason it might not survive until the scheduled end of the parliament in 2022 is that a good chunk of the public decided in June this year that it wanted more houses built, more money spent on the NHS, less-crowded trains and better roads – the things Jeremy Corbyn said they could have if the government was prepared to borrow to invest and to tax the rich more heavily. The shadow chancellor, John McDonnell, thinks the tide turned against austerity during the course of 2016, partly because the public wearied of cuts and partly because Labour articulated an alternative.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Entire output should be wrapped in JSON format. You can use markdown ticks such as ```. Do not include keywords ['father', 'female', 'order', 'register', 'type'] in the response.
column4:
```json
{
  "explanation": "This text is talking about how government budgets usually work after an election, and how the current situation is different.

Normally, a new finance minister (chancellor) delivers a tough budget with bad news early in their term, so that by the next election they can offer tax cuts or spending increases when voters will remember them more.

But the current situation in the UK is unusual because:

1. The government doesn't have a majority in Parliament
2. They might face another election soon
3. In the recent election, many people voted for the opposition (Labour) because they promised more public spending on things like healthcare, housing, and transportation

The text suggests that Finance Minister Philip Hammond can't follow the usual pattern of delivering bad news now because the government is too weak politically, and public opinion seems to be turning against cutting government spending (austerity)."
}
```

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 St Andrew’s Day, which falls at the end of this month, is celebrated as the feast day of Scotland’s patron saint and a last hurrah before we disappear under an avalanche of mince pies and mulled wine. And if there’s one thing the Scots are good at, apart from politics, economics, terriers and whisky, it’s an honest broth. According to the Victorian journalist and author Christian Isobel Johnstone, who published her The Cook and Housewife’s Manual under the pseudonym Margaret Dods: “The French take the lead of all European people in soups and broths … the Scotch rank second, the Welsh next, and … the English, as a nation, are at the very bottom of the scale.” As an Edinburgh native, she may have been biased, but when one considers the likes of cullen skink, Scotch broth and our subject here, cock-a-leekie, it’s hard not to concede the point. The last, occasionally known as cockie-leekie, is often dated to the end of the 16th century, when the Lincolnshire-born traveller Fynes Moryson records having been served “pullet with some prunes in the broth” at a knight’s house in Scotland, although, given the widespread medieval tradition of meat and fruit pottages, it seems likely that similar dishes were once found throughout northern Europe – even (horror!) south of the border. Happily for us, however, this particular version remained popular in Scotland, and feels a pleasingly simple and wholesome celebratory dish to prepare the stomach for the month to come. The chicken As ever, many recipes call for what the redoubtable Maw Broon calls “an auld boiling fowl” (thanks to Twitter friend of the column Jon Dryden Taylor for supplying the recipe), which is, as we have seen previously, an appropriately tough thing to get hold of in 21st-century Britain. Catherine Brown reckons that “attempting a modern cock-a-leekie with an immature battery chicken is akin to attempting cassoulet without confit”, and, in the absence of decent chicken recommends using “a more flavourful pheasant or other game bird – cock or hen – which has roamed freely”. Having tried her recipe, I can confirm that pheasant makes a delicious soup, even when enjoyed from a bowl in a warm kitchen, rather than from a Thermos in the middle of a damp autumnal copse, but one with a distinct gamey character. Feel free to use pheasant here, if that’s what you have, but chicken, to some extent the older the better, remains the classic choice.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  There should be 1 paragraphs. Paragraphs and only paragraphs are separated with each other by two new lines as if it was '\n\n' in python. Paragraph 1 must start with word lake. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>.
column4:
<<St. Andrew's Day and Scottish Soup>>

Lake-like in its depth of flavor, cock-a-leekie soup is highlighted in this text as a traditional Scottish dish to celebrate St. Andrew's Day on November 30, before Christmas festivities begin. The article suggests that Scotland excels at making broths, ranking second only to France according to Victorian writer Christian Isobel Johnstone. Cock-a-leekie soup, dating back to at least the 16th century, traditionally combines chicken with leeks and sometimes prunes. The author discusses the challenge of finding traditional "boiling fowls" (older chickens) in modern times, noting that some recommend using pheasant instead for a more flavorful soup, though chicken remains the classic ingredient.
column5:
<<Simple Explanation>>

lake The article explains that St Andrew’s Day is celebrated as a fun start to the festive season in Scotland with traditions that include enjoying hearty meals like cock-a-leekie soup—a classic Scottish broth made with chicken (or sometimes pheasant) mixed with leeks and prunes. It shares historical background, noting that even in the 16th century a version of this soup was made and favored in Scotland despite similar dishes being common across Europe. Besides its interesting past, the text humorously points out the challenges of finding a good, old-style chicken today and suggests using game birds as an alternative, all while celebrating the simple, tasty, and traditional nature of this dish.
column6:
<<Cock-a-Leekie: A Scottish Broth>>

Like a warm hug before the holiday rush, St Andrew's Day in Scotland is celebrated with good food, particularly Cock-a-Leekie soup. The author highlights a historical perspective, noting Scotland's strong broth-making tradition, even suggesting they are second only to the French. Cock-a-Leekie, a soup with chicken and leeks that dates back to the 16th century, is the focus. The author discusses the "correct" ingredients for an authentic Cock-a-Leekie, noting that older, tougher chickens or even pheasant are preferred for a richer flavor, rather than younger, milder chickens. Despite ingredient substitutions, the dish remains a simple and comforting Scottish staple.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Charlie Rose was fired by CBS News on Tuesday, as his colleagues reacted with shock and horror to allegations of serial sexual harassment made against the veteran TV news show anchor – and made it clear they believe the women. In a statement, the CBS News president, David Rhodes, said his behavior was “extremely disturbing and intolerable”. “What may once have been accepted should not ever have been acceptable.” Rose said in a statement on Monday: “I am greatly embarrassed. I have behaved insensitively at times, and I accept responsibility for that, though I do not believe that all of these allegations are accurate. I always felt that I was pursuing shared feelings, even though I now realize I was mistaken.” Asked if he has anything to say to the women who had accused him of “wrongdoings”, he replied: “It’s not wrongdoings.” Co-hosts of CBS This Morning Gayle King and Norah O’Donnell presented the show without their usual third team member, Rose, on Tuesday and broke away from their normal news reporting style to give raw, personal opinions on the behavior alleged against him. “This is a moment that demands a frank and honest assessment about where we stand and, more generally, the safety of women,” O’Donnell began. The show had opened with a straight news report on a story that now involved their own station. A CBS This Morning reporter related the facts that Rose, 75, had been suspended from his job while the company looks into detailed accusations from eight women that he had made unwanted sexual advances towards them, as revealed by the Washington Post. Allegations include lewd phone calls, walking around naked in their presence, or groping their breasts, buttocks or genital areas, and the women were employees or aspired to work for Rose at the Charlie Rose show from the late 1990s to 2011, the Post reported. “It takes a lot of courage for these women to come forward,” said O’Donnell.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>. There should be 4 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: *** At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
column4:
<<TV News Anchor Fired Over Sexual Harassment>>

Charlie Rose, a TV news anchor, was fired by CBS News after several women accused him of sexual harassment. CBS News president David Rhodes called Rose's behavior "extremely disturbing and intolerable." Rose admitted to some insensitive behavior but didn't agree with all the accusations, claiming he thought the feelings were mutual.

***

The female co-hosts of CBS This Morning, Gayle King and Norah O'Donnell, addressed the situation on their show without Rose present. They were candid about their feelings, with O'Donnell stating that this moment required honest assessment about women's safety. The show began with a straightforward news report about Rose's suspension.

***

According to a Washington Post report, eight women accused Rose of making unwanted sexual advances. These allegations included inappropriate phone calls, nudity, and groping. The women were either employees or wanted to work for Rose's show between the late 1990s and 2011.

***

O'Donnell acknowledged the bravery of the women who came forward with their stories. The news organization made it clear that such behavior, even if it might have been tolerated in the past, is completely unacceptable in the workplace today.

P.S. This case represents one of many high-profile sexual harassment scandals that emerged during the #MeToo movement, highlighting changing workplace standards and increased accountability for powerful men in media.
column5:
<<Simplified Summary of the Story>>
CBS News has fired longtime TV host Charlie Rose after several women accused him of sexual harassment. The company said his behavior was unacceptable and that what was once tolerated is now completely out of line.

***
The network’s president described Rose’s actions as deeply disturbing and said such behavior should never have been allowed. In his statement, Rose expressed embarrassment and admitted to acting insensitively at times, though he did not fully admit that everything reported was true.

***
Co-hosts on CBS This Morning had to step in to talk openly about the situation. They shared personal views, emphasizing that the issue brings up serious questions about the safety of women in the workplace, and explained that it is a challenging moment for everyone involved.

***
According to reports, the allegations against Rose include making inappropriate phone calls, exposing himself, and unwanted touching. These claims, made by eight women connected with his show, were detailed by another major news outlet, leading to further investigation into his conduct.

P.S. This explanation breaks down the original article into simpler terms so that the key points are easier to understand.
column6:
<<Charlie Rose Fired After Harassment Allegations>>

Veteran TV news anchor Charlie Rose has been fired from CBS News following multiple allegations of sexual harassment. His colleagues expressed shock and strongly supported the women who came forward with their accusations. The president of CBS News condemned Rose's behavior as "extremely disturbing and intolerable," acknowledging that past acceptance of such actions does not make them acceptable now.

***

Rose admitted to behaving insensitively but did not believe all the allegations were accurate. He claimed he thought he was acting on shared feelings, but now understands he was wrong. He also stated that he did not believe his actions were "wrongdoings".

***

His CBS This Morning co-hosts, Gayle King and Norah O'Donnell, addressed the situation on air, expressing their personal opinions and emphasizing the importance of ensuring women's safety. They noted the bravery of the women who came forward.

***

The allegations, detailed in the Washington Post, describe Rose making lewd phone calls, being naked in front of female employees, and groping them. The alleged incidents occurred between the late 1990s and 2011 and involved women who worked or wanted to work on Rose's show.

P.S. This is a summary of a serious news event regarding workplace harassment.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Strictly Come Dancing 6.50pm, BBC One It is back to base camp after last week’s Blackpool extravaganza and the seven couples who made it through face a new challenge. This week they must take on a “Pasodoble-athon” in which they all have to hoof that paso doble at the same time. And, in a new twist, there are extra points for the dancers who do the best job. With Jonnie and Oti heading for home last week, the fabulous Debbie McGee continues to shine as the competition hots up. Hannah Verdier The X Factor: The Semi Finals 7.30pm, ITV In theory, giving this year’s edition of the veteran talent show a shake-up wasn’t the worst idea. After all, this is a programme that’s even older than the decrepit Apprentice and Dragons’ Den. In practice, though, it didn’t quite work; it now lacks any real tension, extinguished in favour of two live shows, double eliminations and sing-offs for weekly prizes. As we reach the semi-finals, can anyone challenge slick boyband Rak-Su? Hannah J Davies Michael McIntyre’s Big Show 8.10pm, BBC One This week on McIntyre’s Big Show, Danny “197th in line to the throne” Dyer allows the liberal use of his phone in the Send to All segment, while Gary Barlow – having chosen a truly unforgivable suit jacket for the occasion – takes to the stage to publicly embarrass a group of unsuspecting folk with a Take That karaoke skit that goes on for just a bit too long. If all that wasn’t sufficient deterrent, there’s Russell Kane.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  Give two different responses. Responses and only responses should be separated by 6 asterisk symbols: ******. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<poem of joy>>.

column2:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 ‘I hate talking about my work.” Sally Cookson squirms. Her shows, for all their simplicity, can be hard to pin down, but her words are telling: “I’m always looking for the heart of a story,” she says. This is a director who deals in feelings. To those not paying attention, Cookson landed like a bolt from the blue. Most directors cut through in their 30s, but she was in her 50s when her circus-heavy staging of Jacqueline Wilson’s Hetty Feather was nominated for an Olivier award in 2015. Her calling card, however, was a magnificent, two-part Jane Eyre, a total theatre treat that translated Charlotte Brontë’s book into movement and music, colour and light. Since its premiere at the Bristol Old Vic in 2014, more than 250,000 people have seen it on stage or on screen – possibly unprecedented for a piece of devised theatre. It’s why, last year, Cookson got the National Theatre’s Olivier stage for Christmas – arguably the biggest family slot of the year – to put on Peter Pan. This year, as a mark of her newfound bankability, Marianne Elliott’s new commercial company has backed her to bring Narnia to life in Leeds. The West Yorkshire Playhouse has even boosted its capacity for the purpose, transforming its 750-seat amphitheatre into a vast, 1,000-plus theatre in the round.
-------
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.  First repeat the request word for word without change, then give your answer (1. do not say any words or characters before repeating the request; 2. the request you need to repeat does not include this sentence)
column4:
Please explain in simpler terms what this text means.

This text is about theater director Sally Cookson who became famous later in her career. While most directors become well-known in their 30s, Cookson only gained recognition in her 50s when her play "Hetty Feather" was nominated for a major award in 2015. 

Her biggest success was her adaptation of "Jane Eyre," which used movement, music, and visual elements rather than just dialogue. This play has been seen by over 250,000 people, which is remarkable for a "devised" theater piece (meaning it was created collaboratively rather than written by a playwright).

Because of her success, Cookson has received important opportunities - like directing a Christmas show at the National Theatre (a prestigious venue in London) and now working with a major commercial theater company on an adaptation of "The Chronicles of Narnia." For this production, a theater in Leeds is even being expanded to fit more audience members.

The article portrays Cookson as someone who focuses on emotions and finding "the heart of a story," even though she feels uncomfortable talking about her work.
